column2: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23.--Signor Salvini, accompanied by several friends, arrived in this city this evening from Baltimore, where he is playing an engagement and occupied a box at the Chestnut-Street Opera house, where he witnessed the performance of his son in the play of "Romeo and Juliet." He returned to Baltimore tonight.

When the trial of John Kenny, the bill poster, for the murder of John Lennon was resumed is the Kiags County Court of Sessions yesterday afternoon, Officer John Clancy took the witness stand. His testimony was merely a corroboration of that given by Officers McMahon and
CHARLESTON, Jan. 23.--The Princess Louise will embark on board her Majesty's ship Dido at 5 P.M. to-morrow, and will start for Bermuda at 7 o'clock Thursday morning.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 23.--At the conclusion of the trial of the mandamus case of Chalmers against Myers to-day, Judge Wharton, after delivering his opinion, instructed the jury to return a verdict for the plaintiff. The case will now go to the Supreme Court on appeal of Secretary of State Myers.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23.--Peter Marvine, an animal trainer, was severely injured by a lioness belonging to J.B. Doris's interocean circus, in the Winter quarters of the show, at Frankford, a suburb of this city, last evening.
Some days ago Capt. Folk, of the Twelfth Precinct, Brooklyn, arrested R.K. Van Vloten on a charge of swindling Eggert Brothers out of $35 worth of cigars.

One of the oddest of recent advertisements appeared in the Herald yesterday. "A gentleman" advertised that he "would like to make the acquaintance of cultivated and refined ladies and gentlemen who, while they do not receive the accepted doctrines of
NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 23.--Red Cloud and his interpreter left this city this morning for Washington. They will be accompanied as far as Jersey City by Prof. Marsh of Yale College and friends.
PROVIDENCE, R.L., Jan. 23.--The condition of Prof. S.S. Greene, of Brown University, who had a stroke of apoplexy yesterday, has to-night taken an unfavorable turn, and his death is anticipated.
There was a peculiar and extraordinary insident in the Passaic Court of Oyer and Terminer, at Paterson, N.J., yesterday.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 23.--At noon today the Senate came into the House chambers for the sixth time. Gov. Gilman not being present, Senator Goodrich, President pro tem., took his seat on the Speaker's left. Several Senators and Representatives who were absent yesterday were present to-day.
Alderman Wells presented a petition to the Common Council yesterday, signed by many residents of the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards, asking that the Harlem Bride, Morrisania
OMAHA, Jan. 23.--The Republican caucus last evening was attended by 67 members, that being the number required to elect. Fiftythree signed the caucus call, and the balance ...
Mayor Edson was unable to attend yesterday's session of the committee which is considering the best method of securing more water for New-York, and his place as Chairman was taken by O.B. Potter.

HAMBURG, Jan. 23.--According to the statement of another survivor of the disaster to the steam-ship Cimbria, as late as 2 o'clock Friday morning Capt. Hansen received a report that the Cimbria's lights were all burning properly.
For a good many years the people of Sing Sing have been endeavoring to induce the NewYork Central and Hudson River Railroad Company to extend the Tarrytown specials to Sing Sing.

PARIS, Jan. 23.--The Cabinet Council today adjourned to the Elysee from the residence of M. Duclerc, the Prime Minister. It is reported that the members of the Cabinet have tendered their resignations to President Grevy. None of the Ministers attended the bureaus of the Chamber of Deputies to-day, La France prints the report that the Ministry has resigned.

The lecture-room of the Long Island College Hospital was crowded by a representative Brooklyn audience last evening, the occasion being the opening exercises of the twenty-fourth regular session of the college.

BOSTON, Jan. 23.--Edwin M. Towle, who is charged with complicity in the alleged misappropriation of funds of the Pacific Bank of this city, was arrested and, together with George R. Eager was arraigned in the United States Circuit Court to-day.

Miss Clara A. Weston, a daughter of Mr. George S. Weston, was married last evening to Mr. Harry W. Williams. The ceremony took place in All Souls' Episcopal Church, and was performed by the Rector, the Rev. Dr. R. Heber Newton.

James Burke and Michael Dunn, who were arrested in New-York about six weeks ago charged with the murder of Thomas McKeon at Elizabethport on the occasion of an excursion of the Singer Sewing-machine Company's employes last Summer, were arraigned in the Union County (N.J.) Oyer and Terminer yesterday.

The most important constitutional questions which the Supreme Court of the United States has been called upon to decide in the last few years have arisen under the fourteenth amendment, and its full scope and meaning can hardly be considered as settled yet. One point in regard to its application may, however, be looked upon as finally determined.
BOSTON, Jan. 23.--A special dispatch from Augusta, Me., states that the Judiciary Committee of the House will soon report a bill re-establishing the death penalty for murder in that State.

TRALEE, Jan. 23.--Poff and Barrett were hanged at 8 o'clock this morning for the murder of Thomas Brown, near Castle Island. They protested their innocence until the last moment. There was little excitement.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 23.--A terrible tragedy occurred here at noon to-day. The wife of John Zempirek, a laborer, living in Sixth-street, killed her three children in a most brutal manner, literally cutting them in pieces.
The cold weather which has been diffusing itself over the West, and which has made its presence felt in New-York, was very promiscuous in its movements yesterday.
GALVESTON, Texas, Jan. 23.--A special dispatch to the News from Austin says: "The Legislature has re-elected the Hon. Richard Coke to the United States Senate."

ALBANY, Jan. 23.--Farmer Brooks handed up to the Clerk's desk to-day a resolution from his Ways and Means Committee calling upon the Republican heads of State departments to report to the Assembly within 10 days whether they can reduce the expenses of their departments without abridging their usefulness.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--The tea trade, or at least that part of it which does not deal in "painted," "refuse," or "rotten" teas, will hear, with pleasure, that the Ways and Means ...

DENVER, Col., Jan. 23.--The Senatorial problem still continues unsolved. The following is the result of the last ballot in the caucus to-night: Pitkin, 17; Hammil, 12; Routt, 2; Tabor, 17; Bowen, 5; scattering, 1.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--Gen. and Mrs. E.F. Beale gave a reception this evening in honor of the Hon. Charles Crocker and family, of San Francisco.

Very little news was received yesterday at the office of the Hamburg-American Packet Company with reference to the loss of the steamer Cimbria. In the morning the following telegram from Hamburg, dated yesterday, was received by Mr. Kunhardt:
The Grand Jury yesterday investigated the complaint against Frank Ramsdell, who was held by the Coroner on the charge of having shot

The committee of the Hoboken Common Council appointed to confer with the officers of the North Hudson Railway Company in relation to an elevated road from the ferry to the Heights, reported last night that they had held several interviews with the company's representatives, and that the latter were not willing to pay anything for the franchise.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--Representative Steele, of Indiana, introduced this morning a joint resolution to suspend the operation of the proviso of section 1.094, Revised Statutes, so as to authorize the President to fill any vacancy which may occur

WHEELING, West Va., Jan. 23.--The election for United States Senator took place in the two houses of the Legislature this forenoon with the following result: Senate--John E. Kenna, (Dem.,) 17; George E. Loomis, (Rep.,) 7; John T. Jarney, (Grbk.,) 2. House --Kenna, 36; Loomis, 21; Jarney, 3. The result will be declared in joint session to-morrow at noon.

BOSTON, Jan. 23.--Albion G. Emery, a police officer, committed suicide to-day by shooting at his home in South Boston. He was 37 years of age and leaves a widow and three children. Temporary insanity was the cause of the act.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23.--A dispatch from Los Angeles states that yesterday afternoon Dr. Ross commenced the work of carefully examining for the first time the fragments of bodies which had been picked up at the wreck, and made a remarkable discovery.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 23.--A special dispatch from Pine Hill to the Courier-Journal says: "Yesterday some men engaged in railroad work attempted to dry a number of Hercules powder cartridges, when they exploded, blowing a blacksmith's shop to pieces and killing Albert Reeves, Louis Fortner, and David Brown. The bodies were thrown 50 feet into the air. The cartridges contained 40 ounces each of nitro-glycerine."

"Berths Heyman is a bad woman, a very bad woman," said Commissioner Jacob Hess, of the Department of Charities and Correction, yesterday afternoon, in conclusion of a narrative of that notorious confidence woman's performances at the penitentiary on Blackwell's Island.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24.--Information has been received at Brisbane, Queensland, that a large three-masted schooner was lost at the mouth of the Fly River, New-Guinea.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--Mr. HOAR offered a resolution discharging the Committee on Commerce from further consideration of the House bills to amend the Revised Statutes in relation to danger signals. Laid over under the rules. Mr. Hoar said he would call it up at an early day.
COLUMBUS, Jan. 24.--Republican members of the General Assembly are, as a rule, well pleased with the tone of the meeting last night.
The trial of Louis D'Argencour, an engraver, on the charge of engraving Cuban postage stamps and currency, was begun in the criminal branch of the United States Circuit Court before ...

ROCHESTER, Jan. 24.--The twenty-eighth annual meeting of the Western New-York Horticultural Society convened here this morning. Patrick Barry, of Rochester, was re-elected President. The Vice-Presidents are: W.C. Barry, Rochester; H.E. Hooker, Rochester; R.J. Swan, Geneva; E. Moody, Lockport. Treasurer--P.C. Reynolds, of Rochester. About 80 members are in attendance.
TROY, Jan. 24.--Mayor Fitzgerald will forbid the proposed glove-fights between Sullivan, Coburn, and other lesser lights of the prize-ring, which are advertised to take place here on Monday evening.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Jan. 24.--The trial of James H. Corey for extortion is still on. Dr. Field was examined to-day as to the sanitary arrangements of the Hotel Bellevue and the condition of the typhoid fever patients. Omar Sickels, the bathing master, said he went to the hotel well, and was taken sick with typhoid fever while there.

At the meeting of the Medico-Legal Society last evening a paper was read by Dr. Edward C. Mann entitled "A Plea for Lunacy Reform." Our laws regarding lunacy, the Doctor said, are very defective, and seem to be based almost wholly on the false principle that personal liberty is of little value.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 24.--To-day George W. Vanatta, Chairman of the Court-house Committee of the Board of Chosen Freeholders, began an action against the Trenton Times, an afternoon newspaper of this city, of which Lawrence S. Mott is editor, for libel, demanding $5,000 damages.

HALIFAX, Jan. 24.--George Munro, the NewYork publisher, who, at different times, recently offered a number of bursaries to the Dalhousie College, has now given another substantial evidence of his friendship for that institution by endowing three new tutorships--Latin, Greek, and mathematics--at $1,000 per annum each.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 24.--During the inquest on the Newhall House disaster this morning O.M. Linehan, the engineer; McKenzie, the watchman, and Klupack, the store-keeper, were examined.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, Jan. 24.--Mrs. Jane Baldwin, until a few months ago the Postmistress of this city, and widow of the late Caleb Baldwin, former Judge of the State Supreme Court and member of the Alabama Claims Commission, died at noon to-day, after three weeks illness, at the age of 52. No lady in the State was more extensively or more favorably known.

Thomas Burns, a wagon driver, who had no home, committed suicide yesterday by jumping out of a third-story window of No. 200 West Thirtysixth-street.

The iron men, who have been making strenuous efforts to convince the Congressional committees in Washington that their interests should be carefully protected in the tariff revision, are endeavoring to get up a public demonstration in their own behalf in this City.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 24.--Probably the most unique and intricate case that ever puzzled the minds of any tribunal in this great Republic has been taxing for a week the judicial abilities of the Supreme Court of this State. To the careless observer the learned Justices have appeared much as ...

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24.--Theatrical circles were greatly agitated last night over the sudden and unexpected closing of the Grand Opera-house, which has been under the joint management of Messrs. Charles A. Andrews and L.E. Stockwell for the past three months.

BOSTON, Jan. 24.--In summing up the statistics of the mutual marine and joint stock fire and marine insurance companies of this city the Traveller says: " Of the 15 companies only five show a small increase of surplus over last year and 10 a decrease.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 24.--Messrs. John G. Roach and T.H. Sherley, prominent local whisky dealers, were seen by THE TIMES'S correspondent to-day about the scheme to export whisky on which tax is due, to secure relief which, ...

PANAMA, Jan. 13.--Letters from Callao dated Jan. 4 report that the public now perceive that peace must be at once made. The difficulty is, who is to make it? The Chicago Tribune is quite clear that what Chicago especially needs is an opera-house.
BRUNSWICK, Me., Jan. 24.--Five students of the Sophomore Class of Bowdoin College were in definitely suspended yesterday for hazing.

A lawsuit bearing on the proprietorship of a seat in the Stock Exchange has been begun by Henry McCabe, through his counsel, Horatio F. Averill, of No. 120 Broadway. DOVER, Del., Jan. 24.--In the House to-day the Senate bill to abolish the whipping of persons convicted of murder in the second degree was killed by a vote of 10 to 8.
The Aldermanic committee on the celebration of the centennial anniversary of the evacuation of New-York by the British troops met yesterday at the residence of its Chairman, Alderman John Cochrane.

During the performance of "Around the World in Eighty Days," in the Park Theatre, in Newark, N.J., on Tuesday evening last, Mrs. Van Berg, of this City, who occupied one of the orchestra chairs, recognized her young daughter among the coryphees on the stage.
Members of the Legislature and of some of the trades organizations seem unable to rest easy so long as convicts in the State prisons are obliged to work.
EASTON, Penn., Jan. 24.--A habeas corpus was awarded to-day by Judge Meyers in the case of 50 Hungarians confined in jail here, on complaint of malicious mischief by the Wind Gap and ...

DETROIT, Jan. 24.--Two ballots were taken to-day in the Senatorial contest by the joint convention of the Legislature. On the first Stout reached 49 and Ferry 48. On the second ballot each had 48 votes, the remainder ...

A motion made by the counsel for the defendant to dismiss the complaint in the suit of James M. Selover against Jerome B. Chaffee for $750,000 damages was argued before Judge Donohue, in the Supreme Court, Circuit, Part III., yesterday morning.

Lovers of the national game assembled at Prospect Park yesterday afternoon to witness a game of base-ball played on the ice. The game was played on skates and afforded much amusement to the spectators, who heartily enjoyed the ...
SOPHIA, Jan. 24.--Bulgaria has given notice to the British Diplomatic Agent here demanding admission to the London conference on the Danubian question.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24.--The collections for the sufferers by the German floods to date amount to over $20,000, and 80,000 marks have already been cabled to Friedrich Knapp, Berlin. Matinee performances given to-day by J. L. Stoddard, at the Central Music Hall, and Josephine Gallmeyer, at the Grand Opera-house, for the benefit of the sufferers netted over $600.

About 60 gentlemen, most of whom are practical farmers, assembled at No. 55 Beekmanstreet at noon yesterday, and organized the Second Ensilage Congress, by electing as President Francis Morris, of Baltimore, the first man who built a silo, or fodder pit, in this country. Mr. J.B. Brown, was elected Secretary.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 24. -- On the strength of reports that the Patterson and Leedom mystery was dry, there was a genuine oldfashioned boom at the Oil Exchange in this city to-day, which brought in lots of outside purchasers and made the liveliest market seen for many a day.
Mr. Bartley Campbell's latest melodrama, "Siberia," will be produced at the FourteenthStreet Theatre on Feb. 26.
The steam-ship Republic, of the White Star Line, which arrived here last Saturday, was laid up in Liverpool for nearly two months, during which time her cabins were refitted.

The Tariff bill of the Ways and Means Committee is accompanied by an elaborate document showing the present rates of duty, those proposed by the Tariff Commission, and those proposed by the committee.

A cablegram from Rome to the New-York Catholic Review announces that Pope Leo XIII, has appointed to the vacant See of Charleston, S.C., in succession to the late Bishop Lynch, Mgr. Northrup, and to the new See of Grand Rapids, Mich., as its first Bishop, Mgr. Richter.

That part of the Union Pacific Railway which runs 58 miles to the westward from the onehundredth meridian was built by a man named Boomer, under a contract made between him and Thomas C. WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--The following business was transacted in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day: No. 159--The United States, appellant, vs. The Steamer Nuestra Senora de Regla, argument continued by William Allen Butler for appellee, and concluded by Assistant ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--The Army Ordnance Board, now in session in New-York, has been authorized to visit Troy, to inquire into the manufacture of steel, with a view to making steel field guns for the use of the Army.
The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange listed the following securities at its meeting yesterday:

CINCINNATI, Jan. 24.--Reuben R. Springer a few weeks ago proposed to endow the College of Music with $80,000 upon condition that the stockholders would agree to relinquish all claims to dividends. Seventy-one gentlemen own the 665 shares of the stock of the college--valued at $50 each.
BOSTON, Jan. 24.--The military social event of the season was the ball to-night of the "Veteran Tigers" (Boston Light Infantry) at the Massachusetts Charitable Mechanics' Association Building.
NEWPORT, Jan. 24.--Kate Judd, of Boston, has been arrested on suspicion of setting fire to the Weaver Villa, where she was employed, yesterday morning.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 24.--The people residing in the north-eastern part of this city, familiarly known as the "Five Points," were thrown into a state of great excitement early this morning by a loud report resembling that accompanying an earthquake.

ALBANY, Jan. 24.--The Democrats very unwillingly to-day adopted a civil service reform resolution introduced into the Assembly by the young Republican member from Livingston, Mr. Brooks. In its original form it certainly was about as unobjectionable a grouping of words and ideas as could well be imagined. It read as follows:

CHICAGO, Jan. 24.--The weather this morning has greatly moderated, the thermometer being 80 higher than it was yesterday morning. It is now 12 above zero and rising. The blockades on the West and North-western railroads have been removed, and trains are running nearly on time.

LONDON, Jan. 25.--The steam-ship Lepanto, (Br., Capt. Rogers, from New-York Jan. 7, has arr. here. The steam-ship Ronfrew, Capt., Legget, from Baltimore Jan. 6, has arr. at Bordeaux. GLASGOW, Jan. 25.--The Allan Line steam-ship Mani toban, Capt. McNicol, from Portland Jan. 11, has arr. here.
PALMYRA, N.Y., Jan. 24.--Ex-Senator Robert H. Strahan was married here to-day to Miss Caroline Cuyler Candee, of this village.
ALBANY, Jan. 24.--The State Prisons Committee will start out upon its fishing expedition to-morrow afternoon.

After the committee appointed by Mayor Edson to consider the matter of an increased water supply for this City had been called to order in the Mayor's private office yesterday, ex-Senator James F. Pierce spoke briefly of a plan for introducing water from the Adirondack region, and introduced Dr. W. W. Laman, the originator of the ...
CHICAGO, Jan. 24.--The American Field will publish a reply from Dr. W. F. Carver to Capt. A. H. Bogardus in relation to the latter's propositions for pigeon-matches for the world's wing championship.

Some time between 6 P.M. Tuesday and 8 A.M. yesterday burglars entered the tailor's store of Peter Rontey, on the second floor of the building on the north east corner of Twenty-seventhstreet aad Broadway, and stole 150 pieces of cloth and linings worth $3,500.
Mrs. Vanderbilt, the widow of Commodore Vanderbilt, entertained a party of friends at luncheon yesterday at her residence, No. 10 Washington-place.

Gov. Stephens is a steady, methodical worker. He keeps doing. He never seems to tire. And he does everything thoroughly. He is never in a hurry, and always deliberate and painstaking. He sees all the company that comes to him, and he has a constant stream of visitors.

One of the chief reasons, it is said, for the existence of the famous second panel of the Sheriff's jury is to attempt, once a year, to get up a dinner to excel that eaten annually by the first panel of the Sheriff's jury.

The friends of Norman M. Pierce, a young chemist, of Buffalo, who is missing, called at the Police Central Office yesterday and enlisted the aid of the Police in the search for the young man.
The steam-ship Main, from Bremen, landed 378 immigrants at Castle Garden yesterday.

In the Kings County Court of Sessions yesterday Celia Johnson, a prisoner in RaymondStreet Jail, was the first witness called by counsel for John Kenny, the bill-poster, who is on trial for the murder of John Lennon, a car driver. She testified that on the night of the murder she was in ...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--The testimony of Andrew W. Moore, which attracted so much attention in the star route trial yesterday, has already been corroborated in many respects ...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--The President gave a dinner to the members of the Diplomatic Corps this evening.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24, 1883. It is stated to-night by apparently well-in formed persons that the Grand Jury to-day, by an almost unanimous vote, resolved to ignore the charges against William Dickson, of unlawfully influencing the star route jury, and directed their foreman to report accordingly to the Criminal Court to-morrow.

The Aldermanic Committee on Streets met in the City Hall yesterday and took up a resolution, introduced by Alderman Jaehne and referred to them, inquiring into alleged abuses of their franchises by the steam-heating companies. Park Commissioner Egbert L. Viele, who had been invited ...
HAVRE, Jan. 24.--The steamer Bavaria has arrived here from a cruise near the scene of the disaster to the Cimbria. The search was fruitless.

OMAHA, Jan. 24.--Two Senatorial ballots were taken to-day, showing no material change. The prospects of the Republican caucus are not improving. Fifty-five names signed the caucus call. It is believed now almost impossible to get the other 12 names necessary to nominate and elect. Democrats and Anti-Monopolists are unable as yet to effect a combination. There is no immediate prospect, apparently, of an election.

DUBLIN, Jan. 24.--At the Queen's Bench Division to-day Messrs. Davitt, Healy, and Quinn, who are charged with inciting to lawlessness, were ordered to find securities for their good behavior or to go to prison for six months.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--It is altogether probable that at the meeting of the Senate Committee on Commerce to-morrow two nominations of interest to New-York will be disposed of.

TRENTON, Jan. 24.--The joint meeting of the two houses to-day for the choice of a United States Senator was signalized at the opening by an unprecedented act of discourtesy to the Republican Senate. When the Senate marched into the Assembly Chamber it ...
CHARLESTON, Jan. 24.--The Princess Louise embarked on the Dido at 5 o'clock this afternoon. An immense throng lined the Battery to witness her departure.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24.--Stewart Brothers, proprietors of the Wellsbire Mills, Frankford, have made an assignment for the benefit of their creditors. The liabilities of the firm are placed at $60,000, but the assets are not given. The failure is said to be due to the selling of goods at less than the cost of manufacture.
BOSTON, Jan. 24.--Judge Gray, of the United States Circuit Court, has granted an injunction against the Peoples' Telephone Company (Dolbear's patent) in favor of the Bell Telephone Company.

MONTREAL, Jan. 24.--The second and most interesting day of the Winter Carnival has proved all that Canadians could wish or their visitors from abroad could anticipate in showing to advantage the healthful and exciting Winter sperts which are characteristic of the Dominion.
TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 24.--In joint session of the Legislature to-day the vote for United States Senator taken in the separate houses on Tuesday, was announced and Preston B. Plumb was declared elected.

The Commissioners of the Sinking Fund met in Mayor Edson's office yesterday and listened to a petition signed by 4,000 persons, asking that in disposing of the franchise of the Staten Island ferry the Commissioners pay full regard to the necessities of Staten Islanders in the matter of "larger, ...

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 24.--The Directors of the Southern Exposition have decided to open the display on Aug. 1 next, and continue it 100 days. Ground has been broken for the buildings, which will inclose a space measuring a half-mile around. The total amount of subscriptions to date is $250,000, within $50,000 of the full amount called for.

PARIS, Jan. 24.--The ex-Empress Eugenie has started from Paris for London. It is hard to say yet whether this is a consequence of a direct intimation from the French Government, as is stated, or whether the step is taken at the suggestion of her friends, all of whom are ...

The special performance of yesterday afternoon for the benefit of Mr. Lonsdale and Mr. Harris was a merry entertainment and must have the result of substantial satisfaction to the recipients. The theatre was filled and with an audience of the best character.

Senator Charles H. Russell, Receiver of the Knickerbocker Life Insurance Company, has issued a circular to the policy-holders and other creditors of the company, in which he advises them, as a matter of self-interest, against the employment of counsel to represent claims the validity of which ...

A statement of the amount of business done at the United States Sub-Treasury in this City during 1882, prepared by direction of Assistant United States Treasurer ActoE, shows that the total amount of business done by the Sub-Treasury during the year was $1,502,607,790.66.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 24.--The expected gain of Mr. Windom failed to materialize to-day. His vote was the same identically as that of yesterday. The few changes there were in the vote can be taken to signify nothing except the natural oscillation from day ...

CHICAGO, Jan. 24.--The leading produce markets were less active to-day and rather weak. There was a general recession of prices, with an absence of demand rather than a decided pressure to sell, buyers holding off to see what the new Board of Directors would do in reference to the margin "value" of corn for January.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 24.--The Montgomery Grays returned here from Opelika at 9 o'clock to-night. They report that the town is quiet.

TROY, Jan. 24.--The balloting for officers of the Grand Army of the Republic will begin at the State encampment to-morrow. At a late hour to-night Huggins, of Tonawanda withdrew from the race for the Grand Commandership in favor of Reynolds, of Rochester. This narrows the fight, probably on second ballot, to Bullard, Walker, and Murray, and it will soon be decided.

The Dock Commissioners, in answer to the appeal of the West Washington Market Association, resolved yesterday not to begin their proposed improvement of the water-front on the North River, west of West-street, between Dey ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--The recent exploit of Jansen, the notorious grave robber, in this city was a remarkably bold and reckless one, and the story was not fully told in the dispatch sent to the press last night.
A large gathering of the Alumni of the ical Department of the University of the City of New-York met last evening at Delmonico's to enjoy the twelfth annual dinner of the association.

One man, at least, has kept his head in the senseless scare which has beset the thirdrate statesmen who at present direct the political destinies of France. In the Senate on Monday M. WADDINGTON said that the republic was threatened ...

POUGHKEEPSIE, Jan. 24.--The first race of the season was sailed on the Hudson to-day by the Poughkeepsie Ice-boat Association. The contest was for the club pennant, which had been won in previous years by the Rail and the Restless.

ALBANY, Jan. 24.--The executive session of the Senate to consider the confirmation of the Railroad Commissioners, after listening to two or three rambling speeches, postponed taking any action until to-morrow.

ALBANY, Jan. 24.--The Green Driven Well and Water Supply Company, of New-York, capital $50,000, and the Hoffman Club, of New-York, were incorporated to-day. The Inter-continental Silver Mining Company, of Mexico, with a capital of $1,000,000, was incorporated this afternoon. The principal office of the company will be in NewYork. The New-York and Pennsylvania Coal and Iron Company, of New-York, was also incorporated. The capital of the company is $100,008.

BATH, Me., Jan. 24.--Bank Examiner Richards has prepared a statement of the condition of the People's Twenty-five-cent Savings Bank. All its securities are good, excepting $42,000 deposited in the Pacific Bank, of Boston.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24.--After the Reading Railroad became practically insolvent, but before the Receivers were appointed, for some months the company paid its employes in the mines and on the road in paper promises, which were technically called "wages scrip."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 24.--The CarverBogardus shooting-match, to come off here Feb. 14, is exciting a great deal of interest among sporting men all over the country, and letters are received daily which show that there will be a large attendance. The local managers propose to have a two days' tournament for the benefit of visiting sportsmen. Bogardus is the general favorite among betting men.

The Charity Ball, which is to take place at the Academy of Music this evening, promises, from the large sale of boxes and tickets, to be attended by a great number of persons.
The explosion of a kerosene lamp yesterday in the kitchen of No. 324 Flushing avenue, Brooklyn, caused a fire the damage arising from which is estimated at $4,300.

CUMBERLAND, Md., Jan. 24.--William M. Goldsborough was convicted of criminal libel to-day on account of a dispatch sent to the Washington Star on May 17, 1882, saying: "It is stated William M. Price has left Cumberland to avoid arrest in Morey letter forgery case." Price refused to go on the witness stand. Goldsborough will probably be sentenced to-morrow.

ALBANY, Jan. 25.--The New-York State Temperance Society met in annual convention this morning, about 50 members being present. BOSTON, Jan. 25.--At Winchester last evening, while coasting, a sled containing Mr. Teele and five young ladies struck a hitching-post, and the party was thrown violently to the ground. Miss McKenzie's injuries are of a very dangerous character.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--1 A.M.--For the Middle Atlantic States, increasing cloudiness, followed by rain, warm southerly, veering to colder westerly, winds, falling, followed by rising, barometer.

The Brooklyn Academy of Music presented a picturesque scene last evening on the occasion of the forty-fifth annual ball of the Emerald Association, by which a handsome sum was realized for the Brooklyn Roman Catholic orphan asylums.
QUEBEC, Jan. 30.--The weather yesterday was fine, and the Quebecers seemed to enjoy their carnival. There were few strangers, however, in town. The drive to Montmorenei was participated ...
PITTSBURG, Jan. 30.--William H. Vanderbilt has just placed $330,000 of the bonds and stock of the Pittsburg, McKeesport and Youghlogheny Road in this city.

TRENTON, Jan. 30.--The printing fight came to a head in the Senate this afternoon. It dates back to the time when "Staff" Little, now Receiver of the New-Jersey Central Railroad, was a clerk of the State Court of Chancery.
The citizens of Memphis, Tenn., have contributed nearly $2,000 for the relief of the sufferers by the floods in Germany.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--President Arthur held his first public reception of this season at the White House this evening.

The fifth of Prof. Charles A. Young's illustrated lectures on astronomy was enjoyed by a large audience in the Church of the Strangers last night. The subject was "Meteors and Comets," and the learned lecturer made his audience acquainted with agreat deal of astronomical information in a very entertaining way.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 30.--This morning the steam-boat Carolina, of tho Baltimore and Norfolk Line, while coming up the bay, off Cedar Point, 72 miles below this city, ran into the British steam-ship Riverbdale, lying at anchor.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 30.--The town of Brantford, Ontario, has been thrown into a state of great excitement over a social soandal in which the Rev. T.R. Beattle, Pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, figures conspicuously.

DUBLIN, Jan. 30.--Another friend of Mr. Quinn having offered to become his bail to prevent him from being imprisoned for six months, he refused the offer. He says he would not give bail if threatened with six years imprisonment.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 30.--The second evening of the opera festival has been rainy and disagreeable, yet there were 4,500 people in the hall. The attendance last night, which was estimated at 4,800 proved, when the count was made, to have been 5,500, With 1,000 less in the audience to-night ...

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 30.--Since about midnight last night St. Paul has been in the throes of a most unusual storm--a genuine snow blizzard-- enveloping the city in a whirling and comparatively blinding cloud of fine dry snow, which drifted rapidly, and in some places to a great depth, stopping most of the street cars and causing a very perceptible suspension of out-door business.

ALBANY, Jan. 30.--The Democrats jammed through the Assembly to-day their two bills giving them full control of the New Capitol and the State buildings, and securing them the spoils of office involved in the oompletion of the one and the management and maintenance of the other.

PARIS, Jan. 30.--M. Fallieres, while speaking in the Chamber of Deputies to-day in defense of M. Fabre's bill proscribing pretenders to the throne, was compelled to stop in consequence of feeling ill, and the sitting was suspended. After the sitting M. Fallieres fainted.

The fifth annual reception, exhibition drill, and ball of Palestine Commandery, No. 18, Knights Templar, took place in the Academy of Music last night and was, as usual, a brilliant and enjoyable affair. The music was excellent, the decorations elaborate and attractive, and the supper substantial as well as tempting.

Hetherington, of Atchison, filed articles of incorporation with the Secretary of State to-day. The capital stock of the company is $1,000,000. The persons named are to be the Directors for the first year.

OTTAWA, Jan. 31.--The extradition papers in the case of William Hall, the Newark forger, were forwarded by the Department of Justice to Toronto last night. The warrant for his surrender to the United States officers will be acted on at once. Mr. Murphy, Hall's counsel, failed to secure conditional surrender for him.

WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 31.--At the annual meeting of the American Poultry Association held here to-day, Philander Williams, of Taunton, was chosen President; Charles A. Sweet, of Buffalo, who clined re-election as President, First Vice-President, and George S. Josselyn, of Fredonia, N. Y., Secretary and Treasurer. Committees was appointed to revise the standard for exhibitions. The poultry show now being held here is pronounced the largest ever known in the country, there being 18,000 birds entered.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Jan. 31.--A few years ago the ground near the Kohinoor Colliery was undermined by Messrs. Heckscher Co., and in settling damaged several houses. Martin Conville brought suit for damages, and was yesterday awarded over $1,500. Other parties will now sue to recover.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 31.--William F. Cody, better known as Buffalo Bill, is ill here with pneumonia. The performance announced to be given to-night by his combination has been abandoned.

ALBANY, Jan. 31.--The Senate transacted a good deal of routine business and general local bills were considered in committee and ordered to a third reading, but the proceedings were of little public interest.
Mr. H. M. Pitt will take charge of the San Francisco Opera-house on April 21. He will produce a new comedy there.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31.--The star route, from The Dalles to Baker City, Oregon, was taken up in the Criminal Court to-day, and the entire morning session was consumed in the introduction of the official papers rotating to the route.

TROY, Jan. 31--In the case of Joseph Mackey, of this city, who was released from the Utica Insane Asylum on a writ of habeas corpus obtained by J.B. Silkman, Judge Ingalls, to-day, in an exhaustive opinion, confirmed the verdict of the jury that declared Mackey insane.

BROCKTON, Mass., Jan. 31.--A crank on the engine in C.H. Ward Co.'s shoe factory broke this morning, blowing out the cylinder head. The engine supplied steam to the adjoining factory of C.F. Porter Co. The 500 hands in both factories are thrown out of employment for two or three days.

MONTREAL, Jan. 31.--A few days ago several bodies were stolen from Ste. Marie de Maunoir. An attempt was made to frighten students into giving up the bodies, but without success. Then money was offered as an inducement, and two of the bodies were handed over for $80 ransom.

SUFFERN, N. Y., Jan. 31.--Burglars broke into the office of the Sterling Mountain Railroad, at Sterling Junction, on Monday night, and made a pretty good haul. Among the property stolen was about $30 worth of stamps and several gold pens.

RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 31.--The Hon. W. R. Cox, Congressman from the Fourth North Carolina District, was married to-day to Miss Fanny Augusta Lyman, eldest daughter of the Right Rev. Theodore B. Lyman, Bishop of this State.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31.--The official report of the earnings of the Philadelphia and Erie Railroad Company shows that the net earnings in December last were $86,000, an increase of $3,900 over the same period in 1881. The net earnings for the year 1882 were $1,412,000, an increase of $388,000 over the year 1881.

DETROIT, Jan. 31.--Only two Senatorial ballots were taken to-day. On the first Ferry and Stout each had 49; on the second each had 48. Burrows had 12. The remainder were scattered among five different candidates.

ALBANY, Jan. 31.--The Assembly, by a vote of 109 to 6, passed to-day the bill reducing the fare on the elevated railroads of New-York to 5 cents. There was much discussion over the measures and attempts to delay its passage were made by a number of the members.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Jan. 31.--Ex-Gov. Downey has published a card in which he scouts the tramp theory of the recent Tehichipi disaster and charges it to the carelessness of the railroad employes. He announces his intention of bringing a suit for heavy damages.

The motion was denied, and the injunction sustained.

ODESSA, Jan. 31.--A famine prevails in the Government of Kherson, and several peasants have committed suicide to escape witnessing the misery of their starving families.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., Jan. 31.--The fire in Bear Valley shaft is extending and is now burning in breasts Nos. 9 and 10 and in two manways. Large quantities of burning matter are being drawn out. The temperature at the breasts is very high, and the fire can be heard burning from the gangway. The officers will endeavor to extinguish the fire, if possible, without flooding the mine, as that would entail great expense.

SING SING, Jan. 31.--The earnings at Sing Sing Prison for Jaunary were $21,277 66; expenditures, $17,277 23, leaving a net profit of $4,000 43.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 31.--In the House to-day, among the bills read and referred was one framed by a committee of the Grangers to equalize taxation. It levies a tax on property of every kind. In the Senate the nominations of William H. Smith, to be Recorder of Philadelphia, and Messrs. Iseminger and Sensenderfer, to be Sealers of Weights and Measures in the same city, were rejected.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 31.--L. Candee Co., rubber works, to-day decided to stop work on Feb. 10. This will throw 1,500 persons out of employment. President Henry L. Hotchkiss said he could not tell when they would resume. The high prices of the raw material would cause a loss if manufacturing were continued with the present prices of manufactured goods. They would resume when the results of over-production ceased.

BROCKVILLE, Ontario, Jan. 31.--The sixth annual convention of the Eastern Ontario Dairymen's Association assembled here to-day. Several Americans were present, among them the Hon. Harris Lewis, of Frankfort, N.Y.; Prof. Wetherell, of Boston, and Robert McAdam, of Rome, N.Y.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 31.--James G. Roe, proprietor of the Glenridge House, a well-known Summer resort at Cornwall, this county, this afternoon made an assignment for the benefit of his creditors. It is stated that his failure was caused by the dullness of the boarding-house business at Cornwall last season.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 31.--The mission of Los Dernier to Florida has proved successful. The Legislature of this State accepts the invitation to send delegates to the New-England Manufacturers and Mechanics' Institute Fair the first week in September next, and appropriates $3,000 to carry it out.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 31.--A special to the Leader reports that the coal-miners in the Tuscarawas Valley to-day agreed to accept the terms of the operators.

HAVANA, Jan. 31.--The Government of Santo Domingo has ordered that vessels sailing from countries where Dominican Consuls reside must carry bills of health signed by the Consuls or they will not be allowed to enter the ports of the Republic. The order was to go into force for the United States in 30 days from Dec. 15 last.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31.--A dispatch from Matamoros, Mexico, says: "At the fire-works factory of Senor Meyra, in Amacueca, yesterday, a terrific exlosion occurred, followed by flying rockets and bombs. Meyra and four other members of his family were burned to death, and a number of other persons were badly injured."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 3.--A pamphlet of 50 pages, between forbidding black covers, was the "Misdemeanor Book" at the united States Naval Academy from 1877 until last October. WASHINGTON, Feb. 3.--After holding an executive session this morning the Senate resumed consideration of the Tariff bill. The amendment offered by Mr. Harris yesterday making the duty on cotton thread, yarn, warps or warp yarn, 30 percent ad valorem, was lost--yeas 23, nays 30.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3.--A communication from the Secretary of War was laid before the House to-day transmitting the petition of Col. George W. Getty for an act authorizing his retirement, with pay, according to his brevet rank of Major-General. It is accompanied by a letter from Gen. W.T. Sherman urging the justice of such retirement.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 3.--On Kingsbury Run, at the Willson-avenue crossing, is the oil refinery of Thurmer Teagle. The oil leaking from one of the stills ran into the run, and as that was unusually high, the oil camp up to the boiler-house, where it ignited and went off with a great explosion early this morning.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 4.--A special to the Herald, from Ashtabula, Ohio, says: "The drawbridge at the month of the river is gone. The Nickle Plate Railway bridge at Willoughby has been swept away."

ALBANY, Feb. 5.--The weekly dress parade of the members of Assembly took place this evening. The galleries were crowded with ladies, and many seats on the floor were given up to them.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5.--To-day was set apart under the rules of the House as one upon which motions could be made for suspensions of the rules in order to take up bills and resolutions.

Dr. Edward C. Harwood, of No. 44 West forty-ninth-street, reported at the office of the Health Department yesterday the particulars of a singular case of poisoning, presumably by eating fish. Between 8 and 9 o'clock last Saturday morning the Doctor was summoned to the residence of Mrs. Maria L. Labagh, No. 116 East Fifty-eighth street.

BERLIN, Feb. 5.--A small packet was sent to-day to Herr Keyssner, Supreme Court councilor. On opening it a slight explosion occurred, and on examination showed that it contained an infernal machine. Herr Keyssner subsequently received an anonymous letter, threatening him for his severity when examining law students.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 5.--The White River reached its highest at noon to-day. This is the highest point it has ever been known to reach. It has commenced to recede. The damage, although very serious, cannot be estimated as yet.

Coroner Hyler and his jury continued yesterday afternoon, at Port Chester, their investigation into the murder of Sife Marks, the peddler. Ten witnesses were examined, but nothing of importance was brought out. Charles Horton testified to seeing Theodore Hoffman, the alleged murderer, at Port Chester about noon last Tuesday.

The representatives of the steamers and sailing vessels plying between this port and various home and foreign ports have united in a petition to Congress for the establishment of a much-needed beacon at Romer Shoals, in the lower Bay.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5.--After holding an executive session the Senate resumed consideration of the Tariff bill. Mr. MORRILL again called attention to the brief time remaining before the end of the session, and urged the necessity for industry in dealing with the bill.

The Commissioners of Emigration yesterday sent their report for 1882 to the Legislature. This document states that the total number of immigrants landed here during the year was 520,355, of whom 476,086 were aliens.

Mr. W.S. Walcott made a triumphal progress yesterday afternoon from the final station of the elevated railroad to Gabe Case's hotel to eat the final brace of quail of the 30 brace which Mr. James Moffatt had backed him for $500 to devour in 30 days.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 5.--Thus far there has been no serious damage from high water here and none is apprehended. There has been the largest rise in the Allegheny ever known, but the water will not reach Cincinnati before Thursday, which will afford enough time to provide for it.

CASTINE, Me., Feb. 5.--The schooner Hero, of Boston, was picked up in Penobscot Bay to-day. Both of her anchors and chains were gone, and her crew were half frozen. They were brought to this city by the revenue cutter Woodbury.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 5.--The snow-storm and blizzard that has prevailed for three or four days past has been the most disastrous over experienced in the North-west. There was a greater fall of snow during the terrible times of 1881, but the storm in its disastrous effects was not near so serious as the present.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 5.--The apprehensions which were entertained here owing to the phenominal rise in the Allegheny River have been allayed, as the water had been stationary for several hours up to 2 o'olock this afternoon.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 30.--A blue pennant with a white centre waved from the masthead of all the signal poles in Bermuda at sunrise yesterday morning. This signified, according to the code, that a screw sloop-of-war was in sight.

PARIS, Feb. 5.--The Examining Magistrate, Benoit, to-day made an order sending Prince Jerome Napoleon before the court for an indictment for an attempt to overthrow the existing regime. CLEVELAND, Feb. 6.--The work of clearing up in Cuyahoga Valley goes rapidly forward, and many places are already cleared and ready for business. Items of individual damage in round figures are now obtainable.

The Chairman was instructed to prepare a report in favor of the bill, to be submitted to the committee at their meeting on Thursday.

WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 6.--James Livingston, of Berlin, killed his wife with a hatchet last night, and then notified the neighbors. He said both had been drinking, and the killing was the result of a quarrel over something which happened several weeks ago. Jealousy is said to be the cause of the trouble. Livingston, who is under arrest, is 60 years old, and his wife was 45.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 6.--The Mardi Gras was celebrated to-day with the usual festivities and grand street spectacles. There was an immense crowd in the streets, among the spectators being about 25,000 visitors from all parts of the Union. During the afternoon the King of the Carnival appeared with a grand pageant of 20 cars, followed by the Phunny Phorty Phellows with 14 cars, and the Independent Order of the Moon with 16 cars.
ALBANY, Feb. 6.--Senator Boyd took the initiatory steps toward a genuine reform measure to-day, but the prospect of its being enacted into a law by this Legislature is small enough.

BUFFALO, Feb. 6.--New proceedings were begun in the Surrogate's Court in this city to-day asking that the decree admitting to probate the will of Mrs. Millard Fillmore be set aside. Mrs. Fillmore, who was the widow of President Millard Fillmore, died Aug. 11, 1881.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6.--The peaceable resumption of the tariff debates in both housesto-day, after the warm engagement of yesterday in the House, affords an opportunity for a review of the condition of the proposed tariff legislation, and an examination of the feelings...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6.--The marriage of Miss Alice Stanwood Blaine and Col. John J. Coppinger, of the Army, took place at the residence of ex-Secretary James G. Blaine at noon to-day in the presence of a large company of friends. The new residence of Mr. Blaine is the most complete and handsome mansion in the north-western part of the city.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6.--In the Senate to-day Mr. MORRILL moved to proceed to the consideration of the Tariff bill.

The citizens of Santa Fe, New-Mexico, are preparing to celebrate in July what they call their "tertio-millennial," or, in other words, the three hundred and thirty-third anniversary of the settlement of the town. Ex-Chief-Justice L. Bradford Prince, of that Territory, who is in this City, was seen by a TIMES reporter yesterday.

Mr. S.B. Mills proposes to give a pianoforte recital at Steinway Hall on the 24th inst. He will be assisted by Mr. Bergner and Mr. Remmertz, and will himself play 14 times.

Coroner Hyler concluded the inquest yesterday afternoon in Port Chester touching the manner in which Sife Marks, the murdered peddler, came to his death on the highway, near that village, on Thursday of last week.

A meeting of the Military Order Loyal Legion will take place at Delmonico's to-night. Daniel Manning will sail to-day for a six weeks' stay in Cuba. The trip is rendered necessary by impaired health ceased by overwork.

The Chinese New Year began at midnight last night, and the festivities of this season will be continued among the Chinese residents of this City until Saturday night. The New Year is the great festival in China, where the celebration is often continued by the wealthy mandarins and upper classes of society for a full month, but in this country four days are considered long enough to waste on the inauguration of a new year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6.--The leading produce markets were more active to-day and much stronger. They started up early and fell back under free local selling, then became very strong about 11 o'olock on the receipt of large buying orders from the sea-board, chiefly for May wheat and corn.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6.--Late this afternoon a caucus of Republican Senators was held for the purpose of consulting as to the course to be pursued by the Republicans relative to the pending tariff bill.

The New-York Horticultural Society held their first meeting in their new hall, at No. 26 West Twenty-eighth-street, yesterday afternoon, in connection with the usual monthly exhibition of flowers and plants, and the affair was highly successful in every respect.

Miss Kate Conover Upshur, the eldest daughter of Commodore John H. Upshur, commandant of the Brooklyn Navy-yard, was married yesterday afternoon to Mr. Frank T. Moorhead, in Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn. The bride is a sister of Mrs. W.H. Hunt, Jr., who was married a few months ago to a son of ex-Secretary of the Navy Hunt.

Prof. C.A. Young, of Princeton College, delivered the last of his course of astronomical lectures in the Church of the Strangers last evening, his subject being "Fixed Stars and Nebulae." In opening he said that the first impression of a person in looking at the stars was that they are countless.

It is gratifying to learn that two new Professors have recently been appointed to fill vacant chairs in Liberia College. There now remains but one more vacancy, and it is to be hoped that this will be filled in a short time, so that the Faculty of the college will be complete.

ALBANY, Feb. 6.--Farmer Brooks attempted to-day to check the tide of extravagance which is so rapidly sweeping his Democratic associates into notoriety and bringing them into disrepute with the tax-payers.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 7.--This afternoon the ice moved at Pittston, but it is still stationary here. It is feared that the ice will flow over the Kingston Flats, leaving the gorge unbroken. The water is rising rapidly this evening.

A most daring robbery was committed in the Brooklyn Post Office, in Washington-street, about noon yesterday. At the hour named Assistant Postmaster Charles B. Morton went into his office, which is on the second floor on the Washingtonstreet side of the building, to make up his cash account, preparatory to depositing the money received during the day in bank.

William Bass, an Englishman, employed by Mr. William E. Scoville, of No. 225 Sixth-avenue, Brooklyn, as coachman, rapped at the bedroom door of his employer about 6 o'clock yesterday morning and said the house had been robbed.

LONG BEACH, N.J., Feb. 7.--The ship Parkfield, which came ashore opposite Little Egg Harbor on Sunday night, will probably prove a total loss. She is badly strained, and her seams are opened. The wreckers hope that by patching her they will be able to drag the ship off the shoals and by means of steam pumps keep her afloat.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7.--The stock of the Ransom Stove-works, of this city, practically a branch of the Ransom Stove-works, of Albany, recently suppended, has been attached by the Pennsylvania Coal Company for $2,800.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7.--First Lieut. Ernest A. Garlington, Seventh Cavalry, having volunteered for the service, will be relieved from duty in the Department of Dakota and will roport to the Chief Signal Officer in this City for duty in connection with the proposed relief expedition to Lady Franklin Bay Grinnel-land.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7.--Thomas Goodwin, a deaf-mute, was put on trial in Judge Biddle's court, of the Quarter Sessions, yesterday, on the charge of having stolen two shirts from a laundry on North Second-street, kept by Joseph Thompson.

At the meeting of the Board of Education yesterday communications from a number of special teachers and colored teachers asking for a reconsideration of the action taken by the board last week were read.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7.--Mr. ROBESON, of New-Jersey, from the Committee on Rules, reported a resolution that during the remainder of the session the House shall at 5:30 P.M. each day take a recess until 7:30 P.M. Adopted.

A meeting of the Nineteenth Century Club was held last evening at the residence of its President, Mr. Cortlandt Palmer, No. 117 East Twentyfirst-street, to listen to an address by Henry George on "Ireland and the Land Question."

NEW-HAVEN, Feb. 7.--The contracts for part or the whole of the work of building the two additional tracks between New-York and Stamford will probably be awarded at the Directors' meeting on Saturday, Feb. 10.
BOSTON, Feb. 7.--Albert Ball and Elmer Anderson, each aged 12 years, were arrested at Three Rivers, Mass., last night for robbing the mail.

The regular meeting of the Park Commissioners yesterday morning was very harmonious, and in pleasing contrast to the former sessions of the board. Commissioner Wales, Olliffe, Viele, and Trimmins were all present, and Commissioner Viele presided.

Sawyer Co., being sued for $15,000 damages.

Robert E. O'Brien, appointed in the capacity of civil engineer to inspect the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railway, has made a report to the syndicate which provided the means to complete and equip the road. East of Syracuse, it is said, the road is practically constructed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7.--The compendium of the "Tenth Census," a volume of 1,769 pages, will very soon be published by general distribution, and a few copies in paper covers have already been issued from the Government Printing-office.
The steam-ship Arizona, from Liverpool, landed 167 immigrants at Castle Garden yesterday, and the Erin, from the same port, 117.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 7.--The Monongahela River is taking its turn to day. The copious rain last night, which began early and continued into the dawn, was extended through the country drained by the Monongabela.

A box-maker named Thomas Cusick, residing at No. 141 Madison-street, was tried before Judge Gildersleeve, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, on an indictment charging him with assault in the first degree. An ex-policeman named Washington H. Taylor, who keeps a restaurant at No. 110 Chatham-street, was the complainant.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 7.--Hamlin University, situated near the Manitoba Short Line Railroad, about midway between Minneapolis and St. Paul, was destroyed by fire this morning, entailing a loss of about $65,000, on which there was an insurance of about $26,000.

WAVERLY, Feb. 7.--The Scioto River is overflowing the bottom lands and is rising two and a half inches an hour. The town of Jasper, seven miles below here, was flooded to-night by the breaking of the levee.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 7.--An action in trespass has been brought by Henry E. Collins against John W. Chalfant, in which damages in the sum of $500,000 is claimed.

Chicago, Feb. 7.--A Tribune reporter, who has spent four days in Southern Illinois investigating the fruit and wheat prospects of that region, reports that at Centralia, Duquoin, Carbondale and Cobden the fruit trees were heavily coated with ice, just as much as the limbs could bear.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7.--The leading produce markets were decidedly soft to-day, in spite of apparent efforts to sustain prices. The local folk seemed to be loaded up with a good deal of stuff on which they would like to realize, and the milder weather was not favorable to strong prices.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 7.--In the Superior Court of this city to-day Albert Williams was convicted of forgery in passing raised drafts on the Manufacturers and Traders' Bank and the Merchants Bank, of Buffalo.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 8.--A remarkable case of wife desertion and bigamy has just come to light. On Dec. 28 Charles H. Shores, a dashing young clerk in a well-known retail dry goods store in this city, gave his wife $40, told her he was going traveling for another firm and would be absent three weeks, bade her good-bye, and disappeared from his home.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8.--A curious libel suit was instituted in this city today by Herman Marsdorf, against Barclay Co., of No. 21 North Seventh-street. Marsdorf was at one time the manager of a German theatre in New-York, and as early as 1854 conducted a similar place of amusement in Philadelphia.

This (Sunday) morning I paid another visit to the Cimetiere du Chateau, where the remains of the late M. Gambetta were interred yesterday week. Large crowds have visited the tomb daily, and a walk there is, without doubt, one of the most charming and picturesque of any around Nice.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 8.--The flood in the Monongahela River reached its highest point, 28 feet, at 3 o'clock this morning, and soon after began to recede. Owing to the cold weather, which shut off the small streams, the water did not got as high as was anticipated by several feet.

The steamer Westphalia, of the Hamburg Line, that arrived yesterday, brought about 20 of the survivors of the Cimbria. Nearly all of them, in telling their experiences at the time of the disaster, censured the officers of the Sultan for not stopping to save the passengers of the Cimbria.

The Society of the Army of the Potomac will hold its fourteenth annual session in Washington, May 16 and 17. Martin Maginnis, Captain in the First Minnesota, now a Delegate in Congress from Montana, will deliver the oration. This will be the first meeting of the society in Washington.

BEACH HAVEN, N.J., Feb. 8.--The British ship Parkfield, ashore on the Long Beach Shoals, has from 15 to 18 feet of water in her hold, and the Merritt wrecking organization has been compelled to abandon all work of saving her. As she is lying well up on the shoals it is thought that most of her cargo can be saved, although in a badly damaged condition.

The harvesting of ice on the Hudson River, in which nearly 10,000 men have been engaged for the past month, is practically closed. A crop aggregating 2,500,000 tons has been cut, and most of it stored.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 9.--The Dominion Parliament was formally opened at 3 o'clock this afternoon. The Governor-General, in his address from the throne, alluded to the happy auspices under which Parliament assembles and to his recent visit to British Columbia and the resources of that Province.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9.--Another great Indian reservation, marked upon the Land Office map by a green spot, surpassed in size only by the reservations of the Indian Territory, is to be thrown open to settlers. This is the great Sioux Reservation in Southern Dakota.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Feb. 9.--A daring mail robbery occurred at the union railway station in this city at a late hour last night. The eastbound train being late, the mail was carried into the baggage-room, and while there the mail-pouch was ripped open and 140 registered letters were taken from it.

Inspector Esterbrook, of the Bureau of Buildings, made his report for the year 1882 to the Fire Commissioners yesterday. CHICAGO, Feb. 12--The leading produce markets were rather weak to-day, without much activity. Provisions broke off the most heavily, being beared by a leading packer for about all they were worth. Grain cased off in sympathy, being also beared by the expectation of fine weather bringing in larger receipts.

Officers of the Union Pacific and Northern Pacific Railroads have perfected arrangements for an interchange of traffic and the establishment and maintenance of rates whereby unnecessary building of railroads will be avoided, unprofitable competition prevented, and amicable relations between the two systems preserved.

ALBANY, Feb. 16.--The Assembly Committee on Contested Seats presented its report in the case of Mr. Henry L. Sprague to-day, seven of its nine members voting to unseat Mr. Thales S. Bliss, a member of Tammany Hall, and give the contested seat to Mr. Sprague.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 16.--The general situation to-day has not been materially changed, except that to-night the outlook is more cheerful.
The Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs will make a favorable report on the Mexican reciprocity treaty and recommend its ratification.

It appears that the project of a fast line of American steamers to run between Milford Haven and Montauk Point has been abandoned. That this project could not succeed was long ago pointed out by THE TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16.--No man could tell this morning from any indication when the Senate would pass its Tariff bill. Mr. Morrill yesterday gave notice that he would ask the Senate to sit out the bill to-night.

A meeting of merchants doing business in what is known as the dry goods district was held yesterday at 2 P.M., in the office of the Board of Fire Underwriters, for the purpose of hearing the report of the special committee appointed by that board to consider the pecular hazards from fire existing in that district.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16.--In the Senate today the conference report on the Japanese Indem nity bill was adopted, and at 2 P.M. the Tariff bill was taken up.

The overdue steam-ship City of Richmond, of the Inman Line, made her appearance off Sandy Hook early yesterday morning. She crossed the bar in safety, but there was a fog at the time, and although the vessel was in the charge of a pilot she got somewhat out of her course.

President Asten, of the Board of Commissioners, said that he had no knowledge whatever of any improper conduct on the part of any officer or employe of the department.

Horsemen and gamblers in this City discuss in subdued tones the bills in their interests now before the Senate and Assembly. For six years they have been made miserable by a law entitled " An act in relation to bets, wagers, and pools."

Helen E. Havemeyer, who alleges that she was married to Thomas J. Havemeyer on or about Sept. 26, 1875, and that she lived with him until Oct. 13, 1882, is suing in the Superior Court for a legal separation from him and to compel him to provide for her maintenance.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16.--Rerdell continued his story upon the witness stand to-day and did not reach the end of it. His appearance thus far has been very good.

ALBANY, Feb. 16.--The question of prohibition came up incidentally in the Senate this morning on a favorable report by the Judiciary Committee of Mr. Thomas's resolution amending the Constitution so as to prohibit the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquors in this State.

Vaile, the wife of the defendant in the star route trial, and living at Independence, Mo., died under circumstances that, while they were suppressed and kept from publicity as long as possible by the relatives of the deceased, now clearly indicate that she committed suicide.

VILLACK, Austria, Feb. 16.--Two gypsies fought a duel in the open market-place here. One of them was killed.

The first dense fog of the season made its appearance yesterday, and at a late hour last night it showed no signs of lifting. Early in the morning it was quite thick on the Bay and rivers, and as the day advanced the mist grew denser.

CAIRO, Ill., Feb. 16.--The river measures 45 feet 6 inches, and is rising rapidly, only lacking 6 feet 5 inches of being as high as last year. No serious damage is apprehended from the overflow, unless a heavy rise comes from the Mississippi.

Sickles and Gen. Martin T. MacMahon as probably responsible for these, to us offensive, appointments.

McCaull from producing at the Bijou Opera-house the opera "Heart and Hand," originally commenced in the Court of Common Pleas and removed to the United States Circuit Court by the defendant, came on before Judge Brown, of the United States District Court, yesterday.
The funeral services over the remains of the late ex Gov. Edwin D. Morgan were solemnized in the Brick Presbyterian Church yesterday afternoon and were of the most impressive character.

Mr. Sidney Woollett will give a recital of Guinevere this morning at the Turf Club Theatre. Mr. Tearle was obliged by illness recently to relinquish his part in "The Silver King" to Mr. Herbert. The play is still very popular at Wallack's Theatre.
Surrogate to E.H. Peters entered a decree yesterday evening in the long pending case of the accounting of ex-Judge J.C. Hulbert as guardian of the Walbridge minor children.
CHICAGO Feb. 16.--The leading produce markets were active and excited yesterday, with a great deal more strength in provisions and top prices for grain.

Miss Henrietta Manurer, who made a very successful appearance as a pianiste in this City some years ago, has been playing in Boston of late, and will probably be heard in New-York in the Spring season.

It is quite within the memory of the present generation when New-York was one of the great ship-building ports of the world. Thirty years ago huge shipyards constituted a striking feature of its fine harber.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18.--The condition of affairs at the Braidwood Mine differs in no respect from that recorded in the tolegram sent on Friday night. All Friday night the men worked around the main shaft preparing the buckets to be used in pumping out, rigging the donkey engines, and generally getting things in shape for the work of recovering the bodies of the dead.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18.--The programme of the dominant party in the Senate for the coming legislative week is substantially identical with the unfulfilled programme, outlined last Sunday, for the week which ended yesterday.
DUBLIN, Feb. 18.--The individual alluded to in Carey's testimony as "Number One" is an Irish-American, but resided for some time in France and Germany.

The body of Claus Steffen, of Whitestone, who has been missing since the night of Feb. 10, was found floating, face down, in Flushing Bay early yesterday afternoon, at the College Point steam-ship dock, by James Duke.

There is dissatisfaction in the ranks of the base-ball players. The conference committee, which held a meeting in this City on Saturday last, adopted a resolution whereby no player can command a salary of more than $1,000 a season, unless it is the option of the manager of the club by which he is engaged to increase that figure.

English literature, so rich in examples of the epistolary art that nowadays is fast going but of fashion, receives in these Emerson and Carlyle volumes a rare and long-to-be-historical contribution to its storehouses.
A lady, Miss S.C. Clark, has been appointed Treasurer of a savings bank in Exeter, N.H.

On Saturday the Prince of Wales unveiled, upon Woolwich Common, the United Services' Memorial to the late Prince Louis Napoleon. The monument was raised by the subsoriptions of more than 25,000 men of all ranks in the Army and Navy, and although no single contribution was allowed to exceed l, the committee are able to report that they received 4,310.
A correspondent in Iowa, in a letter printed in another column, gives some account of the change going on in the sentiment of the West on the subject of free trade and protection.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18.--A land grant of 14,000,000 acres, valued at $25,000,000, is worth fighting for, if there be a chance to win it.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 18.--The river is receding slowly to-day, but much less rapidly than yesterday. Second-street is now out of water, and parts of Front-street can be seen.

The Pig's Head Club, an institution whose membership comprises the literary and political talent (limited) of the Thirteenth Ward, ate an anniversary banquet recently at Sullivan's Hotel, on the right angle of Grand and Clinton streets, at which the leading attraction on the elaborate menu was that succulent edible which forms the title of the organization.

BAYREUTH, Feb, 18--Waguer's widow was so overcome on the arrival of the funeral train here that she was obliged to be lifted from the car. A guard of 27 citizens watched by Wagner's bier throughout the night.

In a dingy room, odorous with the fumes of vile tobacco and Brooklyn whisky, the Irish societies of Kings County met yesterday afternoon at Hibernia Hall, in Gold-street, and discussed the problem to parade or not to parade on St. Patrick's Day in the morning.

The seventh of the series of popular Sunday night concerts was given last evening to a very large audience. The orchestra played with spirit and intelligence in the several overtures, marches, waltzes, as well as in the accompaniments of the soloists, and was well conducted by Mr. Max Maretzek and Mr. Aronson.
A most remarkable incident occurred the other day on the Banks of Newfoundland. A codfish was captured in the stomach of which were found five cards--four diamonds and a spade.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 19.--It was rumored about this city to-day, and published in the evening papers, that Herbert C, Ayer had arrived in town and was quartered in the house of a friend, but there is no truth in the statement.

By consent of the parties to it a suit, in which the New-York Elevated Railroad Company was plaintiff and the Manhattan Railway and the Metropolitan Elevated Railroad Companies were defendants, was settled, and a judgment in favor of the defendants was entered in the Superior Court, Special Term, on Dec. 9, 1881.

The General Passenger Agents of the trunk lines held a meeting yesterday afternoon at Commissioner Fink's office, but transacted no business of public importance, devoting their time to the arrangement of details for the meeting, beginning to-day, of the representatives of all the roads interested in the pooling arrangement between Chicago, St. Louis, and Eastern cities.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19.--The lending produce markets were very unsettled and nervous to-day, with violent fluctuations in tone and wider variations than usual in prices.

For the third time during the present season the New-York farmers dined together last evening at Delmonico's. Mr. James A. Burden presided, and the guests of the evening were the Hon. George B. Caldwell, Commissioner of Agriculture; Prof. G. C. Caldwell, of Cornell University, and Mr. Edward Burnett, of Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--At the close of the morning hour in the Senate Mr. INGALLS called up his resolution to fix the daily hour of meeting from now until the end of the session at 10 A.M., which was agreed to. After a brief executive session the Tariff bill was taken up.
The second part of what appears to be the programme of the high protectionists was entered upon in the House yesterday, while a co-operating movement was made in the Senate.
SING SING, Feb. 19.--The men employed in the laundry at the State Prison, numbering about 120, went to work as usual this morning.

CAIRO, Ill., Feb. 19.--At 6 o'clock this evening the river marked 51 feet and was rising at the rate of half an inch an hour. The lowlands below here are inundated, and the loss of stock, grain, , is great.

The first meeting of the Memorial Committee of the Grand Army of the Republic of this City for 1883 was held last evening in the United States Pension Office, in Canal-street, Gen. Henry A. Barnum presiding.

A TIMES reporter called last evening upon Dr. William B. Wallace, the President of the Land League in this City, and asked his views as to Town Councilor Carey's connection with the Phoenix Park tragedy.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--The season of Italian opera to be given by Col. Mapleson at the National Theatre began most auspiciously to-night.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 19.--The St. Louis Freight Bureau has succeeded, after no little trouble, in so arranging matters that a regular line of steamships between New-Orleans and Liverpool will soon be established. Manager Fink, of the bureau, has been in communication with Messrs. Cunningham, Shaw Co., of Liverpool.
ALBANY, Feb. 19.--Following are the official reports of the trust, loan, and mortgage companies of New-York and Kings Counties, as made to the Bank Superintendent, showing their condition on Jan. 1.

The Boston Ideal Opera Company gave a first performance last night, the opera being "Fatinitza."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--A very significant memorandum about the disposal of part of the money received from the Dorsey star routes was the subject of Rerdell's testimony this morning when the star route trial was resumed.

Steps were taken in the various Exchanges yesterday toward raising money for the relief of the sufferers by the floods in the West. Subscription lists were placed in each Exchange, and a considerable sum was subscribed before the close of the day.

The new arrangements by which emigrant tickets are sold over the trunk routes to the West have created much dissatisfaction among people who are willing to travel West and take up with such accommodations as they can have on an emigrant train.

LONG BEACH, N.J., Feb. 19.--The ship Parkfield, which was wrecked opposite Little Egg Harbor, near Beach Haven, on Feb. 4, is being stripped of masts, sails, , and will be sold to-morrow as she lies on the beach.
