CINCINNATI, Feb. 19.--The river continues to fall slowly. In 80 hours it has fallen 88 inches. There was some prospect that gas could be furnished to the business part of the city not in the inundated district to-night, but it was found that the mains are still so full of water that it will be impossible to furnish gas to any part of the city before to-morrow night.

HAVANA, Feb. 19.--General indignation is manifested and considerable excitement prevails here on account of the Director General of the Cuban Treasury endeavoring, upon his own responsibility, to collect the taxes now due for the third three-monthly term of the fiscal year, with an enormous increase upon the lawful rates.

The Hudson County Court of Special Sessions, in Jersey City, was crowded yesterday by an excited and eager throng who had gathered to witness the trial of the City Bank wreckers--Garret S. Beice, its President; Edward N. Shaw, its Cashier, and John A. Beach, its book-keeper.
DUBLIN, Feb. 19.--The hearing of the prisoners charged with conspiring to murder Government officials was resumed to-day. All the prisoners except Patrick Whelan were again placed in the dock.

Three very severe sentences were imposed by Judge Cowing in the Court of General Sessions yesterday. The first case called was that of James Poole, a young ruffian, who was convicted last week of shooting at Patrick McGowan, a saloonkeeper at No. 192 Canal-street.

The application of Salmi Morse for a mandamus to compel the Mayor to grant him a license for the production of theatrical novelties at Morse Hall, in West Twenty-third-street, was denied by Judge Ingraham, in the Superior Court, Chambers, yesterday.

At the weekly conference of the Baptist clergymen yesterday, the Rev. Mr. Marsh, of NewBranswick, N.J., gave his views of the Salvation Army, and the work which is being done by that peculiar evangelical brotherhood and sisterhood in New-Brunswick.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 19.--For the second time within a week the Court of Common Pleas of this county this afternoon administered a black eye to the East End Railroad Company, whose bonds are secured by Vanderbilt, and whose road, when constructed, is intended to be used by that gentlemen to enable him to get into this city.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Feb. 19.--The water reached its highest point, which was six inches higher than the flood of 1875, to-day. The bottoms across the river are entirely overflowed. The water is now falling rapidly and all danger is over.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20.--Col. George Thom, Corps of Engineers, was to-day placed upon the retired list of the Army. This retirement will cause the promotion of Lieut.-Col. Q.A. Gillmore to be Colonel, Major William E. Merrill Lieutenant-Colonel, Capt. Charles W. Raymond Major, and First Lieut. Francis V. Greene Captain.

ALBANY, Feb. 20.--The Senate occupied most of the session to-day in the third reading of bills, the larger part of which were only of local interest. Among the most important that came up for final passage was Mr. Thomas's bill "to tegulate the issue of stock by corporations and joint stock associations."

The House having formally given up all hope or intention of passing a tariff bill, and the Ways and Means Committee having failed to get a two-thirds vote to pass a reduction of the internal revenue, all eyes have been turned upon the Senate.

A colored woman named Charlotte Polo was plaintiff in a suit tried before Judge McAdam and a jury, in the Marine Court, yesterday. Accom panying her was a blue-eyed, flaxen-haired boy of 9 years, who watched her earnestly with an expression of complete confidence in her constantly on his face.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20.--The leading produce markets were active and stronger to-day. They were tame and tended downward early in the day, with milder weather and larger receipts of grain, while the intimation that "there is a pause" in British circles, caused the sending of a good many selling orders here by sea-board speculation.

Additional subscriptions for the relief of the sufferers by the floods in the West were received at the various Exchanges yesterday. The General Relief Committee, consisting of the Chairmen of the Relief Committees of the various Exchanges, met in the afternoon at the office of Theodore I.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20.--The report was circulated among Senators at the Capitol at noon that the Cabinet had been considering the names selected by the President for the Civil Service Commission, and yet it was said by some one who had come directly from the White House that the names were to be sent in to-day.

The annual meeting of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Westarn Railroad took place yesterday. The report for the year ending Dec. 31, 1882, showed the gross earnings from all sources to have been $27,000,267.15; expenses, operating railroad and mines, c., $19,231,377.82; net earnings, $7,774,889.83.

The Aldermen several weeks ago adopted a resolution asking Public Works Commissioner Thompson for a detailed report on the condition of the City's water supply. The Commissioner answered the request yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 20.--The flood has now receded to such an extant that a majority of the buildings which were inundated are now once more surrounded by dry land. The cellars continue full of water, which causes the buildings to remain damp and the injury to goods to some extent still continues.

SING SING, N.Y., Feb. 20.--The number of convicts at the State prison here who have refused to work was increased from 42 to 122 this morning by the strike of 80 men in the shoe shop. Head Keeper Nixon had a conference early in the day with one of the teams of men in regard to their work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20, 1883. Secretary Folger is still quite weak, and is unable to sit up. Although the chills and fever continue his condition is improving. He will not be able to resume his duties this week.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 20.--The funeral services in honor of the late Lyman H. Atwater were held in the First Presbyterian Church this afternoon. HARRISBURG, Feb. 26.--The Jackson Coal Company was chartered this afternoon with a capital of $100,000. It is to run from Lake Township to Pine Township, Mercer County, a distance of 10 miles.

A bill has been introduced in the State Senate which has produced great consternation among theatrical managers. One of them, in conversation with a TIMES reporter a day or two ago, said that if the bill were passed every theatre in New-York would have to be closed and torn down.

A complaint in equity was filed in the United States Circuit Court yesterday by Robert P. Hamilton, of Principulca Bar, Mosquito Reservation, Nicaraugua, Central America, against William G. Hamilton and others, the Trustees of the estate of Alexander Hamilton, to set aside the will of the late Mrs. Maria E. Hamilton.
PANAMA, Feb. 17.--Advices from the south say peace prospects appear brighter. A representative of Chili is treating in Valparaiso with the imprisoned Peruvian Provisional President.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Feb. 26.--Surprises from Wyoming Territory are not at an end. Not only is the country prolific in mineral wealth, but fossil remains are being discovered in abundance. A mining expert, who has been in the Sweetwater Country for three years, has just arrived in this city, bringing with him portions of the skeleton of a megatherium found in a sand-bed in the valley of that river.

The managers of the Republican majority in the House of Representatives--it would be gross flattery to call them leaders--have concluded to carry into the treatment of the tariff the tactics of the political convention and the caucus in their worst and most offensive form.

Senator VAN WYCK's position in respect to European interference in the relations of Chili and Peru is a very easy one to take on the ready promptings of sentiment, but less easy to defend by the cool deductions of reason.

At the regular Monday meeting of the Baptist Pastors yesterday the Rev. Harvey Wood, of England, who has just returned from Leadville, where he recently resigned the pastorate of the local Baptist church, was called upon for some of his experiences. "When I was invited to accept the pastorate of the Leadville Baptist Church," said Mr. Wood, "I was informed by letter that ...

Unexpected opposition was developed last evening in the Assembly to the joint resolution proposing an amendment of the State Constitution which should provide for biennial sessions of the Legislature, and after a somewhat acrimonious political debate the motion for a third reading was defeated by a single vote.

Jay Gould, Russell Sage, Cyrus W. Field, Joseph H. Burnham, and Jacob Berry, and many other Wall-street men were in the Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday morning, when Judge Van Vorst took his seat upon the bench.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26.--In the star route trial this morning, after allowing Rerdell as opportunity to make some corrections in the testimony given on Friday, his cross-examination was resumed.
CANNES, Feb. 26.--Mr. Gladstone started for London to-day.
At the meeting of the County Medical Society last night Dr. Charles Heitzman read a paper on "The Nature of Tuberculosis; Its Transmissibility and its Parasitic Origin."

John P. O'Neill, Receiver of the Continental Life Insurance Company, was interred in Calvary Cemetery yesterday, after a solemn requiem mass had been sung over his remains in St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church.
The Treasurer of the Board of Underwriters issued yesterday a repert setting forth the premiums received on City business by each fire insurance company during the six months ending Dec. 31, 1882.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 26.--The latest news from the levees between this city and Greenville, Miss., is that the Government, State, and parochial officers, aided by tha planters along the river, are making strenuous efforts to complete repairs and hold all the levees now intact, with good prospect of success, as the river is rising slowly at Greenville and points below.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26.--The contest upon the proposed new rule has been begun in the House, but at the time of adjournment tonight the rule had not bean adopted for lack of a quorum of Republicans.

England has formally asked us to return to her jurisdiction one P.J. SHERIDAN. A warrant has issued for his arrest, and he "gladly" awaits its execution. This is but the opening of a matter which would be of slight consequence were only SHERIDAN involved.

An official inquiry into the cause of the deaths of Minnie Uster and the 15 other victims of the panic in the parochial school in East Fourthstreet last week Tuesday was begun by Coroner Levy yesterday afternoon.

ROCHESTER, Feb. 26.--A large mass-meeting was held in the City Hall to-night by manufacturers and their employes, who have joined together in opposition to prison contract labor. The various trade assemblies met early in the evening and paraded the streets with music and transparencies.

COLUMBUS, Feb. 26.--The publication of a dispatch to the effect that the Hon. The best methods of improving and enforcing the Excise law in this City were discussed by several prominent citizens in the presence of a large audience in Steinway Hall last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--A statue of Robert Fulton was placed in the old Hall of Repre sentatives to-day as one of two statues to be contributed by Pennsylvania. It is in strong contrast with the other statues in the hall, owing to the manner in which the subject is treated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26.--On motion of Mr. BAYARD a resolution was adopted by the Senate to-day requesting the House of Representatives to return the Tariff bill in order that certain clerical errors in it might be corrected.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26.--In the United States District Court, before Judge Butler, this morning, Alfred Jerkins, a letter-carrier, was placed on trial charged with having embezzled a number of letters which should have passed through his hands.

A version of Lecocq's opera, "Le Coeur et le Main," under the title of "Micaela," was produced at the Standard Theatre last evening before a very large and appreciative audience. The story of the opera has been made familiar to the public by a previous presentation at the Bijou Opera-house.

ALBANY, Feb. 26.--The proposition to submit to the people of the State whether or not sessions of the Legislature shall be held once in two years instead of annually, as at present, provoked considerable discussion in the Assembly this evening.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 26.--Rumors which had affected the financial standing of Charles H. Brainerd, President of the State Bank, of this city, resulted in a short explanatory statement in the evening papers of Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26.--As a result of the investigation begun by the Citizens' Committee into the operation of the Detective Corps of this city, the Grand Jury to-day returned indictments against John C. The imports of specie at this port last week were $276,550, and the exports $411,638.

Col. Lucius M. Lamar, of Hawkinsville, present State Senator from the Fourteenth District composed of the counties of Dooly, Wilcox, Pulaski, and Dodge, has been in Atlanta this week. Col. Lamar is one of the marked men of the Georgia Senate. He is strikingly handsome, of fine portly figure, and has a most attractive and perennial sweetness of manner.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26.--The Secretary of State has, upon the application of the British Government, issued a warrant for the arrest of P.J. Sheridan, suspected of complicity in the Phoenix Park murders, and it has been placed in the hands of Mr. West, the British Minister. Mr. Sheridan is in New-York.

Gilbert L. Crowell, President of the Empire mine, which is situated at Park City, Utah, is a defaulter to the extent of about $500,000, money which he has deliberately stolen from his clients, and in addition to this he has involved his friends who have indorsed his notes to the extent of $42,800.

Mr. Bartley Campbell is the author of several crude and unsatisfactory plays which show rather ingenuously his possession of the theatrical sense and his lack of true, coherent, reasonable dramatic feeling. All his plays start with impossibilities and end in plain absurdities.

At a meeting of the Young Men's Democratic Club last evening, Mr. Edward L. Parris in the chair, a report from the Executive Committee was received in regard to the new charter for the City proposed by Mayor Edson.

Judge Barrett decided, yesterday, in Supreme Court, Chambers, that the Attorney-General should bring a suit to annul the charter of the Mutual Union Telegraph Company. CHICAGO, Feb. 26.--The leading produce markets were rather quiet to-day, and averaged easier, with little business on outside account. Large receipts in grain, with moderate weather, were reasons for weakness, especially as the British markets were tending lower on breadstuffs.

OIL CITY, Penn., Feb. 26.--When Mr. H. M. Flagler, Secretary of the Standard Oil Company, was testifying before a New-York committee a few weeks ago he was very careful not to go into details as to the workings of his company, nor could such information be ob tained by any official scrutiny.
A party of about 100 ladies and gentlemen was made up in Bangor, Me., to attend the Mapleson opera season in Boston this week.

The first exhibition drill of the Life-saving Fire Corps which Christoph Hoell, of the St. Louis Fire Department, is training in this City was given yesterday afternoon at Engine-house No. 47, on Tenth-avenue. "Old Shipmates," Mr. Robert G. Morris's breezy and interesting drama, was brought forward at the Cosmopolitan Theatre on Monday night. Mr. Frank Mordhunt's vigorous and taking impersonation of Captain Marline Weathergage still forms the chief attraction of this play. The revival has received considerabte public favor. A matinee of "Old Shipmates" will be given to-day.

Mrs. Langtry arrived in this City Monday night from Indianapolis, and went at once to the Albemarle Hotel. She has no engagements to play anywhere this week until Saturday night, when she will perform in Davenport, Iowa. Her last performance was given in Indianapolis Saturday night. Though another step was taken yesterday in the proceedings connected with the tariff, it is still impossible to say what will be the ultimate result. A quorum was obtained at an early hour in the House, and the committee's rule permitting the Senate bill to be taken up for the purpose of non-concurrence only was adopted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27.--The President sent to Congress a few weeks ago several letters and contracts in response to the resolution adopted last July, calling for information concerning any modification of the stipulations which the French Cable Company made with our Government on Feb. 9, 1880, when that company was permitted to land its cable upon our shores.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27.--Capt. George M. Randall, Twenty-third Infantry, and Capt. Marcus E. Taylor, Assistant Surgeon, have been detailed as members of the general court-martial appointed to meet at David's Island, New-York Harbor, by special orders of Jan. 27, 1883.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27.--Secretary Foster, of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company, is authority for the statement that the Recrivers will formally hand over all the property and affairs of the company to the President and Board of Managers to-morrow. The Receivers' certificates have been paid off as fast as presented, and the company is ready to redeem them all.

It was reported yesterday in well-informed insurance circles that the Manhattan Fire Insurance Company has been undergoing an investigation by a committee of Directors and stockholders. During the closing days of last year all the outstanding risks of this company were reinsured by the Phenix Fire Insurance Company, of Brooklyn.

HARTFORD, Feb. 27.--Walter Dart, a church member and Sunday-school teacher of this town, was indicted by the United States Grand Jury today on a charge of stealing letters from the Hartford Post Office, where he was employed. He was afterward arraigned before Judge Shipman, in the United States Circuit Court, pleaded guilty, and was at once sentenced to two years' imprisonment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27, 1883. The acting Secretary of the Treasury has appointed Messrs. William Laimbeer, Jackson S. Schultz, and George H. Andrews a Commission to examine the various pieces of ground offered as a site for the Brooklyn Post Office, and report their views as to which is the most desirable for the purpose.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27.--The leading produce markets were somewhat more active to-day and stronger after a little weakening in the first half of the session. Lighter receipts than had been expected, both in hogs and grain, seemed to be the principal cause in the change in tone. There was not much doing on outside account. MADRID, Feb. 27.--The magistrates who are conducting the inquiry in regard to the Socialistic societies in Andalusia have received letters threatening them with death.
DUBLIN, Feb. 27.--Another of Lord Ardilaun's bailiffs, named Flynn, has been attacked brutally and left for dead near Clonbur, County Mayo.

Speaker CHAPIN, on the day that he assumed the chair in the Assembly, appointed a Committee on Contested Seats which was at once recognized as one of exceptional ability and fairness. There were five cases to be considered by the committee, two of which have excited considerable interest in their several localities.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27.--A remarkable story of financial mismanagement and municipal insolvency is told in a special dispatch to the Times from Altoona, Penn. It is almost impossible to get an Altoona city order cashed, and there is a strong belief among prominent business men that over $100,000 of the city improvement loan has been improperly and illegally issued.

DURBAN, Feb. 27.--It is reported that the Boers have defeated Chief Mapoch and captured Chief Mampoer.

Special Agent Charles N. Brackett, of the Treasury Department, recently received information from the department in Washington that an attempt was to be made to smuggle a lot of merchandise through the Custom-house which was to come from England on the Alaska, which arrived in port on Monday. WASHINGTON, Feb. 27.--The Senate Tariff bill is now in the hands of a conference committee of 10 men, and these men are Senators Morrill, Sherman, Aldrich, Bayard, and Beck, and Representatives Kelley, McKinley, Haskell, Randall, and Carlisle. Seven of these ten men are high protectionists, and they will control each branch of the conference committee.

STAUNTON, Va., Feb. 27.--Another victim of the Western Lunatic Asylum poisoning died today, making the sixth person who has died. The other two inmates who were poisoned have recovered. Pending an analysis of the contents of the stomachs of the deceased by Prof. Mullet, of the University of Virginia, the Coronor's jury is prosecuting its inquiries.

Gilbert L. Crowell, President of the Empire mine, of Parley's Park, Summit County, Utah, who has confessed to having appropriated to his own use about $500,000 belonging to Mrs. Cordelia A. Atwell and the Misses Catberine and Caroline Tallman, still lies sick at his residence at Arlington, N. J., and his physicians express grave doubts as to his recovery.

ALBANY, Feb. 27.--The Anti-Monopoly League has sent up four bills, which will be introduced to-morrow. One forbids any railroad in the State to give free passes to anybody except employes of the road or to sell passes below the regular price. Simpson, Crawford Simpson, No. 311 Sixth-avenue-- were arraigned before Justice Patterson, in the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, charged with robbing their employers.

Henry Carey Baird addressed the Brooklyn Revenue Reform Club last evening in the Brooklyn Art Association Hall, on "The Necessary Foundations of Individual and National Wellbeing and of Civilization." He appeared as an advocate of protection, and was listened to by a large audience, all but a few of the hearers being pronounced free traders.

Moriarity, and ex-Judge Quinn. Mr. Kelly lectures in the old Capitol building tomorrow night upon "The History of the Early Irish Settlers in America.

ALBANY, Feb. 28.--The dull routine of work in the Assembly to-day was interrupted for a few moments by a political debate over amendments to the charter of the city of Buffalo. Mr. Cornelius Donohue had the amendments in charge, and when Mr. Ernst, his Republican colleague, attempted to modify them he raised a whoop that alarmed the House and rallied the unterrified to his support.
DUBLIN Feb. 28.--The Freeman's Journal, says it is authorized to state that no warrant has been issued for the arrest of Mr. Brennan.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 28.--It is the opinion of leading Democrats in this end of the State that Judge Hoadley's withdrawal of his name from among the candidates for Governor is a conditional piece of strategy that may be followed by a re-entrance into the arena at a later date.

Miss Julia De Forest Curtiss, daughter of Charles Curtiss, was married last evening to Mr. Jesse S. Nash, at the residence of her father, No. 32 East Sixty-eighth-street, the ceremony being performed by the Rev. Dr. Charles S. Robinson, Pastor of the Memorial Presbyterian Church.
Mr. P.J. Sheridan was not molested yesterday in the proceedings begun by the British Government for his extradition.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28.--In the star route trial this morning Mr. Ingersoll resumed his crossexamination of Rordell. The handwriting of the different papers had been the subject of a long inquiry during the direct examination, and the same ground was again covered in the cross-examination.

Goods that filled six large trunks were piled up in the seizure-room at the Custom-house yesterday. They were a part of the seizure at the pier of the steamship Alaska which was spoken of yesterday. The seizure proves to have been one of the largest made in a long time, and the prominence of the persons engaged in the smuggling makes the case one of unusual importance.

Among the passengers who stood upon the deck of the Gulon steam-ship Wyoming, just before her departure yesterday morning for Liverpool, was a young African Prince. He was very black and appeared to be about 16 years of age. He wore a dark overcoat, the upper button-hole of which bore evidences of having recently been darned by some one who was a novice in that art.

It is stated by a trustworthy authority that there has never been a worse prospect for the wheat crop in these islands at this season of the year than there is at present. The very serious consequences involved in this anticipation can hardly be overestimated.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28.--The leading produce markets were more active to-day and generally stronger, though the prospect of fine weather had led many to look for weakness and sell in anticipation of it. There was a good many buying orders from the sea-board. Toward 1 o'clock there was a general recession in prices, caused, apparently, by rumors of additional failures outside.

Rudolph Aronson, President, and Directors A.C. Downing, G.B. Charlick, Nathaniel Myers, and Albert Aronson, of the New-York Casino Company, which owns the elegant new Casino at Broadway and Thirty-ninth-street, have been summoned to appear before Attorney-General Russell, at Albany, to-morrow, to show causes why they should not be removed and the property be turned over to a Receiver.

Justice "Billy" Watson, of East New-York, who was arrested some time ago on a charge of promoting a prize-fight between a colored man named Pray and a white man named Hardy, pleaded "not guilty" in the Kings County Court of Sessions yesterday.

CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 20.--I met a man the other day called "Soldier Sam," an honest fellow, and one of the true-blue boys of the late war. He had served under Grant, and could tell reminiscences of the great General by the hour. The best of it was that his stories were always authentic.

The Commencement exercises of the American Veterinary College were held in Chickering Hall last evening. The building was crowded before the ceremonies were begun. Mr. Samuel Marsh presided, and there were also on the platform Profs. A. Liautard, William Darling, Robertson, and Coates; Henry Bergh, John T. Howard, W.H. Barbour, Dr. F.D. Welsse, Hamilton Busbey, and Prof. D.O. Doremus.

The first installment of the monkeys of the world which Prof. Henry A. Ward, of Rochester, is to furnish the American Museum of Natural History, arrived in this City last week, and the specimens have been placed in cases in the museum. Prof. Ward expects that it will take him about three years to fill the contract, for which he will receive $9,500.
It is estimated that the decrease of the public debt for the month of February is about $7,500000.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 28.--William, James, and Richard Thompson, brothers, who committed extensive railroad robberies in Dallas, Texas, and who broke jail some days ago, have been recaptured. They confessed their guilt, and promised to name a large number of confederates.

Among the various preparations for the coronation are the following: The Holy Synod, composed of three Metropolitans, two Archbishops and one Chief Priest, will sit at Moscow until the end of June, and in the meantime be represented in St. Petersburg by a delegation only.

MADRID, Feb, 28.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day, Senor Candam submitted an interpellation in regard to the Socialistic troubles in Andalusia. He declared that a society called the "Black Hand," similar to the Internationale, existed.

ALBANY, Feb. 28.--The Senate managed to rouse a little excitement to-day for the first time during the session. The Capitol Commission bill furnished the occasion, but the extraordinary ruling of Lieut.-Gov. Hill was the immediate cause.
ALBANY, Feb. 28.--The Assembly Committee on Trades and Manufactures will report favorably on the bill reducing the price of gas in New York and Brooklyn to $1.50 per 1.000 cubic feet,

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Feb. 28.--The Philadelphia and Reading Railroad and Coal and Iron Companies today passed out of the hands of the Receivers and were restored to the managers representing the stockholders of those corporations. The order for the transfer was made in the Circuit Court of the United States on Feb. 14.

Geiselman was arrested on a warrant sworn out by Ludwig Raschdau, Acting Consul-General of Germany, at this port, and issued by United States Commissioner Deuel.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 1.--Naval Cadets Charles E. Woodruff, of Pennsylvania; Charles J. Gross, of Maryland, and William A. Megrath, of Georgia, who were engaged in the demonstration of the 30th of January last, the only three of this class who failed to express regret for their conduct, have this day been dropped from the rolls of the Naval Academy by the Navy Department.

When Dr. O'Dea yesterday visited Annie Smith, the little girl who was mysteriously injured in the left breast last Tuesday at her father's house, near New-Dorp, Staten Island, he found her much better, and said that unless unfavorable symptons appeared he would consider her out of danger in 48 hours.

All the members of the Cabinet were present at to-day's session excepting Secretary Folger. The question of calling an extra session of Congress was under consideration. The general sentiment was against it.

Bloodgood, stockholders of the New-York Concert Company,(the Casino,) to have the Attorney-General bring an action to oust the present Directors of the company and for the appointment of a Receiver.

The Assembly Committee on Prisons held a session in the Brunswick Hotel last evening to continue the investigation of the charges of cruelty made against the keepers and officers of the prisons of the State, and of the contract labor system. Chairman Keyes presided, and the evening was devoted to hearing testimony offered in defense of the prison authorities.
The conference committee on the Senate Tariff bill having been finally made up in a one-sided fashion, has come to an agreement much more promptly and easily than was anticipated.

Their market value is about $35,000.

ALBANY, March 2.--Two of Pinkerton's detectives have succeeded in unearthing a conspiracy by which baggage on the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad has been systematically stolen for several month. Last evening Henry Effner and John F. Strain, a coppersmith, were arrested here on the charge of conspiracy and grand larceny.

WASHINGTON, March 2.--In the Senate this evening Mr. MORRILL presented and explained the conference report on the internal revenue and tariff bill. He said the internal revenue part of the bill provides for the repeal of the taxes on banks and bankers, whether State or national, except the tax on the circulation at national banks.

WASHINGTON, March 2.--The Tariff bill has engrossed everybody's attention to-day at the Capitol. The Conference Committee resumed its work upon it at 9:30 o'clock this morning, and from that hour until the conferees finished their work, long after noon, it seemed as if everybody in Washington had come up to the Capitol to ask questions about the conferees' work and the changes in the different schedules.
The Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix continued last evening his series of Lenten discourses in Trinity Chapel, by talking about some of the sins of woman which menace our homes.

That most important of all questions to the mind of every self-respecting Irishman--the course which the St. Patrick's Day procession shall take on the merry 17th of the month--was settled at Central Hall yesterday afternoon by the committee appointed for that purpose by the convention of Irish societies.

The District Criminal Court of Samara recently disposed of a case which is of interest, not only as presenting another illustration of the life and morals of the upper ranks of Russian society, but because the accused, Count N.A. Tolstoi, is a brother of the Russisn Minister of the Interior.

ST. LOUIS, March 4.--The performance of the public ceremony uniting Senator Tabor and the belle of Oshkosh has loosened the tongues of a select few who were cognizant of a quiet ceremony performed in St. Louis several months ago.

At the annual meeting of the American College Base-ball Association at Springfield, March 2, the following delegates were present: Messrs. Crocker and Coolidge, of Harvard; Green and Wall, of Brown; Harlan and Wadleigh, of Princeton; Stuart and Wilcox, of Amherst; Yates and Hubbard, of Yale; Maxwell and Douglas, of Dartmouth.
The report of Superintendent COLVIN upon the Adirondack Survey for 1882 is a valuable and timely contribution to the current discussion of the general subject of forest protection.
The annual meeting of the National League Base-ball Association was held at the Victoria Hotel yesterday afternoon, President Mills in the chair.

The health of the German Emperor is reported again to give cause for anxiety at Berlin. He has not been well at all this Winter, and his brother's sudden death gave him a shock from which he does not easily recover.

At the regular monthly meeting of the Board of Trustees of Columbia College yesterday, the report of the committee to which the petition from the Association for the Promotion of Higher Education for Women was referred was made the first order of business.

When Mrs. Elizabeth Heilman, of William's Bridge, entered the corridor of the Court-house at White Plains yesterday morning a number of men stood around the stove. One of them, Charles P. Van Slyok, made it is alleged, an extremely vile remark to Mrs. Heilman as soon as she came within ...

Julius-Marcus, a well-known liquor broker, who had desk room at No. 16 South William-street, and did business for a number of prominent firms in this and neighboring cities, has swindled several liquor-dealers and fled.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5.--There was much excitement in this city late this afternoon over a rumor that there had been a default in the subscription to the Reading Car Trust loan of such magnitude as to make ineffective their effort to call in the Receiver's certificates, and that the effect would be to vitiate the recent reorganization of the road.

M. Maurice Grau arrived in New-York yesterday morning from Havana by the steamer Newport. In reply to a question put by a reporter of THE TIMES M. Grau said: "We have been having a most delightful time for the last few months in Havana and Mexico.

The Post Office at Central Station, West Va., was broken open and robbed on Jan. 19, and as a result three well-known cracksmen of this City have taken up a long residence in the West Virginia Penitentiary, at Moundsville.

The will of the late ex-Gov. Edwin D. Morgan was filed in the Surrogate's office yesterday. An abstract was published in THE TIMES on Feb. 20, in which the bequests to charitable and benevolant institutions were given.
WASHINGTON, March 5.--The representatives of the Greenback-Labor Party in the Forty-seventh Congress have issued an address to the country of which the following are the principal features:
WASHINGTON, March 5.--Following is the list of the nominations sent to the Senate by the President during the session just closed, which were rejected of which were not acted upon:
The members of the Fourth-Avenue Presbyterian Church celebrated, last evening, the twentieth anniversary of the pastorate of the Rev. Dr. Howard Crosby.
It will probably be a long time before the House of Representatives will be provided with a Speaker by contract. The experiment has not been successful in any particular.

A very interesting revival of "The Long Strike" was effected last night at the Windsor Theatre. This capacious house was filled in all its parts, and the audience watched the performance with keen and steady attention.

MOBILE, March 5.--Col. A.L. Rives, General Manager of the Mobile and Ohio Railroad, now in New-York, will consider, and perhaps accept, the offer made him by the Richmond and Danville Railroad to become its General Manager.
The Rev. Dr. John Hall will deliver a lecture this evening at the Lord Public Reading-room and Library, No. 135 Greenwich-street, on "Lessons from Russia."
WASHINGTON, March 5.--A report has reached this city from Trop that Mr. James S. Smart has declined the appointment to be Collector of Internal Revenue in the Fifteenth District.

Joseph, Myers Son, manufacturers of ladies' cloaks and suits, at No. 25 White-street and at Philadelphia, whose failure was announced on Saturday, owe at least $160,000, and some of the creditors think the liabilities will amount to $180,000.
ALGIERS, March 5.--A expedition of great proportion is being organized to crush the rebels in the southern part of Oran.

Gilbert and Sullivan's "Iolanthe" was produced at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre last evening with an entirely different east from that which presented the opera at the Standard, and the applause and encores with which the artists were complimented by a large audience are indications that the new "Iolanthe" is booked for a successful run.

ATLANTA, March 5.--This morning at 8:40 the train on the Central Road bearing the President of the Sonate, Mr. Boynton, and party arrived, and Mr. Boynton was greeted by a large number of men.

The much-talked-of Wagner memorial concert occurred last evening, and was on the whole, successful. A large and brilliant audience was present, evidently composed largely of admirers of the dead composer, impressed with the...

An audience which filled the large hall of Cooper Institute attended last evening the celebration by the Clan-na-Gael of the one hundred and sixth anniversary of Robert Emmet's birthday. After an overture of Irish airs, rendered by Mlle. Rose ...

WASHINGTON, March 5.--The impossibility of making a trustworthy estimate of the reduction of revenue caused by the new Tariff act is shown by a statement made by Mr. Nimmo, of the Bureau of Statistics.
WASHINGTON, March 5.--The following circular has been issued by the Commissioner of Pensions and approved by the Secretary of the Interior:

WASHINGTON, March 5.--The Supreme Court of the United States convened at noon today, after the usual February recess. All of the Justices were present, and the whole afternoon was devoted to the reading of opinions.

The Rev. J. Lawson was to have been the speaker at the meeting of the Baptist preachers yesterday morning, but he was obliged to be absent at the funeral of Mr. Garford, the evangelist, whose labors in Mr. Lawson's church produced a revival last Winter.

BERLIN, March 5.--The Emperor has accepted the resignation of Gen. Von Kameke as Minister of War. Either Gen. Bronsart Von Schellendorff or Gen. Capiri will succeed him. Gen. Von Kameke resigned because of ...

The Netherlands American Steam Navigation Company and the Royal Netherlands Steamship Company have been consolidated. The former line was established 10 years ago, and at first ran between Rotterdam and this port. Afterward the steamers ran both to Rotterdam and Amsterdam.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 5.--The thriving town of Redwing. which is becoming a milling centre, met with a severe loss yesterday morning. About 1 o'clock flames mere noticed almost simultaneously in the fourth floor of the Bluff Mill and the third floor of the Diamond Mill, both the property of the Redwing Milling Company.

ST. LOUIS, March 5.--The latest news from the lower Mississppi River is that the water at Helena is rising at the rate of about half an inch per hour, and it is now thought that the highest mark of last year will be reached.

A meeting of the Executive Committee of the National Anti-Monopoly League was held yesterday afternoon at No. 7 Warren-street. After considerable discussion a memorial to the Legislature, praying for the passage of the Five-cent Fare bill over the Governor's veto, was adopted.

"Old Shipmates" will be performed until the end of this week at the Cosmopolitan Theatre. The sixth private concert of the New-York Stock Exchange Glee Club will take place at Chickering Hall on Saturday evening at 8 o'clock.

HARTFORD March 5.--The death of Marshall Jewell has been considered mainly in the light of a personal loss among his friends here and elsewhere, and as a serious thing in a business point of view, so prominently was he identified with industrial pursuits in the State.

WASHINGTON, March 5.--Lieut. James A. Buchanan, Fourteenth Infantry, has been relieved from duty in the office of Major Robert N. Scott, Third Artillery, in charge of the publication of the official records of the rebellion, in this city, and ...
Secretary Folger to-day gave instructions that the word "cents" be added to the new five cent piece in order to meet the requirements of law.

CHICAGO, March 5.--The leading produce markets were rather more active to-day, but irregular in tone. Provisions were weak, with only a shade of strength at the outset. Wheat was strong early in the day, and rather weak later. Corn was strong early and continued firm, while oats varied badly, closing higher.

The Spring meeting of the National Association of General Passenger Agents of the Railways of the United States, which was to have been held in Jacksonville, Fla., will be held at No. 26 Bond-street, in this City, on March 18.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5.--A large number of prominent citizens, manufacturers, and others were questioned to-day regarding the Revenue and Tariff bill, which has just become a law. The substance of the opinions expressed is briefly given:
TRENTON, N.J., March 5.--The bill which makes the holding of a joint meeting legal duty on the part of the two houses of the Legislature was reached in its place on the House calendar this evening.
ALBANY, March 5.--The new charter for the city of Albany, contrary to general expectation, was ordered to a third reading by the Assembly this eveding without a word of remonstrance, or even comment.
DUBLIN, March 5.--Flynn, a bailiff of Lord Ardilaun, who was brutally beaten near Cloobur, County Mayo, last week, has died of his injuries.
WASHINGTON, March 5.--In reply to inquiries the Commissioners of Internal Revenue said to-day that the effect of the law reducing internal revenue taxation would be as follows:
BUFFALO, March 5.--There is a universal feeling of indignation in this city to-night over the failure of Mme. Christine Nilsson to sing in concert this evening according to advertisement.

Pilot-boat Ariel Patterson, No. 12, was run into and sunk by the steamer Commonwealth yesterday morning off Seabright, N.J. Pilot John Campbell was lost, but the remaining members of the crew were reached by the Commonwealth and brought to this City.

An interesting case involving a question of identity came before Justice Duffy yesterday, in Essex Market Police Court. Auguste Jameau, a manufacturer of artificial flowers at No. 767 Broadway, appeared against William Davis, a young man ...
The sub-committee recently appointed to devise some means of harmonizing the differences between the importers and jobbers in the tea trade met yesterday morning, but failed to come to any agreement.

Frederick Kaufman, a German musician, who resided at No. 191 Orchard-street, died yesterday in the Chambers-Street Hospital from a fracture of the skull received in some manner which has not yet been made clear.
Decisions were handed down in the Supreme Court of the United States yesterday in a number of cases involving the efforts of creditors to hold States to their contracts in the issue of bonds.

CINCINNATI, March 5.--The political future of Judge Hoadley continues to be a topic of much speculation. A week ago the information was furnishsd that he would be compelled on account of the press of professional business to decline the Democratic nomination for Governor.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5.--A hearing was begun before Judge Hare to-day in the cases of the Gas Trust clerks, J. Spencer Smith, Martin Culp, and Albert T. Goodman, charged with embezzlement while in the employ of the Trust.

The Bijou Opera-house managers were considerate in labeling the play produced by them last evening as a "musical comedy." They would have been still more considerate toward a long-suffering and often-pained theatre-doing community had they not produced the play at all.

Mr. C.E. Douglass, of Crockett, Texas, was fatally shot in the Opera-house in Galeston, Texas, on the evening of the 28th ult., just at the close of the performance, and died at 3:40 o'clock the same night. The circumstances of the accident are very singular.

WASHINGTON, March 6.--The Government will lose a very faithful and efficient officer when Treasurer Gilfillan goes to NewYork at the end of this month. He rose to the office he now holds from the ranks, having entered the Treasury Department as a clerk at a salary of $1,200.

The quinine manufacturers of this country are very much depressed by the action of Congress upon the tariff question. This feeling is shown in the following statement of Mr. C.A. Robbins, of the firm of McKesson Robbins:

The terms on which the Erie Road assumes the lease of New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railroad have been agreed upon, and the lease was signed yesterday by President Hugh J. Jewett, of the Erie Road, President Jarvis M. Adams, of the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Road, and ...

ST. LOUIS, March 6.--Col. William Dalton Mann, of London, was a visitor on the floor of the Merchants' Exchange this morning. Col. Mann is the agent of the Franco-American Steam-ship Company, and the purpose of his visit, as explained by himself, is to ascertain the practicability of establishing a regular line of steamers between NewOrleans and Havre.

WASHINGTON, March 6.--The Government closed its case in the star route trial today, and the defense will begin to-morrow. Judge Wilson, counsel for Brady, said, after adjournment, that he did not know whether the defendants would go upon the stand or not.
ALBANY, March 6.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruger, Chief-Justice, presiding, the following decisions were handed down: Mark vs. The National Fire Insurance Company; ...
The petition addressed to the Trustees of Columbia College asking for the extension of certain educational facilities to women was simple and direct.

CLEVELAND, March 6.--The passage of the Tariff bill is generally looked upon as a forerunner of the reduction of wages of iron and steel workers. No such action has yet been taken, but it is looked for at any time.

Oliver P. Burton called to order in Jefferson Hall, at Fulton and Adams streets, Brooklyn, last evening the first meeting held in that city to discuss the protection of American industries. There were only about 30 persons present.
BADEN BADEN, March 6.--Prince Gortschakoff, ex-Chancellor of Russia, is dangerously ill here.
A Washington paper speaks of a certain man as an "ex-forger." A young girl of 16 has just married a man of over 70 years in Olneyville, R.I.
TRENTON, March 6.--The committee appointed to investigate charges of bribery made against ex-Speaker John Egan reluctantly reported adversely to Egan to-day.

The Commissioners appointed by the Supreme Court to estimate the benefits and damages which will result to the land along the Harlem River and Spuyten Duyvil Creek by the proposed canal which Gen. Newton is to cut from the East to the North River, or what is knows as the Harlem River Improvement, have completed their report, ...

The Young Women's Christian Association gave their annual reception in the hall of the organization, at No. 7 East Fifteenth-street, last evening Mr.William Harmon Brown, of the Advisory Board, presided, and the Rev. Drs. R.R. Booth and Henry C. Potter were present on the stage.

The seventeenth annual Commencement of the New-York College of Dentistry took place last evening at Chickering Hall, which was crowded with the many friends of the 31 young graduates who composed the Class of '83.

CHICAGO, March 6.--The leading produce markets were rather slow to-day and generally weak, though they did not show any large decline in prices. There is a good deal more stuff on sale than is wanted, except perhaps in corn, but holders did not press their property on the market severely ...
The Japanese Envoys to Hawaii, who are now on a short visit to this city, were formally presented to the President to-day by the Secretary of State.

ALBANY, March 6.--The Senate, in Committee of the Whole, discussed at some length a bill introduced by Mr. Bowen extending the range of investments that may be made of the surplus funds of fire insurance companies.
ATLANTA, March 6.--A.O. Bacon, of Macon, who opposed Mr. Stephens in the recent canvass, has arrived in the city and announced himself a candidate.

Tobacco manufacturers are well pleased with the passage of the bill raducing the internal revenue tax on their products, principally because the settlement of the question restores confidence within the trade.

UTICA, March 6.--Utica elects Charles A. Doolittle, Democrat, Mayor, by 600 majority, and the rest of the city ticket, except the city Treasurer, is Democratic--4 of the 6 Aldermen and 11 out of the 12 Supervisors.

WASHINGTON, March 6.--Ex-Speaker Keifer has left this city for his home in Ohio. It was well known to a few persons on Saturday last that he was bitterly opposed to the Tariff bill as reported from the conference committee.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 6.--Next Saturday and the two following Saturdays the Harvard Athletic Association will hold its in-door meetings. As of late years the meetings will to held in the new Hemenway Gymnasium, and they will be, as usual, fully attended by the students and their friends, both ladies and gentlemen.

At the sitting of the Essex County magistrates at Colchestar on Saturday, the Rev. Henry Clarke Hewson, Vicar of Fingringhoe, near Colchester, appeared in answer to summonses, one charging" him with being drunk and disorderly on the 2d inst., and the...

BALTIMORE, March 6.--There was quite a flurry at the Stook Exchange to-day. Virginia securities were in a terribly demoralized condition. The last prices for consols on Monday were, at the call, 51 ; on the street, 48.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 6.--The storm signal was hoisted a few minutes after 6 o'clock this evening, causing considerable speculation as to whether the startling prediction of Wiggins that a storm of terrible severity was to occur this week, was to be verified three days before the Ottawa prophet expected.

The Standard Quartet Club certainly has no reason to complain of a want of appreciation. The fourth concert of the present season was given last night before an audience of flattering size, when the discouraging state of the weather is considered.

The annual presenfation of marksmen's badges to the members of the Seventh Regiment was made last evening. Tickets were issued to the friends of the members, and the doors of the armory were looked after a reasonable time had elapsed.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6.--John B. Clark, as principal, and Samuel H. Brough and Thomas B. Lyons as accessories, were committed to prison without bail by the Coroner to-day charged with the murder of Chang Ah You, a young Chinaman who was employed in the laundry of Sam Wah, at No. 844 South Second-street.
In spite of all official reports to the contrary, the internal condition of Russia is said by those who have lately visited the empire to be as bad as ever.

Prof. William G. Sumner, of Yale College, read a paper before the Nineteenth Century Club last evening on the subject of "Sociology." The audience which assembled in Courtlandt Palmer's parlors, at No. 117 East Twenty-first-street, to listen to the Professor and discuss this abstruss subject was large and brilliant, among those present being Mr. and Mrs. Everett P. Wheeler, Mr. and ...

Coroner Levy charged the jury yesterday in the inquest over the little victims of the school of the Most Holy Redeemer, in Fourth-street, yesterday, and after over three hours of deliberation a verdict was rendered.
There is a diversity of opinion as to the effect that the new tariff schedule, which is to go into effect July 1, will have upon the woolen and worsted trade.

DUBLIN, March 6.--The Freeman's Journal says it is confidently believed that the French authorities will release Frank Byrne from custody, as affidavits conclusively proving an alibi in his case have been forwarded to Paris by a special messenger.

WASHINGTON, March 6.--The court, counsel, and jury appeared to be refreshed after the three days' intermission when the star route trial was resumed this morning. The witness Boone was recalled by Mr. Bliss.

The snow-storm which visited this City yesterday was one of the most disagreeable, though by no means the heaviest, which have characterized this exceptionally stormy season. The flakes began to fall at 6:10 o'clock in the morning, dropping gently at first and giving no evidence that they had come to stay.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 28.--I drove out to Jacob Thompson's beautiful home to-day in the suburbs of this city to find him enjoying all the comforts and luxuries of life. All of his conversation was instructive and interesting.
Critics of M. DAUDET'S new story, "L'Evangeliste," have complained of the gross improbability of the virtual kidnapping of Mlle. Erben by a fanatical Protestant zealot.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of Packard's Businees College was celebrated in the Academy of Music last evening. There was a large audience, composed principally of the students and their friends and business men who have graduated from the college.

BOSTON, March 6.--Goodwin H. Bush, of Westfield, Mass, was arraigned in the United States Circuit Court on two indictments, charging him with defrauding the Government of taxes by the illicit distilling of spirits at a distillery in Westfield, and pleaded not guilty. The case was continued until Tuesday next.

ALBANY, March 6.--The assembly to-day had under consideration for a brief period the Carey-Tremper Harbor-master bill. This bill authorizes the Mayor of New-York to appoint the Captain of the Port and six Harbor-masters; the Captain of the Port to hold office three years and the Harbor-masters two years.

The Manhattan Railway Company is the incubus on the rapid transit system of this City. It has been used as a device for ex panding the nominal capital represented in the elevated railroads and for practically consolidating, competing lines in a monopoly.

ALBANY, March 6.--The assembly to-day had under consideration for a brief period the Carey-Tremper Harbor-master bill. This bill authorizes the Mayor of New-York to appoint the Captain of the Port and six Harbor-masters; the Captain of the Port to hold office three years and the Harbor-masters two years.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 6.--Between 500 and 600 men employed in the Springfield Rolling Mills are on strike because of the employment of non-union men in some of the departments. Some of the non-union men have joined the strike. All the departments except the plow plate mill are shut down.

The steam-ship Caracas, of the Red Letter D. Line, arrived yesterday from Curacoa. Capt. HopKins reported at the office of the owners. Messrs. Dallett, Boulton Co., of No. 135 Pearl-street, that the authorities at Curacoa, had apologized for the firing at the steam-ship Valencia as she was leaving that port on Feb. 12.

The Republicans in the Legislature should do all that can be done to compel the majority in that body to meet fairly and directly the question of a reform of the public service in the cities of this State and under the State Government. The public evasion of a commission of inquiry should not be allowed to pass without challenge.
"The Long Strike" will be acted only until the end of this week at the Windsor Theatre.

The burning of the Cambridge Flats, with its attendant loss of life, is a blow directed at a class of buildings popular and almost necessary in this City. The architectural beauty of many of these structures, their central situation, their aptness of arrangement to meet the requirements of domestic life, together with the benefit of ...
LONDON, March 7.--The valuable collection of paintings and the plate and furniture in Wrotham Park, the country seat of the Earl of Strafford, which was burned yesterday, were saved.

The annual meeting of the Union Pacific Raliway Company took place in this City yesterday. The following Directors were elected: Sidney Dillon, Elisha Atkins, F. Gordon Dexter, Frederick L. Ames, Ezra H. Baker, Jay Gould, Russell Sage, Solomon Humphreys, David Dows, Grenville M. Dodge, Augustus Schell, S.H.H. Clark, John Sharp, ...
MEMPHIS, March 7.--A special to the Appeal from Helena, Ark., says: "The crisis has been reached here, although it can scarcely be said to have been passed.

The third performance this season of the Oratorio Society took place at the Academy of Music last night in the presence of a large and brilliant audience, which manifested its enjoyment of the entertainment in an unmistakable manner. Mendelssohn's "Elijah" was the oratorio given, a work which, except at the society's public rehearsal on Tuesday, has not been given here for two years.

Commissioner Olliffe presided over the meeting of the Park Commissioners yesterday, and a somewhat exciting discussion characterized the session. Gen. Viele and Mr. Wales being the prinsipal participants. After the reading of the minutes, Commissioner Viele asked that a correction night be made to the press reports in regard to Dr. Morris's report on the sanitary condition of the Arsenal in Central Park.

DETROIT, Mich., March 7.--The Democratic State Convention at Lansing to-day was attended by about half the number of delegates to which it was entitled. For Judge of the Supreme Court, full term, John W. Champlin, of Grand Rapids, was nominated. For Regent of the State University, Arthur L. Clark, of Sanilac County, was nominated.

To-night Chickering Hall will be invaded by picture-dealers, amateurs, dilettante, and those who come to stare. The collection of painting which just filled, and no more, the galleries of the Messrs. Leavitt, and which is said to belong to Mr. J.C. Runkle, will be brought to the hammer. Mr. Avery has done his best to give the pictures every advantage.
Secretary Folger to-day ordered the reinstatement of W.H. Daniels as Collector of Customs at Ogdenaburg, N.Y., thereby displacing Mr. Jones, the present incumbent.

WASHINGTON, March 7.--The leave of absence of Col. George F. Andrews, Twenty-fifth Infantry, from Sept. 12, has been extended six months. The leave of absence granted First Lieut. Alfred C. Sharpe, Twenty-second Infantry, has been extended five days. The order relieving Capt. F.H. Hathaway, Assistant Quartermaster, from duty in the Department of Dakota, has been suspended until further orders.

WASHINGTON, March 7.--"Then I say before the living God that I never saw such a check." These were the words uttered in a loud voice, with uplifted hand, that cost the Hon. James B. Balford, of Colorado, $100 in the Criminal Court this afternoon during the progress of the star route trial.

PITTSBURGH, March 7.--In reviewing the Tariff bill to-day Mr. Joseph D. Weeks, Secretary of the western Iron Association, made a discovery that is of great importance to the iron rod trade, which was thought to have been killed when the bill became a law. In calling the attention of THE TIMES'S correspondent to the matter he said:

The apartment-house No. 48 East Sixtyfourth-street, between Madison and Park avenues, known as "The Cambridge," was partially destroyed by fire early yesterday morning. Of the 10 families inhabitinq the house all escaped in safety save two ladies, Mrs. Mary H. Wakeman and her ...

WASHINGTON, Penn., March 7.--The seventeenth human body was reduced to ashes in the Le Moyne Crematory to-day. The custom seem to be growing in favor. Only five weeks ago the body of a child of Dr. Samuel Hahn, deceased, of New-York, was incinerated here.

HALIFAX, March 7.--The severest strom experienced here this Winter raged last night, the wind blowing fiercely from the south-east, and heavy snow-drifts forming in the streets. Beginning shortly after 10 o'clock it increased in severity until 3 in the morning, when it was sweeping over the whole Province with great fury.

CHICAGO, March 7.--The loading produce markets were weak to-day, with a moderate volume of trading, chiefly on local account. There was a good deal of selling all around by holders and some by shorts, but the latter were rather easy about operating, though not a few of them looked longingly at the situation.

A large crowd of men and women who delight in listening to scandal assembled yesterday in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, to listen to the testimony in the suit of Edward Schnell against his uncle, Frederick Blohm, for $50,000 damages for alienating the affections of his wife.
COLUMBUS, March 7.--The fight among the Democrats for the first place on their State ticket this year is gradually narrowing down to a contest between the Hoadly and Geddes factions.

WASHINGNTON, March 7.--Under date of Iakutsk, Siberia, Dec. 8. Lieut. Harber gives a detailed report of the operations of his party in their search for the missing people of the Jeannatte. At midnight, June 23 and 24, they left Iakutsk for the Lens delta, arriving at Bulun July 3. They took in the stores left by Engineer Melville and fitted out four parties with native boats.

ALBANY, March 7.--The most important bill that has passed by the Assembly to-day was that of Senator Titus, abolishing the office of Canal Appraiser and the State Board of Audit and establishing in their stead a Board of Claims, composed of three Commissioners, with a salary of $5,000 each.

DUBLIN, March 7.--At a meeting of the Local Board of Swineford, County Mayo, it was reported that great distress prevailed in the district. More than 30 persons are in the Poor-house suffering from famine fever.

NEW-HAVEN, March 7.--The fifth Winter meeting of the Yale Athletic Association took plane in the gymnasium this afternoon. The first event upon the programme was the tug of war (600 pounds) between the Classes of '83 and '85. The teams were as follows: Representatives of '83-- Frank H. Beede, Dover. N.H.; A.L. Bowman.

The arrival of the body of the murdered heavy-weight pugllist, James Elliott, yesterday morning, has created great interest in sporting society in this City. When Elliott was fought to his death by Jerry Dunn in a Chicago restaurant on the evening of March 1, the sporting gentlemen of that city made no sign that they would have him decently buried there, and mild-mannered "Parson" ...

ALBANY, March 7.--The largest audience that has assembled in the Chamber this Winter gathered to-night to witness the proceedings in the effort of the Assembly to override the Governor's veto of the Five Cent Fare bill. It was a foregone conclusion that the attempt would prove unsuccessful, and the proceedings were funereal in their nature.

The tariff appears to be generally satisfactory to firms employed in the manufacture of ladies' cloaks, although when passed by the Senate it threatened to seriously injure their businees. The general feeling of the subject was expressed yesterday by F.C. Campbell, of the firm of Meyer, Jonasson Co., of No. 358 Broadway.

Charles Appleby married Mary A. Britton in October, 1877, and went to live with her at the home of her parents. In October last he left his wife at that place and established his home elsewhere. Mrs. Appleby then began a suit for a limited divorce, charging that her husband had illtreated and abandoned her.

One of the perpetrators of the daring highway robbery in Greenwich-street on Feb. 13, when the cash-box of Adolph Goldsmith, of No. 59 Greenwich-street, was stolen from his messenger boy, was brought to trial in the Court of General Sessions yesterday.

MIDDLEBURG, Penn., March 7.--Uriah Moyer was hanged here in the jail-yard at 11:08 this morning for the murder of Gretchen Kintzler on Dec. 8, 1877. The prisoner passed a very quiet night, sleeping well. When he was led out of his cell to the scaffold he stepped up firmly and exhibited great nerve.

LONDON, March 7.--News has just been received that the British steamer Gloucester City, Capt. Deslandes, which left Bristol on Feb. 8 for New-York, foundered on Feb. 23 in latitude 44 north, longitude 52 west. The crew were rescued and landed at Havre.
Tufts College, Massachusetts, receives $10,000 as a bequest from the late Miss Mary Blake, of Kingston, N.H.

ALBANY, March 7.--The Senate spent two or three hours to-day in the discussion of a bill introduced by Mr. Grady, and which he said was sent to him by Elbridge Gerry, counsel for the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. It prohibits all manufacturing corporations in this State from employing in manufacturing industry any minor under the age of 14 years under any circumstances.

Testimony for the defense in the star route case was begun yesterday with a somewhat disastrous effect upon the first witness, the Hon. J.B. BELFORD, of Colorado, who was fined $100 for contempt of court in insisting upon making a statement which he had been forbidden to make.

Messrs. George H. Andrews, Jackson S. Schultz, and William Laimbeer, the Commissioners appointed by Secretary Folger to select a site for the proposed Federal building in Brooklyn, met yesterday afternoon in the Common Council Chamber in that city, to receive offers of sites and to hear any suggestions which might be offered with a view of guiding them to a proper selection.

The importers of, and dealers in, china, glass, and earthen ware in this City are generally very much dissatisfied with the changer made in the tariff schedule as applied to their trade. The increased duties on the various grades of goods are bitterly complained of, and the alterations in the classification of duties on the products of foreign potteries are denounced by many importers as absurd and mischievous.

CINCINNATI, March 7.--The Germans, who are still sore over the liquor legislation of last Winter, have been wrought up again to a serious extent by the proposition to abolish the teaching of German from the public schools. A bill containing such a provision was introduced into the Legislature by Senator Dexter yesterday.

For several days several men have been at work in tha Registerts office searching the records of mortgages and deeds and taking notes therefrom. They appeared as soon as the office was open in the morning, each carrying under his arm a cigar-box in which he kept his notes, and remained until the office closed at night.

TRENTON, March 7.--The Senate held a long and, as common rumor has it, a very excitinq executive session this evening. The particular bond of contention was the nomination by the Governor of ex-Assemblyman James J. Bergen as Prosecutor of Somerest County. Mr. Bergen was nominated by the Governor last year, but the Senate failed to ...

In the Westchester County Circuit Court, at White Piains, yesterday, the entire day was taken up in the trial of the matter of the application for a commission for the care of Mrs. Henrietta Wiley, of William's Bridge, and her property.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7.--A special dispatch to tho Times from Washington says: "Senator Cameron's health is much more seriously impaired than is generally supposed, and his condition is regarded by many as really critical, but not at all hopeless.

CLEVELAND, March 7.--The annual meeting of the Cleveland, Columbus, Cincinnati and indianapolis Railroad Company to-day wes devoid of any great degree of interest, as no exciting questions were up for discussion or settlement. The Vanderbilt proxies were on hand, and as there was only one ticket fin the field it was unanimously elected as follows:

At a meeting of the Medico-Legal Society last evening in Mott Memorial Hall, ex-Surrogate Calvin presiding, Dr. O'Sullivan made an interesting statement in regard to the condition of the public school buildings. He said that several years ago he made a request to the President of the Board of Education that there should be medical supervision of the public schools.
WELLINGTON, New-Zealand, March 8.-- The Maori chiefs Tewhiti and Tohu have been released from prison.

The Commissioners appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury to select a site for the proposed Federal Building in Brooklyn met again yesterday in the Common Council Chamber of that city, Commissioner Andrews called the meeting ...
ALBANY, March 8.--The democratic majority in the Assembly refused to-night to give to Mr. Henry I. Sprague the seat which is now illegally occupied by a Tammang man, Mr. Thales S. Bliss.

Prof. SUMNER and HERBERT SPENCER may as well take a back seat and keep it. The former has been used up by the Tribune, aided by the Willimantic Linen Company and by Mr. FREDERICK B. HAWLEY, an alert and long-winded political economist, to whom we incautiously tendered the use of our columns for the purpose.

In the Supreme Court, at White Plains, yesterday, the hearing on the application for a commission to take charge of Mrs. Henrietta Wiley, of William's Bridge, and her property, on the ground that she is a habitual drunkard, was brought to a close.

HALIFAX, March 8.--Though to-morrow, the date for the breaking out of Prof. Wiggins's hurricane, is now at hand, there is no indication of the elements having yet begun to gather for even an ordinary exhibition of their power.

DETROIT, Mich., March 8.--The Greenback State Convention to-day accepted the proposals for a fusion made by the Democrats yesterday, nominated their half ticket, and adopted a platform distinctively their own.

PITTSBURG, March 8.--The Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers will hold a district meeting here Saturday afternoon to consider the scale of wages to be presented to the manufacturers and to go into force June 1.

ALBANY, March 8.--In spite of much opposition Mr. Roosevelt called up his resolution directing the Attorney-General to bring suit to annul the charter of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company, and secured enough votes to send it to the Judiciary Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 8.--Very little progress was made in the star route trial to-day. From time to time counsel for the defendants have loudly complained about the alleged unwillingness of the Government counsel to allow them to see some of the...
WASHINGTON, March 8.--All of the Civil Service Commissioners are in this city, Mr. Dorman B. Eaton having arrived to-night, and they expect to hold their first meeting tomorrow.
There were returned recently to the General Passenger Agency of the New-York Central Road a bundle of tickets which were found in the overhauling of one of the stations on the line of the road.

The steam-ship City of Merida, of the Alexandre Line, which arrived yesterday from Havana and Vera Cruz, was out in both of the hurricanes which prevailed last month in the Gulf of Mexico. Capt. Rettig states that the City of Merida was on her way from Havana to Vera Cruz on Feb. 17.

CLEVELAND, March 8.--The appointment of Thomas Jones to the Cleveland Post Office as a gift to the Stalwarts and Senator Jones, and the removal of United States Attorney Meyer because he bolted the Republican Congressional nominee, have caused no little comment and no end of criticism on the part of Republicans.
DUBLIN, March 8.--The authorities expect very soon to be able to implicate several Irish members of Parliament who have for a long time been suspected of connection with the murder conspiracy.
A Philadelphia paper which is pleased with the new tariff claims that many of its faults even are improvements on the old tariff.

Preparations for the approaching coronation at Moscow are now being rapidly pushed forward. The date of departure of the Court from St. Petersburg to the old capital will probably be about Easter. All the heirs apparent of Europe will receive invitations, but neither the German nor Austrian Crown Prince is expected.

NASHVILLE, March 8.--At an early hour this morning the firemen began to remove the debris of last night's fire, the work beginning in Foley's machine shop, as it was supposed William Miller had been killed by a falling wall at that place.

ALBANY, March 8.--The senate had up the Capitol Commission bill again to-day with a view to its final passage, but the mistake was made for the third time of calling it up so late in the session that the hour of adjournment arrived before it could reach a vote.

LONDON, March 8.--The trial of the action brought by Miss Fanny Hyland against Mr. Biggar, member of Parliament for Cavan, for damages for breach of promise of marriage, took place to-day, and the jury rendered a verdict against the defendant, the damages being fixed at 400.

The Police were yesterday made acquainted with the circumstances surrounding the strange disappearance of Mr. Charles Wood, a shippingmaster, of the firm of Wood White, who have an office at No. 124 West-street. He has been missing since the 28th ult. Wood was unmarried.

Experiments will soon be made with a view of introducing electricity as a motive power on the elevated roads in this City. These experiments, which are to be made on the Thirty-fourthstreet branch, will be conducted by Mr. Stephen B. Field, the electrician for the Mutual Union Telegraph Company.

George Affleck, alias George F. Adams, his wife, Carrie Affleck, and James Dunn, alias "Pop" White, alias "Doo" Long, are under arrest at Police Head-quarters charged with having robbed Jesse Williams, a farmer, of Orange County, N.Y., of a sachel containing $7,000 in gold coin.

Business in the Courts of General Sessions has frequently been retarded to an unwarrantable extent by the action of "green" jurymen--that is, jurymen not accustomed to passing upon cases--in not coming to an agreement one way or the other in the cases submitted to them.

CINCINNATI, March 8.--The Volksblatt (Republican) says: "The passage by the Legislature of the Dexter bill abolishing the instruction of German in the public schools will certainly result in the overthrow of the Republican Party and insure Democratic supremacy for many years to come."

Late Wednesday night Deputy Revenue Collectors Sempsey and Wills, assisted by two Police officers of the Thirty-first Precinct, seized an illicit distillery in the basement of an old house in West Ninety-sixth street, near the Riverside drive.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 8.--A dispatch from Helena, Ark., says: "The river has risen a scant half-ince during the past l2 hours. It is thought that the levees can now be held against probable emergencies, as they were maintained last night against a terrific eastern gale that sent the water dashing over in many places.

The most destructive fire which has occurred on the east side of the City for many months broke out early this morning in the candle factory of R.G. Mitchell Co., Nos. 379, 380, and 381 South-street, running through to Nos. 322 and 324 Front-street.

In the chapel of the Eighth Ward Mission, at No. 9 Ludlow-place, West Houston-street, 20 poor women listened yesterday afternoon to a talk from Mr. W. Bayard Cutting about "How to Pray," and to some Gospel hymns sung by Mr. and Mrs. George C. Stebbins.

Swayne, Robert Graham, the Rev. Dr. H.C. Potter, and ex-Judge Arnoux, composing a committee of the Church Temperance Society, called on Mayor Edson yesterday to secure his aid in efforts to reduce the evils of intemperance in this City.

ST. LOUIS, March 8.--A special telegram received from Van Buren, Ark., says: An attempt was made to-night to rob the mail train on the Little Rock and Fort Smith Road, just before reaching this place. The train was due here at 9:30 o'clock.

CHICAGO, March 8.--The leading produce markets were less active to-day and generally irregular. The early tone was weak, but toward 11 o'clock the markets started up strong and ruled so until past noon, when they eased off a little, and closed rather tame.

The members of the New-York County Executive Committee of the Anti-Monopoly League were in session two and a half hours last evening, and an hour and a half of the time was spent in a lively war of words on the part of several members.

ATLANTA, March 8.--All night long trains came in bearing delegations from every town and county in the State. Old men, young men, people who were famous in the war, and people who have obtained distinction since were mingled, and their solemn looks and measured steps gave evidence of the deep feelings that had been stirred up.

TRENTON, March 8.--The proposed new city charter for Jersey City and Newark met a sudden death in the House this afternoon. A few months ago a committee of citizens was organized in Jersey City to accomplish needed reforms in the methods of local government existing there.

The case of Mr. John Pondir, the Exchangeplace broker who caused the arrest, on a charge of assault, of E.F. Eberstadt, of No. 40 Broadway, was examined into at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday.

The trial of Excise Commissioner Hendrick Hendrickson, of Jamaica, was concluded before Judge Armstrong in the Court of Sessions in Long Island City yesterday. Hendrickson was charged with receiving $50 from a saloon-keeper for voting to grant him a license.

BOSTON, March 8.--The Massachusetts combination controlling the telephone exchange system, which has established itself throughout NewEngland and Northern New-York, has just extended its operations into portions of the North-western States.
At the regular monthly meeting of the Union League Club last evening, 14 new members were elected.

ALBANY, March 8.--The Assembly Railroad Committee held an interesting session this afternoon. The subject under consideration was the investigation into the charges of the Long Island Railroad officers that they had been approached ...

The recent decision of the United States Supreme Court, in the Virginia coupon case of Antoni against Greenhow, was accepted by the Readjusters of Virginia as a victory. Cannon were fired in Richmond on receipt of the news of their supposed victory.
The Executive Committee of the National Civil Service Reform League, of which Mr. George William Curtis is President, at a meeting in this City Wednesday adopted the following resolutions:
