WASHINGTON, March 8.--Gen. Nelson A. Miles was called to the witness stand this morning by the defense in the star route trial and examined by Mr. Chandler. He testified that in the Summer of 1876 he went into the Tongue River country.

The first meeting of the Land Transfer Reform Association was held in one of the rooms of the Bar Association Building last evening. A constitution and by-laws were adopted, officers elected, and a committee appointed to draft bills embodying the views of the association on certain subjects.

The reduction in the duty on silks from 60 to 50 per cent. is regarded by various persons interested in the manufacture and sale of silk goods in this City as not likely to have any disturbing effect upon that branch of the mercantile business. Importers manifest no particular satisfaction over the reduction, and domestic manufacturers do not ...

FREDERICK, Md., March 8.--Between 1 and 2 o'clock this morning Mr. Simon Crenise, who lives about two miles north of Newmarket, on the Burnt Mill road, was startled by the cries of his children and the sight of smoke and flames, which were pouring into his rooms.
In the course of a recent suit brought by a wife against her husband for abandonment, it appeared that the pair had originally quarreled over the question of naming their children.

A somewhat peculiar sort of petition has been presented to the Erie Road asking for the removal of the so-called "subarban" cars, which are being run on the trains to Newark and other points in the immediate vicinity, and the substitution in their place of the old style of passenger cars.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8.--Judge Elcock today heard evidence in support of the motion for a new trial for Thomas A. Craig, who was last week sentenced to the penitentiary for two years and six months for the betrayal of Elizabeth Benison under the promise of marriage.

CLEVELAND, Ohio.--The Plain Dealer publishes the following: A popular method of ascertaining the opinions of those whose opinions are valuable by reason of their prominence in the community in which they live, is the newspaper interview.

At the close of the war of the rebellion the State of Virginia found itself with a debt, incurred before the war, which, with accumulated interest, amounted to about $45,000,000. West Virginia had been made a State from its territory, the new State taking from the parent State about one-third of its wealth, territory, and population.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8.--The Park Theatre Company, of this city, has come to grief. The masculine survivors of the combination began arriving in town on freight trains last night, and by noon to-day 13 of the band called on Magistrate Lennon and asked to have a warrant issued for the arrest of Charles C. Marshall.

The attendance at the sale of the J.C. Runkle collection of foreign oil-paintings was sufficient to fill Chickering Hall last evening. The sale lasted until nearly midnight. The bidding was spirited, and the prices obtained were, as a rule, good.

When Miss Laura H. Wallace, who plays the Widow in "Our Shipmates," stepped up to the bar of Essex Market Police Court yesterday afternoon, when her case against Mrs. Frank Mordaunt for assault and battery was called, she trembled and said she was afraid Mrs. Mordaunt would do her some injury in court. Justice Duffy assured her that she would receive protection and need feel no anxiety.

The case of Edward Schnell against his uncle, Frederick Blohm, in which he seeks to recover $50,000 as damages for alienating the affections of his wife, came up again yesterday in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn.

An order was issued at the Post Office Department to-day to establish the free mail delivery at Binghamton. N.Y., on April 1.

A dispatch from Chicago, published in the City papers yesterday, announces that the competing shippers and lines of that city complain that David Dows Co., of this City, have been given a special rate on gain over the Erie Road.

ALBANY, March 9.--Mr. Roosevelt, of NewYork, exploded a bombshell in the Assembly this morning by rising to a question of privilege and tendering his rerignation as a member of the Committee on Contested Elections. In explanation of his course he said:

"Divorce" was the subject of the Lenter discourse by the Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix, in Trinity Chapel, last evening, and it was listened to by a congregation which crowded the church in every part, and overflowed through the doors to the vestibules.
The Manhattan Temperance Association will hold two meetings to-morrow. The first one will take plece in the Masonic Temple at 3 o'clock, and the second in Steinway Hall in the evening.

CLEVELAND, March 9.--William E. Ambush, a rather prominent and eccentric colored attorney of this city, was sentenced in the Criminal Court to-day to the penitentiary for a year and a half, having been convicted of attempting to black-mail a physician of high standing here.
At a late hour last night the grand car-- nival of destruction predicted by the eminent Canadian prophet, Mr. Wiggins, was a part of the unknown, unknowable, and undiscoverable.
PARIS, March 9.--Six thousand persons, most of them attracted by motives of curiosity, collected on the Esplanade des Invalides this afternoon.

CLEVELAND, March 9.--The indications on the surface of Ohio Democratic counsels suggest a row such as has usually injured the prospects of success at the polls and divided the party of the State into factions.
The audience at Chickering Hall Thursday afternoon was the largest that has attended any of the concerts given this season by Mr. George W. Morgan and his daughter, Miss Maud Morgan.
An order was issued at the Post Office Department to-day establishing free mail dalivery service at Watertown, N.Y., on April 1.
BERLIN, March 9.--Prince Bismarck is confined to his bed. He is again suffering with neuralgia.
One of the most troublesome species of thieves who trouble transportation companies are cotton-thieves. Dealers in cotton in this City are constantly annoyed by the breaking of their bales of cotton.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 9.--A story more startling than any previously related was reported to-day before the Legislative committee investigating the Dixmont Insane Asylum. The witness was R.B. Parks, a former attendant.

In the prison yard of the Tombs yesterday morning, at 8:12 o'olock, two convicted felons, Michael E. McGloin and Pasquale Majone, suffered death on the gallows.
A sad accident occurred yesterday morning on the Morris Canal, at the foot of Washingtonstreet, Jersey City, by which the lives of 35 laborers ware endangered and one man was drowned.
DUBLIN, March 9.--Eight daggers have been found in the Ringsend Basin.

The fire at R.G. Mitchell Co.'s candle factory at No. 322 Front-street kept the firemen busy until yesterday afternoon. At that time the candle factory was in ruins, and the contents of the adjoining cooperage of B. Cosgrove's Sons, on the Front-street side, had been consumed.
The trial of the suit of Edward Schnell to recover $50,000 for the loss Of the affections of his wife was continued yesterday in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, before Judge Cullen.
Mr. PATRICK EGAN, the Treasurer of the Irish Land League, has taken flight from Dublin and has retired into obscurity. Land Leaguers and officers of the British Government vainly search for EGAN.

HELENA, Ark., March 9.--The river has been stationary since yesterday, with 46 feet 11 inches on the gauge. It was stationary at Madison yesterday, and is probably falling today. A decline is confidently expected here by Sunday.

HALIFAX, March 9.--Should the stormwarning now be hoisted on the Citadel Signal Station it would create the greatest excitement and dread, so carefully are appearances of the next 24 hours' weather watched and every change of the most trivial character noted and everywhere and by every one commented on.

The ladies of Kentucky have been noted during this entire century for their unusual beauty and robust health. This reputation has been justly earned, for our ladies have in personal perfection certainly equaled, if not surpassed, the women of any other portion of the land.

The fifth concert of this (the forty-first) season will take place to-night at the Academy of Music, the first part being in memory of Richard Wagner, consisting entirely of his works, and the second part devoted to Beethoven's "Symphony Eroica."

The decision of a contested election case has not generally been regarded as a political event of the first importance. Many such cases have been decided in a partisan way without exciting special indignation or producing any perceptible political effect.

TROY, March 9.--The Trustees of Union College held a meeting at Schenectady yesterday, nearly all the members being present. The resignation of Prof. Pierson, Treasurer, was accepted, and William J. Woodward, of New-York, was elected to succeed him.

There was a row on Wednesday evening, at a meeting of the Washington Club, at No. 5 East Twelfth-street, and Robert Cushing, a sculptor, of No. 65 Irving-place, was struck in the face by Francis H. O'Toole, a plumber, of No. 242 Sixthavenue.

The marked diminution of cats in this City and in Brooklyn during the last three years is attracting the attention of scientific persons.
Fire Marshall Sheldon was engaged yesterday in investigating the origin of the fire at the Cambridge Flats, by which Mrs. Mary H. Wake man and her daughter lost their lives.

When the agents of the New-York Title Company visited the Register's office yesterday morning they were commanded by J.W. Bissell, of Boston, Superintendent of the company. Mr. Bissell took down a volume of mortgages and set one of his men at work.
WASHINGTON, March 9.--Ex-Secretary Blaine said to-day, with reference to the alleged attempt to assassinate him, that the window of the carriage was not broken while he was in it.

The probabilities are that no meeting of the Passenger Department of the Joint Executive Committee of the trunk lines and Western roads will be held in this City on March 15. Commissioner Fink is still confined to his house by a rheumatic attack, which is of so serious a character as to preclude the possibility of his being able to be present at such a meeting should one be called.

OTTAWA, March 9.--The 9th has arrived and passed, and no doubt many who had placed some confidence in the fulfillment of the great storm predicted by Dr. E. Stone Wiggins will be somewhat disappointed at the storm not coming.

LIVERPOOL, Feb. 16.--"I would like to talk with you about the trade of Liverpool, but more particularly as to the working of the American Shipping act," I said to Mr. Packard at the consulate yesterday.
LONDON, March 9.--The steamer Navarre, bound from Copenhagen to Leith, foundered during the gale of yesterday. There were 81 persons, mostly emigrants, on board, only 16 of whom were saved.

CHICAGO, March 9.--The leading produce markets were irregular to-day, with only a moderate amount of trading. Grain was weak, as a consequence of fine weather and an increasing movement from first hands, but stiffened a little late in the session, when a shifting of the barometric needle on 'Change led some operators to think that Wiggins's storm might be brewing after all.

One of the closest billiard matches ever contested in this City, and one which has excited much interest in sporting circles, was played last night at O'Connor's billiard-rooms, at Broadway and Twenty-second-street, by C.G. Davis and D.C. Johnson, two well-known amateurs.

ALBANY, March 9.--The Emigrant Commission having persuaded the Governor that the Senate was wrong in limiting the amount that they may draw of last year's appropriation to $90,000, he requested that the bill might be recalled from the Executive Chamber for amendment.
The New-Orleans Times-Democrat alludes to lockjaw as a very common affliction in that city. The Toronto Public School Board has just increased the salaries of the teachers throughout the list.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 9.--Katie Judd, of Boston, who set fire to the Weaver villa, escaped from the County Jail last night, in company with a young man named George Rounds, under arrest for breaking and entering ...

ALBANY, March 9.--The Assembly Reapportionment Committee reported the De Witt bill, which was made a special order for Thursday next. Mr. Howe, Republican, of New-York, said of it that while it was not the best bill that could be presented, it was, on the whole, as fair as the Republicans could possibly expect.

LONDON, March 9.--Bullion to the amount of 200,000 was bought yesterday for export to NewYork. It will be forwarded by Saturday's steamer.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 9.--The worst snow and wind-storm of the season is reported along the line of the Northern Pacific Railroad. Freight business west of Fargo is entirely suspended, and all passenger trains are getting through with great difficulty. Grafton, Dakota, has suffered the most, business being entirely suspended during the day.

HARTFORD, March 9.--A new phase of the Hartford and Harlem Railroad matter came before the Railroad Commissioners to-day. The corporators of the proposed road ask for an approval of their layout in sections, as for example, they want the Commissioners to approve a piece of road about eight miles long, between Newington and Meriden, and another piece in the vicinity of Norwalk.

PHILADELPHIA, March 9.--A Woman's cries for help started the neighborhood of Ninth-street, near Norris-street, between 5 and 6 o'clock this morning. The shrieks came from the residence of Samuel May, whose family occupies the dwelling No. 2,021 North Ninth-street.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 9.--On the 8th ult. at a meeting of the Trustees of Princeton College a committee of nine was appointed to take action upon Dr. McCosh's suggestion for the formation of a school of philosophy in the institution.
Patrolman Mullen, of the Twenty-seventh Precinct, found a window on the College-place side of the Produce Bank, at College-place and Barclay-street, open at 6:40 o'clock last evening.

Of all the recreations of which the average wealthy New-Yorker who is blessed with good health and spirits likes to indulge, yachting is probably the most expensive. But this can only be done by one who has a princely income--or unlimited credit.

HALIFAX, March 11.--With no appearance to-day of what Prof. Wiggins asserted would prove his greatest blow, but, on the contrary, a change of the wind to a westerly direction and a clearing of the weather, the doubts and fears of the people have passed away, and after three days of varying excitement the city has resumed its accustomed tranquillity.

"Spread the news," said the Rev. Lindsay Parker, the Pastor of the Sixty-first-Street Methodist Episcopal Church yesterday morning; "the church is free." He read the long roll containing the subscriptions, and said there was enough to pay the entire church debt of $32,500 and $1.500 over.

None of the methods hitherto employed to check the practice of burglary has been successful. The Police cannot suppress burglary for the reason that the burglar knows that the chances that he will escape detection are at least equal to the chances that he will fall into the hands of the Police.

One of the strangest freaks of the flood is reported from Whitewater River, a few miles above Lawrenceburg, where Farmer Hunt lost 40 acres of land and his neighbor, Fred Newhouse, had a barren and rocky mill site converted into 10 acres of as rich land as the fertile valley affords.

A Western valley, with a beautiful river in the middle of it, is the opening scene of my story. A few hundred yards from the bank of the stream stood a grove of stately trees, in the centre of which a brick cottage had been erected.

While Acting Police Sergeant Richard Comisky was seated at his desk in the Second Precinct Station-house, at East-avenue and Fifthstreet, in Long Island City, yesterday morning at about 11:20 o'clock, Patrolman Patrick J. Casey put a pistol up to his face and fired a bullet into his brain. Comisky was instantly killed.

It was thieves' day on the East Side yesterday. JAMES ELLIOTT, the murdered pugilist, bully, blackguard, and burglar was buried, and all the criminals in the City gathered to pay the last honors to his memory.

It is not generally known that the new tariff law repeals, from the moment of its passage, the provision of the previous law requiring that charges, package, , should be included in the dutiable value of imported goods.
While at Capt. Horer's place an invitation was received from Mr. and Mrs. Wilson to visit their place, but a short distance away, which invitation was accepted by the whole party.

There is a good deal of nonsensical talk about Col. Coppinger--the husband of Alice Blaine--going the rounds of the press. That Coppinger's marriage to Miss Blaine should have developed in him a subject for the paragrapher's wit and censure is lamentable.
BADEN BADEN, March 11.--Prince Gortschakoff, ex-Chancellor of the Russian Empire, is dead.

It was published far and wide that well known leaders of sporting society in this and neighboring cities would yesterday honor the memory of James Elliott, the murdered heavy-weight pugilist, by following his body to the grave. Miss Lillian Russell, Miss Augusta Roche Miss Alice Whitaore, Mme. de Ravasz, pianiste, and Mr. William Hamilton, together with a very good orchestra of from 40 to 50 musicians, conducted by Mr. Solomon, appeared last night at this theatre on the occasion of the third concert of the Sunday evening series.
A sneak-thief entered the residence of Mr. Herman Hahlo, No. 19 East Fifty third-street, on Saturday, and carried off from the rack in the hall five valuable overcoats.

WASHINGTON, March 11.--The organ of the brewers of the country, published here, says that it is satisfied with those paragraphs of the new tariff law which impose duties on barley and malt. The old duty on rye and barley was 15 cents a bushel, and the old duty on barley-malt, was 20 per cent. ad valorem.

WASHINGTON, March 12.--A decision was rendered by the Supreme Court of the United States to-day in the case of the New-York Guaranty and Indemnity Company et al., appellants, vs. The Memphis Water Company, The City of Memphis, et al., brought here by appeal from the Circuit Court of the United States for the Western District of Tennessee.

Judge Freedman, in the Superior Court, Chambers, yesterday, denied a motion made by the Metropolitan Elevated Railroad Company for the opening of the judgment entered in December, 1881, in the suit of the New-York Elevated Railroad Company against the Manhattan Railway Company and the Metropolitan Elevated Railway Company.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 12.--A cave occurred at Carrolton to-day which excited some apprehension, but the city threw a large gang of laborers into the gap and the damage was averted. CHICAGO, March 12.--The leading produce markets were dull and weak to-day. The fine weather here and weakness in England sent wheat down and the lead was followed by the rest. They all seemed to depend upon that to an unusual degree. The closing feeling was steadier, but tame.

ST. LOUIS, March 12.--At the special meeting of the representatives of the American Baseball Association, at the Lindell Hotel, to-day, the proceedings throughout were harmonious and businesslike. President H.D. McKnight, of the Allegheny Club, occupied the chair, and in the executive chamber were Messrs. Lew Simmons and William Sharsig, of the Athletics; James Mutrie, ...

PITTSBURG, March 12.--The oil market was very strong and excited to-day in consequence of well-authenticated reports of the falling off of production on the Cooper trade in Forest County. The market opened with sales at 95, and advanced to 97 , but dropped off to 95 under the heavy hammering of the bears. The bulls, however, had all the advantage on their side and soon rallied.
Mme. Sofia Scalchi, the great contralto, is staying in this City with Dr. Elsberg and family.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12.--John S. Syren, a German, attempted to murder his sister-in-law this morning at her residence, No. 406 South Twelfth-street. He fired two shots at her. One ball pierced the left breast and the other the abdomen. Syren then shot himself in the head above the right temple. The wounds of both will in all probability result in death.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 12.--At about noon to-day two large steamers were observed some distance off the harbor making slow headway toward this port. At once it was surmised that the disabled Inman steamer City of Chester had luckily been fallen in with by another steamer and was being towed safely to Halifax.

A dividend of 3 1/3 per cent., payable April 16, was declared on the common and preferred stock of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad, at a meeting of the Directors, in this City, yesterday. The books will close March 26, and reopen April 18. The annual statement was presented. The balance of the income account, Jan. 1, 1882, was $5,693,010.35.

The trial of the suit of Edward Schnell against his uncle, Frederick Blohm, to recover $50,000 damages for the loss of Mrs. Schnell's affections, which, according to the plaintiff, were alienated by the defendant, was resumed yesterday before Judge Cullen, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn. Augusta Scheder, a sister of Mrs. Schnell, testified that there had been frequent quarrels between Schnell and his wife.

WASHINGTON, March 12.--The "Diplomatic Correspondence" of the year 1882, transmitted to Congress with the last annual Message of the President, is now in course of publication by the Government Printing-office, and when completed will make a volume of about 600 pages. Nearly all the selected letters and extracts from letters of any general importance have been covered by current newspaper publication.

United States District Attorney Elihu Root entered upon his duties yesterday. He reappointed Mr. Samuel B. Clarke as senior attorney in the civil department and appointed Gen. B.B. Foster Assistant District Attorney, to have charge of the criminal department, in the place of Mr. Willlam P. Fiero, who forwarded his resignation to the Attorney-General yesterday.

The second and third sessions of the Presbyterian Sunday-School Institute, which were held yesterday afternoon and evening in the FourthAvenue Presbyterian Church, were very largely attended, and much interest was manifested in the addresses and the discussions of Sabbathschool methods of labor. The afternoon session was opened with a fifteen minute praise-meeting, which was led by Mr. George W. Beale.

It is probable that the Apportionment bill reported in the Assembly last week will be adopted without change. If so, the first five Congressional districts will include the counties of Long Island, four of them being comprised in Kings, and the next nine will include Staten Island, the small islands of the Bay, the City of New-York, and the County of Westchester.

HAVANA, March 12.--The Director of Fiances, Don Juan Loren, has left for Spain on board the Spanish mail steamer. The Sub-Treasurer remains in charge of the Treasury Department until a new Director has been appointed.

F.N. Lawrence, President of the Stock Exchange, gave his testimony in the office of Evarts, Southmayd Choate yesterday, in regard to the expulsion of W.J. Hutchinson from the Stock Exchange. The examination was in the course of Mr. Hutchinson's suit to regain possession of his seat, and was held out of court by agreement of counsel in the case.

From Cincinnati comes the information that General Passenger Agent Fuller, of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad, has decided to withdraw from the trunk line pool. Upon this statement is based the prediction of a railroad rate war. As the Chesapeake and Ohio is not a trunk line, and has never been a member of either the trunk line pool or of the Joint Executive Committee, it cannot well withdraw from either of them.

The new Hamburg steam-ship Hammonia arrived at this port yesterday morning and was moored at the new German docks in Hoboken. The Hammonia was built in the ship-yard of J. G. Thomsen, on the Clyde. Her hull is entirely of steel and is divided into nine water-tight compartments.

ALBANY, March 12.--The quidnuncs in Albany are greatly exercised over the flying visit that Gov. Cleveland made to New-York last Saturday afternoon. They want to know the object of the errand. The Anti-Monopolists insinuate that he went down to receive the congratulations of Jay Gould and other railroad monopolists on his veto of the Five Cent Fare bill.

WASHINGTON, March 12.--Although no instructions have been given to Gen. Drum to prepare the detail for a court of inquiry to investigate the management of the Signal Office under Gen. Hazen, there is reason to believe the matter was to-day called to the attention of the President by the Secretary of War, with the request that a court be ordered.

France, under the republic, has been very judicious in the selection of enemies upon whom to make war. She has carefully avoided meddling with nations armed with modern weapons, but she has fearlessly attacked Tunis and threatened Madagascar, and is now actively preparing for war with Mr. STANLEY in the valley of the Congo.

Mr. Mapleson's Spring season at the Academy of Music was begun last night successfully. The house was crowded, and the audience was evidently bent on being pleased, and testified its enjoyment with lavish applause and many floral offerings. The principal interest of the evening naturally centred in Mme. Albani, whose Margherita was unknown to most of those present.

Erwin Archer, alias Edwin Harvey Wadge, whose extradition to England on the charge of forgery is sought by the British Government, was a witness in his own behalf in his examination before United States Commissioner Osborn yesterday. He produced a legal document to prove that he had his name changed from Erwin Harvey Wadge to Erwin Archer on Jan. 17, 1878.

"Let the cows of Orange County kick over the pails," was the significant war cry at a large meeting held in the Court-house at Goshen yesterday, under the auspices of the Erie Mutual Milkproducers' Association. This sentiment meant that the milk producers of Orange and adjacent counties were desperately aroused in their controversy with the New-York City milk-dealers as to who shall fix the market price of milk.

WASHINGTON, March 12.--Morris Friedsam was appointed to-day to be Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third Collection District of New-York in place of Max Weber, resigned. This office has for some time been mentioned here as among those in which changes were to be made, but Mr. Friedsam ...

The Brooklyn Board of Aldermen met yesterday, and elected ex-Alderman James Dunne to the position of Keeper of the City Hall, made vacant by the resignation of James F. Waters. The salary is $35 a week, and the Keeper's family is furnished with rooms, fuel, and light. The appointment was made by a strict party vote, 14 Democrats voting for Dunne and 9 Republicans voting against him.

ALBANY, March 12.--A spirited contest over the office of Superintendent of Public Instruction is going on among the Democrats. The principal candidates are ex-Deputy Attorney-General W.B. Ruggles, of Steuben; exDeputy Superintendent of Public Instruction Edward Danforth, of Elmira, and the present Superintendent of the Public Schools of Utica, Mr. Andrew McMillan.

The suspension of Blossom, Hayne Co., dealers in naval stores, at No. 164 Front-street and at Wilmington, N.C., was reported yesterday. Members of the firm declined to say anything in relation to their affairs except that they were liquidating. A creditor said yesterday that there had been a general understanding among them to keep the matter from the public, as a settlement was in progress.

The steam-ship Hudson, of the Cromwell Line, which left New-Orleans on the 7th inst., reached this port yesterday. After the vessel had passed Sandy Hook the hatches were opened. Anodor of smoke was detected at the main hatchway and the temperature of this hold was high.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 14.--The river tonight marks 34 feet 3 inches. Memphis is again in direct telegraphic communication with Helena, Ark.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14.--Loo Chin Coon, the most famous and popular actor that ever delighted ad Chinese audience in San Francisco, arrived in this city this morning. When the Chicago express train, on which he was, came into the Broadstreet station a fat Chinaman who had for more than an hour peered patiently through the gates became strangely agitated.
PHILADELPHIA, March 14.--The Liverpool, London, and Globe Insurance Company is erecting on Walnut street, below Fourth, a six-story building.

LONG BRANCH, March 14.--On Monday last, while James Hubbard, a Middletown farmer, with some farm-hands, was engaged in removing some stumps, he unearthed a nest of adders, old and young, not at all pleased at being disturbed. The farm-bands fled, but Mr. Hubbard succeeded in killing 18 snakes when the farm-hands returned and assisted in dispatching the remainder.

LONG BRANCH, March 14.--Pilot-boat No. 12, which was run into and sunk off Seabright by the steamer Common wealth about two weeks ago, was raised to-day and towed toward New-York. The body of Pilot Campbell, who was supposed to have been caught in the rigging was not found.

LONDON, March 14.--In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Parnell moved the second reading of his bill amending the Land act. He said agitation in Ireland must continue to increase until the act was amended. Mr. Chaplin, Conservative, moved the rejection of Mr. Parnell's bill. Mr. Thomas Dickson, Liberal, supported the measure because it embodied the programme adopted by the conference of Ulster tenants.
A driving-belt 42 inches wide slipped and broke last evening in the United States Illuminating Company's generating depot, No. 36 Stantonstreet, and put the machinery out of gear.

WASHINGTON, March 14, 1883. The Malagassy Envoys took official leave of the President this afternoon. They will leave here to-morrow for New-York, and will probably stop in Baltimore and Philadelphia.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 14.--The disapappearance of James Dunn, a well-known boss mason and contractor, was reported to-day by his family. On Saturday morning he was paid $l,000 for work done for Mr. John Hocy, at Hollywood Park. Dunn then went to Red Bank and drew $850 from the bank. All traces of his movements after leaving the bank have been lost. He was sober and reliable, and his friends cannot account for his disappearance.

PITTSBURG, March 14.--A shooting tournament will be held here on April 3, 4, 5, and 6. On the first day Capt. A.H. Bogardus and Dr. W.J. Carver will contest for a purse of $800. Contestants from all the principal cities have signified their intention of being present.

CHICAGO, March 14.--The last game of the preliminary balk-line tournament was played here to-night, and resulted in Morris scoring 500 to Wallace's 471 points; 53 innings; best runs--Wallace, 54; Morris, 67. The result of the tournament is that Wallace and Morris will take part in the big tournament beginning here March 26. In the preliminary tournament Morris won the first prize, Wallace the second, and Gallagher the third.

The township elections in Passaic County on Tuesday resulted in important gains to the Republicans. In Acquackanonk a Union ticket was chosen without opposition. In Little Falls the Republican ticket was chosen almost unanimously. In Manchester the Republicans swept the field.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 14.--The United States men-of-war Tennessee and Yantic arrived to-day and anchored in front of the city. The Vandalia, Alliance, and Kearsarge are in the river and will be up in the morning. A decree has been gazetted prohibiting the importation of American hog products, including sides, bacon, and sausages.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, March 14.--Navigation is practically open between this city and the island region. There is no ice in the bay or in the lake of the port. The steamers made trips to-day to Marslehead, Kelley's Island, and Put-in Bay, and report all the routes open to navigation.

WASHINGTON March 15.--Ex-Gov. Crawford, the resident Washington Agent of the State of Kansas, to-day filed at the Interior Department a brief in support of the position taken by the State authorities on several long-pending questions in regard to the Atchison. Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad land grant, and the case will probably come before the Secretary for oral argument at an early day.

About 400 dairy farmers of Orange County crowded into the dusty court-room in Goshen yesterday afternoon, and unanimously reaffirmed their determination to ship no milk to the NewYork City milk-dealers until the latter would agree to pay 3 cents a quart for March milk.

One of the wildest and most shameless revels which has ever disgraced the record of local occurrences was the "Grand Soarlet Ball" which was given in McGlory's dance hall, in Hester-street, last evening, in which 2,000 male and female debauchees took part, and the like of which could not be found the world over.

LONDON, March 15.--The fortieth annual university boat-race between the picked crews of Cambridge and Oxford was rowed on the Thames late this afternoon in the midst of a snow-storm, and concluded after darkness had fallen on the river.

ALBANY, March 15.--Mr. Roosevelt appeared before the Assembly Judiciary Committee this afternoon and made an argument in favor of his resolution directing the Attorney-General to bring suit to dissolve the Manhattan Railway, of New-York.

In 1877 Henry Stanley made his wonderful descent of the Congo River, and revealed the fact that, if the Livingstone Falls were once surmounted, and Stanley Pool reached, there would be waterway for hundreds of miles up the course of this equatorial stream. The mouths of the Congo had been discovered in 1481 A.D. by the Portuguese, and are immortalized in the "Lusiad" of Camoens.

A survivor of Balaclava--one of the "noble six hundred"--is dead in England, and a fortnight ago was buried with military honors at Plymouth. A large crowd followed the remains to the grave the procession being led by a band of music.

A foolish quarrel between two young law students has not only involved the participants in serious trouble, but also four friends who were silly enough to allow themselves to be drawn into the affair. Five young men were brought before Justice Power, of the Fourth District Police Court, yesterday afternoon to answer to the charge of attempted dueling.

WASHINGTON, March 15.--Gen. Brady resumed his testimony in the star route trial this morning. Referring to the testimony already given in regard to the Redding-Alturas route, the witness said he had no means of knowing that the mail was being earned in shorter time than the expedited schedule before the order for expedition was made.

Ludwig Barney will appear as Marc Antony in a German version of Shakespeare's "Julius Caesar" at the Thalia Theatre next Monday evening. Herr Reinan will be Brutus and Herr Kierschner Cassius. The scenery and costumes will be copies of those used by the Meiningen actors when they produced this tragedy in London.

LONDON, March 1.--Mr. Parnell may have exercised a wise discretion, personally, in refusing to answer the indictment of Mr. Foster, but as a statesman he has injured whatever prestige he may have possessed, and his silence is an indorsement of the charge that the Land League has connived at murder.

LONDON, March 15.--Lord Edmund Fitzmaurice, Under Foreign Secretary, stated in the House of Commons this afternoon, in answer to Mr. Coleridbe Kennard's question, that the Government had done nothing toward recovering the surplus of the Alabama award.

A meeting of depositors of the suspended Oriental Savings Bank to "undertake proceedings for an aocounting," as the object was stated in the call, was held yesterday afternoon at the law office of T.V. Jarvis Christophers, No. 92 Eldridge-street. The Receivers have been discharged, having turned over to the Bank Department the unclaimed dividends, amounting to $2,255.50.

WASHINGTON, March 15.--The President to-day appointed A.U. Wyman, Assistant Treasurer of the United States, to be Treasurer, vice James Gilfillan, whose resignation has been accepted to take effect on April 1. Mr. Wyman will secure his bond and qualify by that date.

CINCINNATI, March 15.--The Republican convention which was held to-day nominated L.L. Sadler for Mayor on the second ballot. The other candidates were Herman T. Knuwener, Capt. James S. Wise, John Simpkinson, and Charles Jacob, Jr.

WASHINGTON, March 15.--The direct examination of Gen. Brady came to an end soon after the beginning of the session of the court this morning, and the witness was then taken in hand by Mr. George Bliss. The cross-examination continued until adjournment, and was, for the most part, confined to the orders for increase and expedition made by the witness while in office.

OTTAWA, March 15.--A return, consisting of a copy of the memorial addressed to the GovernorGeneral from the Royal Society of Canada and the Canadian Institute of Toronto relative to a representation of Canada in the international conference to determine a standard meridian, now contemplated by the Congress of the United States, was laid on the table of the Senate to-day.

An effort is being made to organize another Unitarian Church in this City, or rather to revive the church of which Mr. O.B. Frothingham was Pastor. It will be called "The Third Unitarian Church Theistic," the word Theistic being added to indicate that the object of the congregation will be the worship and service of God the Father.

ALBANY March 15.--The Assembly resumed to-day the consideration of the application of the Westchester Catholic Protectory for an appropriation of $25,000 and the insertion of the item in the Supply, bill. It was frankly admitted by the friends of the Protectory that the money was for the maintenance of the juveniles cared for by the institution, and the question of a sewer, on which the application was originally based, was laid aside.

LONDON, March 15.--A terrific explosion occurred at 9 o'clock to-night in the office of the Local Government Board, Westminster, and caused the destruction of a great deal of property, but, fortunately, nobody was seriously hurt.

UNIONTOWN, March 15.--A blinding snowstorm did not cool off the indignation of the people of Fayette County who feel outraged over the acquittal of N.L. Dukes, the slayor of Capt. Nutt. ATLANTA, March 15.--The State Central Committee of the Republican Party met today. Fifty members were present, and Col. A.E. Buck, Chairman of the committee, presided. The session lasted from 3 until 7 o'clock, with, closed doors. The resolutions were adopted unanimously.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 21.--Telegrams from Kentville state that there is the greatest freshet known for years in the Cornwallis River. The Windsor and Annapolis Railway track is submerged and badly washed out for a distance of two miles east of Kentville station. At Wiswell's half a mile of track is three and a half feet under water.

The suit is for the recovery of the rents, revenues, and value for use of the property finally decreed as belonging to Mrs. Gaines, and known as the "Blanc tract," extending along Canal Carondelet from Dorgenois to the Bayon St. John, on a line running westward from Ursulines-street, and containing about 135 arpents.

At a meeting of the Central Labor Union yesterday afternoon William McCabe, on behalf of the committee appointed to call upon the Excise Commissioners and ask for a strict enforcement of the Excise law, said that the Commissioners had told the committee that the Police were wrong in stopping the sale of liquors after 1 o'clock in Madison-Square Garden on the occasion of the working men's ball there, ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 23.--About seven years ago a woman named McCready, who lived in a squatter's shanty in Westmoreland County, about 40 miles east of this city, suddenly disappeared. She had no friends, and little search was made for her.

WASHINGTON, March 25.--The news of the death of Postmaster-General Howe was not received here until late this afternoon and only gained limited circulation this evening. It was received with much surprise and sorrow.

Of the external merits of these new volumes little can here be said in addition to what has already been said of the earlier ones in the same edition. They are handsomely printed from large and noble type. They are bound substantially, and their covers are in all ways tasteful as to color and design.

CINCINNATI, March 25.--"We are all right over the canal," said an active Republican to-night, which means that in his opinion, and it is shared by all the Republican leaders, the German vote is once more secure. With the Germans in their places the Republicans have rarely failed of winning a handsome victory.

"It may not have been 50 years ago," said a gentlemen whose years did not seem to warrant the belief that he was in active life much longer than 50 years ago," and it may have been longer, when Dr. Linn was the colleague of Col. Benton in the United States Senate.

From 6 o'clock yesterday morning until 9 o'clock masses were sung in St. Patrick's Cathedral every hour for the administration of the sacrament of the holy communion to the members of the congregation. At 10:30 o'clock the Easter solemn pontificial mass was celebrated with the most impressive ceremonies known in the Church ritual.

PARIS, March 10.--I cannot foresee the finale of my letter. Perhaps to-morrow's sun may set upon a tragedy; perhaps the expected manifestation may end in nothing, as did that of yesterday; but, let me add, as that of yesterday might not have ended if the weather had been less inclement.

About 150 delegates from various Irish societies met yesterday afternoon at Germania Hall, in Third-avenue, for the purpose of making arrangements to receive Charles Stewart Parnell on his arrival in this country. The delegates succeeded in transacting no business, though they spent three hours in indulgence in petty quarrels.

Secretary Folger's physician reports at a late hour to-night that the condition of his patient is much improved. The Secretary is now suffering from erysipelas in the face and head, brought on by a severe cold. The disease is aggravated by lowered vitality and an impoverished condition of the blood, due to overwork and imperfect nutrition, but it is not thought that there is, as yet, any reason for especial apprehension.

Dr. McCOSH is a failure, and it is useless to attempt to disguise the fact. He came to this country with no little reputation as a philosopher and an educator; and, moreover, he had been favorably mentioned in a ballad by the late Mr. THACKERAY. That he is no philosopher has been clearly demonstrated.

"In the name of our God we will set up our banner," said the Rev. Samuel T. Graham, reading from the Twentieth Psalm, before a congregation of 500 persons in Association Hall, at Market and Washington streets, in Newark, yesterday morning.

The New-York Senate has passed a bill intended to abridge the liberty of the press. Senator KOCH, of this City, introduced the bill on Friday last. It was referred to the Judiciary Committee, favorably reported, and passed.

LONDON, March 14.--Winter has returned. It came in with a snow-storm a week back. The downfall was slight, however. The wind and sun have saved the authorities the trouble of clearing it away. Oddly euough, while it is very cold, we have still quite a remarkable amount of sunshine, and the Spring flowers insist upon blooming, though a trifle pinched and dowdy in appearance.
WASHINGTON, March 25.--The Sunday Chronicle to-day prints the following letter from Gov. B.F. Butler with regard to the enforcement of the Eight-hour law:
"Marketing" will be the subject of a lecture to be deliverod by Miss Maria Parioa, at 2 o'clock to-morrow afternoon, at the College of Pharmacy, in East Twenty-third-street, near Third-avenue.

Every seat in Trinity Church was occupied and hundreds of chairs were placed in the aisles to accommodate the early comers who could not find seats in the pews. Several hundreds stood in the aisles and in the vestibules throughout the two hours' service. Nearly as many as found entrance to the edifice went away, unable even to get to the doors.

ST. LOUIS, March 25.--J.A. Blackman, a postal clerk on the Missouri Pacific Railroad, was arrested yesterday afternoon for embezzling sample packages of merchandise sent through the mails. Blackman has been a long time in the postal railway service, and is an ex-member of the Kansas Legislature.

WASHINGTON, March 25.--James B. Price, whose deposition in the civil suit of John A. Walsh against Thomas J. Brady was published this morning, was one of the leading star route contractors in the contract term of 1878-82, and it was in relation to one of his routes that the original complaint of Jerome J. Hinds was made.

DENVER, Col., March 25.--There are in the Territory of New-Mexico about 2,000 persons belonging to the Hermanos Penitentes, a fanatical religious sect who believe in the periodical atonement of sin by inflicting on their bodies agonizing tortures. They were originally connected with the Roman Catholic Church, but Archbishop Laney, ...

In spite of the unusual number of entertainments last night, the twelfth popular concert at the Casino was attended by a large and appreciative audience. The programme was, generally speaking, interesting. The solo performers were Miss. Emma Juch, Mme. Galassi, Mlle. Ravasz, Signor Ravelli, Signor Caravatti, and the ever-smiling Mr. Jules Levy.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 25.--The news from Thibodeaux to-night is that, after the incessant labor of hundreds of volunteer plantation hands and others all night and all day, the break was closed this afternoon, very little damage having resulted. This work was followed by a fall of the water in the Bayou Lafourche of about 20 inches after 6 o'clock last night.

The New-York lodge of The Growlers, an order as yet confined to the cities of Washington and New-York, held its fourth annual banquet at the Utah House, at Eighth-avenue and Twentyfifth-street, last evening. One hundred and fifty gentlemen bearing this amiable name sat down to a feast so satisfactory that even a growler could find nothing to object to. Chief Growler John H. Conway presided, and was assisted ...

Easter dawned serene and beautiful upon the City yesterday. The sun shone bright and clear, the wind blew gently from the south, and the atmosphere was mild and pleasant, and these favorable circumstances brought out the Easter church pageant of beauty and fashion in all its brilliancy and glory.
CHICAGO, March 26.--The leading produce markets were rather quiet to-day and irregularly steadier. Provisions ended about as they began, and gain averaged easier but without weakness.

In the suit of John W. Greene, owner of premises at the north-western corner of Hudson and Laight streets, against the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company a motion was made to dismiss the complaint on Thursday last. Argument upon it was closed on Friday, and Judge Freedman yesterday denied it.

The opening of the new Star Theatre--or, rather, the reopening of Mr. Wallack's old theatre, which has been turned suddenly from its Teutonic course--was an interesting event last evening. The Star Theatre will be directed by Mr. Wallack and his associates, and its name defines its purpose.

WASHINGTON, March 26.--The President saw no visitors to-day, Monday being his day of seclusion. He is represented as being very deeply affected by the death of PostmasterGeneral Howe, for whom he entertained a strong personal regard.

BRAIDWOOD, Ill., March 26.--The work of recovering the bodies of the 75 coal miners who were drowned at the Diamond shaft, near this city, on Feb. 16, by the shaft being flooded, began last night, after 38 days of incessant pumping. Thousands of people flocked to the shaft all day.

A series of pernicious amendments to the Sunday clauses of the Penal Code was adopted by the Senate last week. These amendments have not been called for by the public, and are in no sense for the public interest, but have evidently been drawn un at the suggestion and for...

A meeting of the Board of Police Justices was held in the Jefferson Market Police Court last evening, Justice Kilbreth presiding. On motion of Justice Smith a rule was adopted which provides that "all complaints of Sabbath-breaking shall be preferred at the Police court in the district in which the defendant resides or transacts business."

Crush hats, such as the beaus wear at the opera, sat upon the heads of the millions who helped the riders onto their horses and held the paper baloons for them to turn somersaults through in Barnum's circus at the Madison-Square Garden last night.
WASHINGTON, March 26.--The following business was transacted in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day:

PITTSBURG, March 26.--The firm of C.P. Markle Sons, paper-makers, made an assignment to-day. All sorts of rumors are in circulation concerning the event, which took the community completely by surprise. The following statement of the Assignee, Jesse H. Lippencott, covers all the points so far as they are known.

LOUISVILLE, March 26.--Gov. Crittenden, of Missouri, arrived in this city this morning to testify in the libel suit of G. Hite against the Courier-Journal Company. This trial, which has been in progress for a week or more, has been at times of a very sensational nature, as it developed facts and incidents in the career of Jesse James and his gang not before known.

The Seventy-first Regiment fair in aid of the new armory and regimental fund was opened last evening with a flourish of trumpets and an address by Mayor Edson at the old armory at Broadway and Thirty-fifth-street. Over 2,000 persons were present, and the gallant soldier boys paraded in large numbers, encouraged by the smiles of scores of pretty girls in bright dresses and pink and blue ribbons.

The Railroad Commissioners of the State, Messrs. John D. Kernan, William E. Rogers, and John O'Donnell, began yesterday morning, at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce, an investigation into the financial history of the elevated railroads of the City.

In the midst of life we are in the midst of all sorts of things. This time-honored proverb is conspicuously illustrated by certain statistics recently published concerning the secret society known as the Independent Order of Odd-fellows.

The Vanderbilt ball has agitated New-York society more than any social event that has occurred here in many years. Since the announcement that it would take place, which was made about a week before the beginning of Lent, scarcely anything else has been talked about.

Recent large jewelry robberies in different parts of the country have incited the retail jewelers of this City, Philadelphia, and other Eastern cities to organize a movement for the better protection of retail jewelry stores throughout the United States.
Republican politicians at Albany and elsewhere in this State are quick to see that the preposterous blundering of the Democrats in the Legislature is producing a revulsion of popular feeling.

DUBLIN, March 26.--The Freeman's Journal states that the correspondence which has passed between the Home Office and Mr. Lowell, the United States Minister has resulted in the former renouncing all hope of securing the extradition of the person known as "Number One."

Dr. R.C. Brandeis read a paper on "Catarrhal Headaches and Allied Affections" before the New-York County Medical Society last night. Following the paper came the election of three delegates to the State Medical Society. At the meeting of the State society in February, 1882, a new code of ethics was adopted...
ALBANY, March 26.--Senator Koch this evening attempted to get a reconsideration of his bill which passed the Senate on Friday changing the law on the subject of libel.

Absolute harmony does not prevail among the milk-dealers of New-York, Jersey City, and Brooklyn. The price agreed upon by the conferference committee representing the independent milkmen and the producers last Saturday is not satisfactory to all of the former class.

It is impossible to recall, just now, the number of times which "Rigoletto" has been represented in New-York, neither would it be very profitable to print a list of names of the artists (many of them more or less celebrated) who have...

LONDON, March 26.--Queen Victoria was able to-day to attend the baptism of the infant daughter of the Duke and Duchess of Albany. The Queen was wheeled to the chapel in a chair. After the baptismal ceremony she received the guests in the green drawing-room.

BOSTON, March 26.--The text of the letter sent by the Hon. N.A. Plympton, of Worcester, to Gov. Butler, declining the nomination of Insurance Commissioner, and the reply of the Governor thereto will be published in the morning.

Mr. Hosea B. Perkins, the graceful afterdinner speaker of the Washington Heights Century Club and silver-tongued orator of Tammany, came very near being called upon to climb the golden stair at the solemn hour of midnight last Sabbath evening.

PANAMA, March 17.--Dr. Francisco Garcia Calderon, who is a prisoner in Chili, has addressed a long note to Dr. Logan, in which he objects to the dispatch addressed by the latter to Admiral Montero and objects to its having been given publicity.
In the death of the late TIMOTHY O. HOWE, layer, Judge, Senator, and Cabinet officer, has passed away one of the few remaining politicians of the old school identified with recent American history.

WASHINGTON, March 26.--The Secretary of the Interior has to-day addressed the following interesting letter to the Commissioner of the General Land Office in regard to the occupation of large tracts of Indian lands in Kansas by stock men:

LOCKPORT, N.Y., March 26.--In the Niagara County Sessions, Judge Davis presiding, sentences were imposed to-day on convicted criminals, as follows: William Hamilton, a Scotchman, of 30 years, and a machinist by occupation, convicted of forging an order for $5, was sentenced to Auburn State Prison for two years and two months.

PANAMA, March 17.--Dictator Vintimilla continues in hot water in Guayaquil. Signor Alcides Destruge is Consul at the port for the United States of America, for the Kingdom of Italy, and for Venezuela.

Passengers on the Newark and New-York Railroad have at times during the past few weeks caught occasional glimpses in the distance of an electric motor spinning along on a private track near Greenville.

The Congregational Club dined at the Rossmore Hotel last night and listened to a few addresses on the subject of prison reform. President Roswell Smith presided, and the following named gentlemen were present:

WASHINGTON, March 26.--It is reported to-night that the Grand Jury, which has been in session here for some time, has found indictments against ex-Senator W.P. Kellogg and Thomas J. Brady in the star route cases arising under the Price contracts. There are said to be several indictments, and it is expected that the Grand Jury will bring them into court to-morrow.

ST. LOUIS, March 26.--The trial of Russell Brown for the murder of his grandmother, Mrs. Gen. Dorris, was commenced in the Criminal Court to-day, Judge Van Wagoner refusing to accept Brown's plea of guilty of manslaughter in the third degree, which was accompanied by an offer to accept 10 years in the penitentiary.
Through the generosity of Mr. Peter Cooper, type-writing has recently been added to the free studies at the Cooper Union.

Frederic Bill, a stockholder of the Gold and Stock Telegraph Company, filed a bill to set aside a lease of its property and franchise to the Western Union Telegraph Company and others for 93 years, and then moved for an injunction, pendente lite, to restrain the lessee from disposing of the property acquired.

ALBANY, March 26.--The Republican minority in the Assembly startled the Democrats and somewhat astonished itself to-night by finding its legs and standing up to secure the rights to which it is entitled.

ALBANY, March 26.--The Republican minority in the Assembly startled the Democrats and somewhat astonished itself to-night by finding its legs and standing up to secure the rights to which it is entitled.

Joseph Siegrist, the veteran speculator in tickets for the Italian opera, appeared last evening on the platform of Chickering Hall and delivered a lecture entitled "Reminiscences of Italian Opera in America."

READING, Penn., March 27.--The differences between the Schuylkill and Lehigh Railroad bondholders and the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company have been adjusted, the latter agreeing to reduce the original amount of bonds from $1,000,000 to $600,000, canceling $400,000, and to pay the holders of the $600,000 4 per cent. up to May, and 4 per cent. thereafter.

The extensive library of the late Charles I. Bushnell, comprising rare and curious books, engravings, autographs, and historical relies, will be sold at auction by the Messrs. Bangs Co., of No. 739 Broadway, on Monday, April 2, and the four following days.

Edwin Harvey Wadge, alias Capt. Archer, held for extradition on a charge a of forgery committed in London in November last, was brought before Judge Brown, in the United States District Court, on habeas corpus and certiorari proceedings.
E.G. Wiechmann Co., woolen jobbers, at Broadway and Grand-street, made an assignment yesterday to Claus Frederick Hinck, of Hinck Brothers, No. 55 Worth-street.

LONG BRANCH, March 27.--The New-Jersey Methodist Episcopal Conference, which has been in session here for the past week, concluded its labors and adjourned to-day. The following appointments were announced:

About 100 ladies, with a sprinkling of gentlemen, listened to Miss Maria Parloa's lecture on "Marketing," in the lecture-room of the College of Pharmacy, yesterday afternoon. Marketing had reference only to the buying of meat, and was illustrated by a side of beef and a young butcher, who looked like a theological student, who dissected the same.
BOSTON, March 27.--At the annual meeting of the Bell Telephone Company, held here to-day, the reports made showed the rapidity of the development of the business the past year.
BELEFAST, March 27.--The jury have rendered a verdict of guilty in the case of the six members of the Armagh Assassination Society, who were placed on trial here yesterday.

The action taken yesterday by the Grand Jury in Washington adds to the list of defendants in star route cases to be tried hereafter a well-known and skillful politician, who has for some time been regarded by keen observers as a favorite of fortune.

HARRISBURG, March 27.--The sub-committee of the House Judiciary General Committee, to which was committed the task of inquiring into the right of N.L. Dukes, of Fayette County, to a seat in the House, held a meeting this evening at 5 o'clock.

While passing through West Twenty-thirdstreet yesterday afternoon, Detective Sergeant Frink saw two professional thieves--Thomas Rielly, alias Henry Harrison, and Frederick Harrison, alias "Doc" Burnton, walking ahead of him. He followed and saw them enter the clothing store of Wade Cummings, under the Grand Opera-house.

FOND DU LAC, Wis., March 27.--Investigation into the affairs of the lumber firm of Paige Brothers, of Davenport, Iowa, one partner in which recently committed suicide, causes unexpected developments, and the liabilities of the firm are now declared to exceed $500,000.
George H. Conkling, Jr., who shot and killed William H. Haverstick on March 19, appeared before Police Justice Smith for formal examination in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday afternoon.

BOSTON, March 27.--The case of the Union Pacific against the Credit Mobilier was before the full bench of the Supreme Court to-day, with the exception of the Chief-Justice and Judge Coburn, who take no part in the proceedings, as they are interested in the Union Pacific as holders of its bonds.

Five long tables ware spread in the banquet hall at Delmonico's last night, where the annual dinner of the College of Pharmacy took place. Covers were laid for 150 persons, Dr. D.H.J. Menninger, the toast-master, sat at the head of the main table, and on a confectionery elevation before him was a deadly looking mortar and pestle.

ALBANY, March 27.--The unwillingness of Democrats to allow a full, fair, and free discussion of the merits of civil service reform was illustrated this morning in the Assembly when Mr. Howe attempted to have some action taken on the Pendleton bill, now buried somewhere in several orders. It seems as if the Democrats were determined to adjourn without taking any notice or this important question.

At the monthly meeting of the Council of Reform on Monday evening the principal business was the discussion and adoption of a bill for the appointment of a commission to take into immediate consideration the subject of furnishing this City with an additional supply of water.

Judge Freedman decided, in Superior Court, Chambers, yesterday, that the lease of the property of the Mutual union Telegraph Company's by the Western Union Telegraph Company had not been properly ratified by the stockholders of the latter corporation.

During the first Administration of the first President of the United States, WASHINGTON, as we are credibly informed by the historians of that remote period, was considerably troubled with his Cabinet appointments.
CHICAGO, March 27.--The second game of the balk-line tournament was played this afternoon in Central Music Hall, William Sexton and Alonzo Morris being the contestants.
Bob-tail cars are to be abandoned on Franklin-avenue, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, March 27.--The politicians who linger about the Capitol are exercising their minds a good deal to find a man whom they regard as a proper successor to the late Postmaster-General Howe.

There is a reason why the contest over the Speakership of the next House of Representatives should begin so many months before the Speaker is to be chosen and should be waged somewhat warmly, for in it is involved the position to be taken by the Democratic Party on more than one important public question.

WASHINGTON, March 27.--Judge French, acting as Secretary of the Treasury, has addressed a letter to the Secretary of State on the subject of the proposed modification of Canadian regulations in regard to the importation of bonded whisky from the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 27.--The Commissioner of Internal Revenue has finished the preparation of a circular, which will be sent to Collectors and other interested persons, with regard to the reduction of the tax on tobacco and the regulations of the department concerning claims for rebate.

The American Athletic Club gave an interesting gymnastic exhibition in Turn Hall, in Fourthstreet, last evening, which was observed and appreciated by a large and intensely emotional aggregation of spectators, who were swayed by their feelings to the utterance of every species of vocal encouragement, disapprobation, and enthusiasm.

CHICAGO, March 27.--The leading produce markets to-day were not active, but firm. Grain held up well--in spite of reports of rain in California--for wheat, and a more liberal inspection of corn here than ever before, while provisions were firmer, with some fears of manipulation, especially in lard.

Gilbert and Sullivan's satire on the aesthetic craze of the day in the shape of their tuneful and picturesque opera "Patience" is revived this week at the Standard Theatre where it first won its success.

MUSKOGEE, Indian Territory, March 27.-- Gen. Porter has disbanded his forces, and they have gone home, with the exception of a few scouts, leaving the United States troops to capture Spiechee and his men.

The large hall of Cooper Union was about two-thirds filled last evening with members of the Central Labor Union, who held a mass-meeting to protest against convict labor; to agitate the necessity of a new charter for the City, and other matters of interest to working men.

The comic opera company of which Miss Catherine Lewis is the life and soul, and which is named for her, have come back to New-York for a brief season. "Olivette," always a favorite of its class, has been selected for the first, half of this week.

The survivors of the ill-fated Jeannette expedition arrived yesterday morning at 9:30 o'clock on the steamer Wesphalia, of the Hamburg Line. The party consisted of Ensign Henry J. Hunt and Seamen Herbert Wood Leach, James H. Bartlett, Frank Manson, and John Lauterback.

Soon after the Aldermen had been called to order at their regular meeting yesterday a Message was received from Mayor Edson returning without his approval the resolution passed March 13 permitting the New-York Electric Lines Company to lay wires or other conductors of electricity in and through the streets of the City. In the veto the Mayor Says:

BURLINGTON, Vt., March 27.--In the United States Court here to-day the celebrated Vermont Central Railroad litigation was brought to an end. In the cases of Francis A. Brooks and other holders of the first mortgage bonds against the Vermont Central Railroad and others, a decree of foreclosure was entered by arrangement between the litigants, and the other cases, eight in number, were discontinued.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 27.--The following gentlemen will act as pall-bearers at the funeral of the late Pastmaster-General Howe: Chief-Justice Cole, Gov. Rusk, Secretary Lincoln. Secretary Teller, Horace Rublee, of the Milwaukee Sentinel; Senator Sawyer, and Frank M. Hatton. The Rev. Robert Collyer, of New-York, and the Rev. H.M. Simons, of Minneapolis, are expected to act as officiating clergymen.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27.--Early this morning, after the guards who patrol the corridors of the Eastern Penitentiary all night had been relieved, a convict, Charles Deckert, calling himself Frank Mishler, was found dead in his cell hanging by the neck from a gas-bracket.

A large assemblage of the advocates of temperance gathered in the Brooklyn Academy of Music last evening, the occasion being a reception tendered to Mr. Eli Johnson, a prominent advocate of the temperance cause, who has just returned from a tour in Australia.

Leases were signed yesterday which give to James H. Breslin, of the Gilsey House, the control of the Manhattan Beach property at Coney Island, including both the Manhattan Beach and Oriental Hotels, for the coming season.

WASHINGTON, March 27.--Mr. Ingersoll continued his examination of Mr. Dorsey this morning. He was asked if he knew whether he had drawn any check for $7,000 upon Middleton Co., in June, 1879, as described by Rerdell.

BUFFALO, March 27.--The work of getting a jury for the trial of Thomas Waldron was completed in the Court of Oyer and Terminer to-day. Waldron is the Christian brother known as "Brother Frank," who has been the head of St. Joseph's Catholic College in this city, and who is under indictment for assault on Hattie Carr, a girl of 6 years.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., March 27.--THE TIMES of Feb. 10 contained a summary of the points upon the trial before Judge Lewis of the action of The People ex rel. Hubbell, Storrs, and Fergason against McCollum and Balcom, to oust defendants from the office of Commissioners of Excise of the city of Lockport.

The Martin Luther Society of New-York City was organized at Mott Memorial Hall last evening. About 60 gentlemen, representing the Gustavus Adolphus, Epiphany, St. Matthew's, St. James's, Trinity, St. Luke's, St. John's, St. Peter's, and Christ Churches were in attendance.

Plymouth Church has protested "in the name of GOD, of liberty, and of republicanism" against French interference with the internal affairs of the island of Madagascar, and a great many amiable missionaries and other well-meaning persons have expressed their sympathy with the objects the Malagassy envoys hope to gain by their visit to this country and their indignation at the wanton and aggressive conduct of France.

ALBANY, March 27.--The Assembly Committee on Cities gave a hearing this evening to the bill modifying the charter of the Broadway Underground Railroad Company so as to permit the construction of the road on the arcade plan.

Alderman Kirk introduced in the Common Council yesterday a preamble and resolution directing the Corporation Counsel to begin proceedings to secure the forfeiture to the Board of Supervisors, now the Board of Aldermen, of the rights and franchises of the Manhattan Railway Company.
ALBANY, March 27.--The bill that has passed the Assembly to "suppress political assessments," and which was lost in the Senate, was reconsidered to-day on the motion of Mr. Pitts.

PITTSBURG, March 27.--The failure of C.P. Markle Co. is, perhaps, the most remarkable and surprising mercantile event that ever took place in this city.
LONDON, March 27.--It is stated that the Marquis of Lorne, upon his return to England from Canada, will be raised to the peerage.
Mr. John McCullough will begin shortly an engagement at Nible's Garden. Miss Annie Pixley will appear on the nights of this week, at Nible's Garden, in "M'liss."
Bishop Potter will administer the rite of confirmation this evening in St. Phillip's Church, in Mulberry-street.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., March 28.--The orderloving and law-abiding people of this place are justly indignant over the neglect of the authorities in not attempting to bring to punishment a gang of ruffians who destroyed a numher of the ballots here on the day of the town election.

BOSTON, March 28.--The Herald to-morrow will say: "Negotiations for the purchase of the great organ in Music Hall have been concluded, and it will be removed during the coming Summer. It is not stated who the purchaser is or where it will be taken."

It may be considered as one of the curiosities of the times that the death of JOHN BROWN, the untitled son of a Scotch peasant, should be heralded as far as the mail and the telegraph can carry the tidings to English-speaking people.
The Republican City Convention of Passaic City has decided in favor of the renomination of Mayor Spencer, who inaugurated a year ago a system of street paving.

BOSTON, March 28.--The Malagassy envoys were visited this morning at the Tremont House by the Mayor and other officials, and afterward left for Salem. The envoys were received at Salem by large crowds. They visited the family of the late John Bertram, whose business relations with the island were extensive and long continued.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28.--Upon application of counsel for the Trustees of the Girard estate. Judge Allison to-day granted a preliminary injunction enjoining the Maxim Electric Light Company from erecting poles in Delaware-avenue, between Vine and South streets, notwithstanding the company had been authorized by the city to erect the poles.

MONTREAL, March 28.--The wife of Capt. Boxer, of the royal Navy, England, has arrived here with her husband to claim $225,000 settled upon her by her adopted father, the late Henry Judah, Queen's Counsel.

Paterson has nearly 600 liquor saloons selling liquor under the authority of the License Committee of the Board of Aldermen, which committee grants licenses to all comers who pay $35 per year for the privilege.
