ROCHESTER, March 28.--Seth Green's condition to-day is about the same as yesterday. Insomnia is now the worst feature in his case, and he is quite exhausted and restless. His physicians think, however, that he will recover.

NASHVILLE, March 28.--William C. Woodward, arrested on the charge of passing goldplated nickels as five-dollar gold pieces, was taken to St. Louis to-night for trial. In order to prevent the prisoner from suing out a writ of habeas corpus Detective Bauer swore out a warrant, which was immediately served.

HARRISBURG, March 28.--Dukes, the assassin, has himself solved the problem which has for some days occupied the attention of the House of Representatives in general, and its Law Committee in particular, and which for a greater length of ...
PITTSBURG, March 28.--An important meeting of the Western Nail Association was held in this city this morning. All the mills in the district were represented.
OTTAWA March 28.--The dog show was well attended to-day. It closed tonight, and its success in every respect is generally conceded by sportsmen. The judges have not yet concluded their labors.

BOSTON, March 28.--A majority of the Legislative Committee on Election Laws will report a revolution providing for such a change in the Constitution that the poll-tax shall not be levied and collected as a qualification to the right to vote. A minority report will also be submitted. The House this afternoon passed, by a vote of 133 to 64, the bill providing for biennial elections for State officers and biennial sessions of the Legislature.

TRENTON, March 28.--In the United States Circuit Court to-day Judge Nixon made an important decision in the case of the Bell Telephone Company against Andrew Albright and John J. Ghegan, of Newark. Ghegan claimed to have invented a telephone which was used by the People's Telephone and Telegraph Company, and a line ...
PITTSBURGH, March 28.--A disastrous conflagration, in which two children were burned to death, occurred in the Eleventh Ward of Allegheny this morning.
J.H. Devereux, of Cleveland, is at the Windsor Hotel. The Hon. Henry S. Sanford, of Florida, is at the Brevoort House.

DUBLIN, March 28.--The Freeman's Journal says the escape of "Number One" will probably be discussed in the House of Commons to-morrow. The Journal asserts that the Police allowed him to escape because they knew his arrest would reveal matters weakening the evidence given by James Carey.

The fight between the Orange County milk producers and the milk-dealers of this City is not yet quite over. It is claimed by the dealers that there is a very large supply of milk at present, and the mild weather will prevent the farmers from storing it up. Mr. J.A. Ferris told a TIMES reporter that he had bought 17 cans of milk at the Erie ...
In the suit of The People against the Metropolitan Telegraph and Telephone Company a motion was made before Judge Barrett, in Supreme Court, Circuit, yesterday, for a decree directing ...

BOSTON, March 28.--The Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston was organized this afternoon as follows: Ex-Gov. A.H. Rice, President; Directors--W.A. Tower, Theodore Dean, Charles Babbidge. George P. Denny, R.B. Hallowell, and W.L. Garrison; Clerk and Treasurer--W.L. Garrison; General Manager--C.D. Stickney. The capital is $1,000,000. A central lighting station will be immediately established in the business portion of the city with a capacity of 20,000 lights.

The German ship Else, Capt. Fennekahl, which arrived yesterday from Liverpool, had one of the longest passages on record. Her voyage occupied 102 days. Capt. Fennekahl reports that he left Liverpool on Dec. 16 last. Variable head winds and gales set in, and on Jan. 24 Capt. Fennekahl found himself in latitude 50 39' and longitude 26 .

The recognition of the merits of civil service reform by Gen. A.P. Ketcham, Appraiser of the Port of New-York, in the appointment of a Board of Examiners in his department, before which persons desiring positions might prove their fitness, is now supplemented by an opportunity for showing the practical working of this movement.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 28.--Democratic primaries to-night, in preparation for city and ward election Monday next, were very largely attended, and the utmost interest is taken in the convention to be held on Friday and the election three days after.

There has been a great gathering of railroad men at Troy within the last few days to see two elegant and novel cars that are just about to be shipped to Australia. Among the railroad magnates who were attracted to the shops by the announcement that the cars were ready for shipment were Mr. Tillinghast, of the New-York Central and the Wagner Car Company; Mr. J.W. Hobart, General Superintendent of the Central Vermont Railroad;...

Mr. Roscoe, one of Davidson County's Representatives, wrote the following explanation of his vote to table the amendment offered by Mr. Hawkins to the State Debt bill excluding the bonds of Mrs. Polk from payment dollar for dollar:

TUCSON, Arizona, March 28.--The Indian situation is growing serious. Advices from Silver City say that a party which arrived there from San Carlos report that the young bucks on the San Carlos Reservation were very restless last week, and there was every evidence of an early outbreak.

Frank Byrne, who has posed as one of the Irish patriots, especially since his arrest in Paris on suspicion of being concerned in the CavendishBurke assassination in Phoenix Park, Dublin, arrived in this City yesterday on the steamer Amerique, of the General Transatlantic Line. Mr. Byrne was accompanied by his wife. He is at present stopping with his sister, Mrs. Peter ...

ALBANY, March 28.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruger, Chief Justice, presiding, the following business was transacted: No. 105--In the matter of the claim of William H. Flandrow, a creditor of Tunis Van Brunt; argued by Joseph H. Choate for appellant, George Zabriskie for respondent. Day calendar for Thursday: Nos 73, 108, 653, 651, 654, 29, 107, 74.
The correct pronunciation of the name of the distinguished Mexican now visiting the United States is as though spelled dee-as.--Chicago Tribune.

NASHVILLE, March 28.--J.P. Walker, a sporting man, of Louisville, was found dead in bed this morning at Linck's Hotel. The Coroner held held an inquest over the body, and the evidence showed that he had been suffering of late with rheumatism, and was taking morphine for its relief. He is supposed to have taken an overdose and from its effects died during the night.

LONDON, March 29.--The steam-ship Polynesian, (Ger.,) Capt. Kuhne, from New-York March 12, has arr. at Hamburg. The steam-ship Turquoise. (Br.,) Capt. Ellis, from Baltimore March 10, has arr. at Waterford.

E.W. Brueninghausen, Chairman of the Memorial Committee of the Grand Army of the Republic of this City, had a very encouraging interview yesterday with Mayor Low, of Brooklyn, in relation to the veterans taking part in an official opening of the bridge on Decoration Day.

CHICAGO, March 28.--The leading produce markets were more irregular than usual to-day, but generally stronger. Corn and lard advanced rather sharply, and that acted on other articles, though there was not much demand except for flax-seed. Another snow-storm tended to stiffen prices in grain.
OTTAWA, March 28.--It is understood that Sir Leonard Tilley, instead of prohibiting the exportation of game, as asked by the Sporting Men's Convention, will place an export duty on game.

A plan has been suggested by the Committee of Five of the holders of the first mortgage consolidated bonds of the New-York City and Northern Railroad for the reorganization of the road, which is at present in the hands of a Receiver. The proposition is that the present first mortgage shall be foreclosed. In the reorganization, it is proposed to make the new mortgage equal to the present--

The result of the annual town elections in the 22 towns of Westchester County on Tuesday changes the political complexion of the Board of Supervisors from Republican by two majority to Democratic by at least six majority.
William F. Seidler, a saloon-keeper who did business at Market and Lawrence streets, Newark, ommitt ed suicide at his home, on Pacific-street, during Tuesday night.

EASTON, Penn., March 28.--The Lutheran ministers in this portion of Pennsylvania met here yesterday, and have held several sessions discuss ing the question of having an episcopate in the Lutheran Church in America. As a preparatory step papers were read showing the state of the episcopate in the early Church and in the German ...
CINCINNATI, March 28.--The thirty-fourth annual report of the pork-packing in the West, by the Cincinnati Price Current, will be printed tomorrow.
LONDON, March 28.--The Times anticipates that Mr. Childers, Chancellor of the Exchequer, will have on hand on the 3lst inst., the end of the current financial year, a minimum surplus of 1,500,000.

The funeral of Dr. William H. Van Buren was held yesterday morning at St. Patrick's Cathe dral. The body was inclosed in a mahogany coffin, which rested on a heavily draped catafalque, in the centre aisle, directly in front of the altar. The coffin was covered with flowers.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, March 28.--Yesterday morning a young woman, who passed as Miss Delia Brown, died at the Revere House, in this city. This excited no particular interest until late last night, when the authorities began an investigation. This forenoon the fact was established that she died from the effects of an abortion.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 28.--The jury in the Hite libel suit against the Courier-Journal Company returned a verdict for the defense to-day. It is universally said that the testimony of Gov. Crittenden, of Missouri, brought about the result.

The business men and property-owners of Coenties-slip and its vicinity, who are making an effort to have the land recently filled in at the foot of the slip converted into a public park, met yesterday afternoon at No. 7 Coenties-slip.

A few months ago the Democrats of Portsmouth, N.H., picked out the only ex-rebel soldier in their city and elected him Mayor. He is a native of the town, but removed to Mobile, Ala., shortly before the breaking out of the war, and went into business there, being then about 25 years of age. When the State of Alabama seceded he voluntarily enlisted as a private in Company B, of the Alabama ...

WASHINGTON, March 28.--Stephen W. Dorsey's testimony in the star route case was heard to-day by a large crowd of spectators, but not by so many as to fill the court-room, Judge Wylie continuing his sensible order to prevent the attendance of the idle and filthy court loafers, who formerly packed the small apartment to suffocation.
ATLANTA, Ga., March 28.--Gen. J.B. Gordon, ex-United States Senator, has written the following letter concerning a recent publication in certain leading newspapers:
Mr. Daniel O'Leary, the long-distance pedestrian, has arrived in Melbourne, Australia, and has wagered 300 to 200 that he will defeat Edwards, an Australian pedestrian, in a six days' walk.

At a special meeting of the members of the Lee-Avenue Congregational Church, Brooklyn, Eastern District, last evening, the resignation of the Pastor, the Rev. Wilbur F. Crafts, was accepted, to take effect Saturday next.

In the trial of Lee Hung for arson, which is now in progress in Department One of the Superior Court, many Chinese witnesses have been examined. It is well known that when a Chinaman is called to testify in court he never understands a word of English, notwithstanding that if he were to meet a person on the street he could make himself as intelligible as many Americans.
Very successful experiments in telephoning between this City and Chicago, a distance of about 1,000 miles, were made yesterday afternoon in the office of the Postal Telegraph Company.

Said a noted housewife and housekeeper: "Oh dear, what shall we do about servants? Bad servants are the bane of keeping house. The colored servant grows steadily worse. She is uncleanly, wasteful, pilfering, careless, and story-telling. She robs me unsparingly to feed her children, or her sisters, or her friends, or to give away.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 28.--The Senate, by a vote of 23 to 7, passed the bill creating a Railroad Commission. The provisions of the bill do not apply to uncompleted railroads or roads hereafter to be constructed until after 10 years shall have expired after the completion of such roads.

Four New-York artists, Messrs. W.C. Bauer, W.H. Coughlin, George C. Wright, and J.W., Rough, gave a novel and interesting exhibition of rapid sketching last evening at the School of Industrial Art for Women, No. 251 West Twentythird-street, for the benefit of the school.

The promoter of legislative jobbery carefully sows his seed while the work of a session of Congress is slowly assuming form. He does not hail the appearance of the tender shoot with the music of a brass band, but he has an eye upon it and patiently bides his time, knowing that in the hurly-burly ...

WASHINGTON, March 28.--Crowds of people were waiting at the entrances of the Criminal Court room this morning before the opening of the proceedings in the star route trial, but under the stringent regulations imposed by the Marshal few persons were admitted besides members of the Bar and others having business in the courtroom.

An interesting incident, developing further the peculiar characteristics of the late President Abraham Lincoln, was brought to light in the Adjutant-General's office, War Department, several days ago.
NASHVILLE, March 28.--The Hon. W. Houk is here in the interest of the Trustees of the National Home for Disabled Volunteer Soldiers of the United States, who own a number of Tennessee bonds.

Joshua L. Chamberlain, in 1861, was a Professor in Bowdoin College, Maine. When Sumter was fired on, the Governor of Maine offered this college Professor a place in a Maine regiment, not because he was a Professor, but because he knew he was a patriot of the old Joseph Warren fighting ...

WASHINGTON, March 28.--Adjt.-Gen. Drum has received a telegram from San Antonio, Texas, stating that Gen. Sackett, Inspector-General United States Army, was stricken with apoplexy at that place yesterday. No particulars as to his condition were given. Gen. Drum has telegraphed for full information.
ALBANY, March 28.--The following companies were incorporated to-day: The Debary Baya Merchants' Line for the navigation of the St. John's River in the State of Florida; capital, $200,000.

LAWRENCE, Mass., March 28.--At a special meeting of the stockholders of the Boston and Maine Railroad to-day, it was voted by a stock vote of 42,563 to 953, that approval be given to the lease of the Eastern Railroad by the Boston and Maine Company, of such tenor and upon such terms as have been agreed upon by the Directors.

The Paterson silk manufacturers are giving considerable attention to the probable effect on their business of the new law, which goes into effect on July 4 next, prohibiting the employment of persons under 14 years of age.

The Alumni of Lafayette College will hold a meeting at Delmonico's this evening at 8 o'clock. Richard Hart and William Clarke pleaded guilty to an attempt at burglary in the Court of General Sessions yesterday and were sentenced to eight years in State prison.

By invitation of Mayor Edson the members of the late Water Supply Committee met in the Mayor's private office yesterday to talk about the proposed bill providing for the construction of a new Croton Aqueduct.

Ex-Congressman, Bayless W. Hanna, of Terre Haute, Ind., has purchased the Crawfords ville (Ind.) Review, the Democratic organ of Montgomery County, and will assume full editorial and business control of it.

Democratic sentiment in the Legislature is beginning to show signs of division on the question of an early adjournment. That is one of the good things which the party has been promising, but it is doubtful whether it will be sufficient in itself to

PHILADELPHIA, March 28.--The denizens of an outlying section of the Twenty-eighth Ward were thrown into a high state of excitement this morning by the discovery of three ghastly wounds upon the person of a woman who was being laid out for burial and who it was supposed had died from pneumonia.

Victor Masse's opera, "Paul et Virginie," was sung at the Casino last night by Maurice Grau's company in the presence of a large and demonstrative audience. This opera was stated on the programme to be the composer's masterpiece, and the information was also given that it was written expressly for M. Victor Capoul and ...
HARTFORD, Conn., March 28.--In the House to-day the Consolidated Railroad bill passed by a large majority.

E.J. Courtney, alias Dr. James Brunell, alias Christopher Richards, alias "Little Jim," who is known to the Police as an expert and dangerous counterfeiter, was tried for forgery and convicted in the Court of General Sessions last June.

Apropos of the recent David Davis wedding I am reminded of a good story current here when Hayes was in the White House and Evarts was in the Department of State. Evarts and David Davis were antipodes in point of flesh, though fairly matched mentally.
During the past week 286 deaths, 174 births, and 36 marriages were recorded at the Brooklyn Board of Health office.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 28.--A man said to be Herbert W. Eaton, who discharged a revolver at his brother and his partner in business, Joseph E. Eaton and Samuel Kelly, Jr., in a livery stable at Calais, Me., a few days ago, wounding both, the latter fatally, was on the Quebec Express coming toward Halifax to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28.--At a meeting of the stockholders of the Permanent Exhibition Company, to-day, the committee to-day appointed to consider the question of winding up the affairs of the company reported in favor of an immediate dissolution.
NEW-ORLEANS, March 28.--In the election fraud case which has been on trial here the jury to-day returned a verdict of not guilty. The other cases were indefinitely postponed.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28.--The Society to Protect Children from Cruelty has vigorously set about the enforcement of the law govering the employment of minor children in mills and factories. A circular containing a copy of the act of Assembly is being prepared for publication.

LOCKPORT, March 28.--In the Niagara County Sessions to-day, Judge Davis presiding, James Blake, convicted yesterday of robbery, was arraigned for sentence. The prisoner, with two others, forcibly plundered a farmer of his money at a picnic, at Olcott, last August. He is a cigarmaker, of Lockport, 23 years old, with a wife and three children.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 28.--Few familiar faces were to be seen in the lobbies here to-night of the men who, two months ago, were exercising their influence in the lobbies of Congress in favor of an extension of the whisky bonding period. The commercial value of the Canadian Parliament has not yet been fixed.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 28.--The Executive Committee of the Triennial Conclave of Knights Templar held a conference with the hotel men yesterday. No definite conclusion was reached, and only two or three hotel-keepers would agree to accommodate any definite number of knights.

Angelo Cornetta was yesterday informed of the decision of the Court of Appeals affirming the conviction of murder in the first degree in his case for the killing of Daniel Cash in Sing Sing Prison. He will probably be resentenced to be hanged next Wednesday, when the Supreme Court reconvenes at White Plains.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., March 28.--The twentysixth session of the Newark Methodist Episcopal Conference began here in the Main-Street Church this morning, with about 150 delegates present and others coming in rapidly.
FREEHOLD, N.J., March 28.--In the new Board of Chosen Freeholders there is a Republican gain of one. The following are the names of the successful candidates: Neptune Township, John ...

Alonzo C. Yates, the Syracuse merchant, whose will is now under contest in the Surrogate's Court, was the husband of Anna E. Yates until 1870. He then procured a decree of absolute divorce from her, and soon afterward married hi cook, who will be the principal beneficiary from his will if it is upheld.
Capt. McCullough, of the schooner Anna, that arrived in port Monday from Honolulu, states that the recent great tidal wave that visited the island of Maul was a remarkable event.

ALBANY, March 28.--The prohibition question occupied the Senate the greater part of its session to-day, the measure under discussion being Mr. Thomas's concurrent resolution for an amendment to the Constitution prohibiting the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquor in this State. The opposition to the amendment was opened by Mr. Grady, who is personally a teetotaler, but who ...

S.F. Pierson, recently Commissioner of the Colorado Railway Association, and for many years continuously favorably known in connection with railroads, has been appointed Assistant Commissioner of the trunk lines to take charge of the Passenger Department, and will have his office at the head-quarters of the commission in this City. R.T. Bryden remains, as before, Secretary of the Passenger Department.

ST. LOUIS, March 28.--J.N. Peers, editor of the Collinsville (Ill.) Herald, was publicly horsewhipped in that town yesterday by Mrs. Henry Marshall, the wife of a well-known business man there, for the publication of an article which reflected upon herself, her husband, and her mother. Peers was badly marked about the face and neck by the heavy rawhide vigorously applied by the indignant lady.

A private exhibition was given in the Madison-Square Garden yesterday, afternoon by the Elliott family, who have been forbidden to perform in the Barnum show by the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, on the ground that the children are in danger of falling and breaking their legs.

Dr. H.D. Joy, of New-York, has been appointed Physician-in-Chief of the Sailors' Snug Harbor at New-Brighton, in place of the late Dr. C. Henry King. Dr. Bogart will continue to be Consulting Physician of the Institution.

ST. John, Newfoundland, March 28.--At Cape Race, about daylight to-day, a large barkentine was passed in the ice about a mile from shore, abandoned and apparently leaky. She must have struck Renew's Rook, off Cape Ballard, on her way along the shore, and the crew probably left her the first chance they had when the vessel was ...
WASHINGTON, March 28.--The following business was transacted in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day: No. 210--John L. Merriam, appellant, vs. The United States; argued.
MONTREAL, March 28.--The Government has granted a subsidy of $24,000 per annum to the monthly line of steamers between Antwerp and Canada.
COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, March 28.--John White, a young man, employed by Martin Son, expressmen, in this city, started for Spring Lake, two miles north of here, alone, on Sunday, to shoot wild ducks.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 28.--A special dispatch to the Times-Democrat from Atchafalaya, La., says: "The river is rising two inches per day. The passenger trains have been stopped between the river and Baton Rouge Junction, the water being over the track from one to three feet in depth. The new levees between Churchville and Simmsport are fast giving way, and one break has already been announced. Very few plantations along the river will escape the overflow."

The players engaged by the New-York League and Metropolitan Base-ball Clubs will report for duty at the Polo Grounds this afternoon. In the evening a reunion will be held in "The Club," No. 1,980 Third-avenue.

Donizetti's great opera is hardly as popular as might be expected from its many beautiful arias and scenes, probably on account of its generally sombre character. But when the principal roles are intrusted to such artists as appeared last night, Mme. Scalchi and Signori Ravelli and Monti, it affords almost continuous genuine musical enjoyment.

CLEVELAND, March 28.--The press dispatch sent out from Chicago this afternoon stating that 40 engineers on the Nickel Plate Road had struck because they had been ordered to work 12 hours a day instead of 10 is pronounced by general officers of Nickel Plate as untrue, and in their opinion some other road is intended.

WASHINGTON, March 28.--Minister and Mrs. John W. Foster, who have been with Gen. and Mrs. Diaz and party for the past 10 days, gave a tea party at their residence here this afternoon in honor of this company of dis tinguished Mexicans.

Tha gamblers and policy men who have been doing business in the Twenty-ninth Police Precinct became greatly alarmed yesterday over a rumor that Anthony Comstock had secured sufficient evidence against them to procure 10 warrants for raiding as many places, and nearly all of them have packed up their movable property and stored it away to await results.

Mr. George W. Cable has been lecturing with some success before the Johns Hopkins University, of Baltimore. Charles Reinig, a young man just out of his teens, married a comely young woman named Alice Gallagher, of No. 1,649 First-avenue, in October last, and, according to her story, deserted her three months later. When he left his wife it was reported that he had gone to Boston and married again.
The Police managed until yesterday to conceal the fact that last month a safe was broken open in Tammany Hall and more than $2,500 in money was stolen.

The ladies of St. Ann's Catholic Church, wishing to aid in paying off the debt upon the church and parochial school, opened a fair last evening in Ferrero's Assembly Rooms, in the Tammany Building, on East Fourteenth-street, which is to continue to April 14. TROY, March 28.--The fashionable St. John's Episcopal Church was crowded to-day when Miss Julia W. Smith, daughter of the Hon. Levi Smith, counselor at law, was married to Mr. Henry W. Taft, of Cincinnati, Ohio, son of the ex-AttorneyGeneral of the United States and at present American Minister to the Austrian Court.

The opening day of the trout season falls on Monday, April 2, this year, the Sunday laws preventing fishing on the 1st day of April, and the sun will probably shine that morning on more fishermen on Long Island than there are trout in her streams. The sun may not shine on Monday, but it will make no difference in the number of fishermen present.

Signor MANCINI, the Italian Minister of Foreign Affairs, recently made a speech in defense of the foreign policy of the Government. His explanation of the refusal of Italy to accept the proposal made to her by England to join in the task of overthrowing ARABI ought to have been very satisfactory ...

WASHINGTON, March 28.--Edward Hanlan, the oarsman, who is soon to row a race with Kennedy, near Boston and who is now in training on the Potomac, said to a reporter to-night in the presence of Kennedy that statements had recently been made and printed in various parts of the country which were likely to raise doubts as to the fairness and honesty of the forthcoming race.

There is increasing evidence that the Elbe and Baltic Canal enterprise will be carried out. Two projects looking to that end are in contemplation, one being suuported by English capital, the other by Hamburg. The latter is looked upon with the most favor.

POTTSVILLE, March 28.--St. Clair, an important mining town, situated three miles from this city, was startled to-day by the news that Herman Neuman, a prominent merchant and citizen, well and favorably known throughout this county had committed suicide. Neuman was a widower, his wife having died nine years ago, leaving three ...

OTTAWA, March 28.--Following is the completion of the regular prize list in the dog show: Pointer puppies, class 29--First, Bramble, Hillsdale Kennel, Lancaster, Mass. Champion field spaniels, class 34--First, Benedict, Col. Stewart Taylor, Wyoming Territory. Blackfield spaniel dogs, class 35; second, Hornell Bonanza, ...
PHILADELPHIA, March 28.--By the will of the late Gustavus S. Benson, which was admitted to probate to-day, bequests aggregating $21,000 are made to various religious associations.

KENOSHA, Wis., March 28.--A special train bearing the Milwaukee and Madison delegations made the run to this city in one hour and ten minutes. Many strangers arrived on the morning train. The town was draped in mourning, and on all sides were evidences of deep sorrow for the loss of the dead Postmaster-General.
CHICAGO, March 28.--The city Democratic Convention held this morning nominated Carter H. Harrison for Mayor, John Dunphy for City Treasurer and Julius S. Grinnell for City Attorney.

Louisa Gardner Hall, member of the Protestant Episcopal Sisterhood, known to the world simply as ,"Sister Louise," died very suddenly on Tuesday evening of heart disease in the House of the Holy Comforter at No. 54 West Eleventh-street. Sister Louise was born in Milwaukee, Wis., 32 years ago, and while still in her girlhood she devoted her life to works of charity ...

Mrs. Catharine C. Remsen, of No. 190 West Fourth-street, left her apartments on Tuesday to visit her husband, who is a patient at St. Vincent's Hospital. When she returned home she discovered two men there.

BUFFALO, March 28.--A remonstrance has been drawn up here and signed by the President or some officer of every bank in the city against the passage by the Legislature of the bill to restrict elevator charges.

A hearing in the Hotchkiss-Hutchinson suit, in which Charles A. Hotchkiss sues to recover $108,000 from his former brokers, Kennedy Hutchinson, was had yesterday afternoon before Referee George H. Adams, at the latter's office in the Mills Building. Mr. Hutchinson read from his purchase and sales book the list of sales of Union ...
TORONTO, March 28.--The students of the Toronto University have organized a rowing club to compete in the American college matches.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28.--The Central Union of the Irish National Land League met at Philapatrian Hall to-night to make the necessary preparations for a preliminary convention to arrange details for the Irish National Land League and Irish-American Land League conventions to be held on April 26 and 27 at Horticultural Hall, and also to arrange for the reception of Mr. Parnell and his colleagues on the evening of the 27th at the Academy of Music.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 28.--Charles E. Harmon and I.H. Munroe, of Camillus, gave information at the District Attorney's office yesterday afternoon that the body of Edwin R. Harmon, the father of the former, had been stolen from its grave in the Camillus cemetery.
ALBANY, March 28.--The charter amendments reached Albany the hour that the Legislature adjourned.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 28.--A force Militia, in readiness to proceed to the Lingan mines, paraded in the drill-shed again this evening.

WASHINGTON, March 28.--The President has not yet given any attention to the nomination of Postmaster-General Howe's successor. To-day the White House was closed to visitors, and only a few persons saw the President. Early to-day the President received the following dispatch from Aiken, South Carolina:
A man, apparently insane and very poorly dressed, was found wandering about the town of Gravesend, Long Island, yesterday. He was arrested and taken to the Town Hall.

CINCINNATI, March 28.--The Saloon-keepers' Association met this evening and heard the report of the committee appointed to wait upon the candidates of both political parties for the purpose of ascertaining their views regarding the liquor and Sunday questions.

Bertha, Dreyfuss, a young woman living with her widowed mother at No. 340 East Fortyninth-street, early Tuesday evening left her work, in an artificial flower manufactory in West Houston-street, to do some shopping.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 28.--In the case of the State ex rel. L.B. Da Ponte against the Board of Assessors, praying for a mandamus to prevent the assessment of certain State and city bonds alleged to be exempt from taxation under the Constitution, Judge Rightor to-day refused the mandamus. The case will be appealed to the Supreme Court. After this decision Louisiana 7s fell , Baby bonds 1 , and premium bonds 1 .

NORFOLK, Va., March 28.--Gen. James L. Corley, an insurance agent in this city, cut his throat at a hotel in Hampton this afternoon. He was a graduate of West Point, held a commission in the United States Army before the war, and served with Gen. Lee in the rebellion.

ALBANY, March 28.--The Assembly spent three hours to-day in discussing whether or not the people of the State of New-York should go fishing on Sundays. A modification of the Sunday laws now set down in the Penal Code has been the ambition of Mr. "Tim" Campbell's life since his election to the Legislature.

A fire broke out in the basement of a tonement-house on Grand-street, New-Haven, yesterday. Benjamin Jackson, a policeman, went into the rooms on the second story through a blinding smoke and carried out two women who had reached the head of the stairs and could proceed no further.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28.--Mrs. Lizzie Gerse, aged 19 years, this morning attempted to kill her new born child by throwing it into a well at her house. The infant was rescued by an officer, and the woman, who is unable to leave her bed, was placed under surveillance.

If the Police officer on duty in Park-place had been attending to his business early this morning he would have seen a wagon containing between 75,000 and 90,000 cigars driven away from in front of No. 21.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28.--A dispatch was received at the Central Station shortly after midnight from the Twenty-fourth Police District Station, Clearfield and West streets, saying that 300 man, supposed to be acting under the direction of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company, were destroying the new bridge of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company at Second and Venango streets.

CHICAGO, March 28.--The fourth game of the billiard tournament this afternoon was between Maurice Daly and Lon Morris. The weather was stormy and the attendance light. In the betting Daly was rated almost a sure winner, the odds being forty to eighteen, while even money was laid on his beating Morris by 100 points or more.

PRINCETON, March 28.--The crews were picked to-day, and are as follows: First four-- G.C. Howell, '83; G.B. Jemnison, '83; C.W. Bird, '85; T.A.C. Baker, '83. Second four--R.E. Leo, '86; J.M.T. Finney, '84; W.L. Granberry,'85; A. T. Baker, '85.

Miss Pauline E. Peterson, daughter of Otto L. Peterson, was married last evening to Mr. Harry G. Barber, a son of Mr. Alfred Barber, in St. James's Protestant Episcopal Church, Lafayette-avenue and St. James-place, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Charles W. Homer, Rector of the church, assisted by the Rev. Samuel M. Haskins.

MONTREAL, March 28.--Since Mme. Albani's advent to Montreal, when she was met by a deputation of the City Council, received at the railway station by a concourse of over 10,000 people, and escorted to her hotel by a torch-light procession of hundreds of snow-shores, she has received a continued ovation.

WASHINGTON, March 29.--The star route trial was resumed in the Criminal Court this morn ing, Mr. Ingersoll continuing his examination of Mr. Dorsey. The witness denied generally that he had ever filled up or authorized any one to fill up an affidavit in regard to the number of men and animals required on a route after it had been sworn to or filed.

CHICAGO, March 29.--The leading produce markets were less active to day and very much unsettled. They were generally stronger early in the day, in spite of unsettled weather, and averaged quite weak during the last hour of the session. The early advance was due to outside buying orders, which were supposed to be sent partly in response ...

WASHINGTON, March 29.--Adjt., Gen. Drum received a telegram from San Antonio. Texas, this morning, stating that Gen. Sackett's illness is not so severe as at first apprehended, and his early recovery is confidently expected.

At the twenty-fifth annual meeting of the members of the Brooklyn Library last evening, Vice-President A.C. Barnes, who presided, urged the need of money to develop the usefulness of that institution, and referred to the influence exerted on its membership by the influx of cheap reprints of English novels which could almost be bought by the cartload for the price of a year's subscription to the library.
It has been so often said that the Governorship of Massachusetts is purely an ornamental position that much curiosity has been manifested in observing Gen. BUTLER'S course as Governor.

LIVERPOOL, March 29.--A man who carried a box containing explosives and infernal machines has been arrested here. He had just arrived from Cork. An Irish railway porter, supposed to be an accomplice, has also been taken into custody.

CINCINNATI, March 23.--I met a gentleman the other day who knew Salmon Portland Chase intimately in those days when he was attending school at the old Cincinnati College. The reminiscences that he gave of the great statesman and jurist were of great interest to me.

CHICAGO, March 29.--The opening game today in the balk-line tournament was between Dion and Wallace. As usual with the afternoon games the attendance was light. There was considerable betting on the result at nearly even rates, Dion having the call. It was a case of young head versus old head, the two players representing the extremes as regards age and experience.
Surrogate Rollins was sick yesterday, and the motion calendar was postponed until Monday. The office of the Working Women's Protective Union has been removed to No. 19 Clintonplace, near Broadway.

TUCSON, Arizona, March 29.--Judge H.C. McComas and his wife wore murdered yesterday by Apaches at Thompson Cafion, 18 miles east of Lordsburg, New-Mexico. Their son was with them, and it is supposed that he was captured.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 29.--There was a very large meeting of the congregation of the Baptist church this evening to consider the recent troubles in the church relative to the forced resignation of the Rev. Roland D. Grant, the Pastor.

PITTSBURGH, March 29.--The oil market in this city closed to-day amid scenes of excitement that have rarely been equaled, and never excelled, in this locality. Prices fluctuated so rapidly as completely to carry away the usually level-headed brokers during the morning session, and for an hour after the second call hardly any business was transacted.
The estate of the late Nathaniel Thayer, of Boston, is estimated at $17,000,000.

BOSTON, Mass., March 29.--The formal investigation of the charges made by Gov. Butler in his inaugural Message against the charitable institutions of the State, and especially against their conduct by the State Board of Health, Lunacy, and Charity, began to-night at the Statehouse.

When Dr. A.D. Williams briefly described, Saturday night, at the meeting of the Medical Society, a case of aphasia which had recently come under his observation, he excited a good deal of interest in his confreres, and it is now generally acknowledged that the case is one of the most remarkable ever put on record.

CHICAGO, March 29.--Information has reached here that the Supreme Court sitting at Springfield has filed an opinion in the case of Lester and others against the Chicago Board of Trade in favor of the latter. The suits, 20 in number, grew out of what was known as the July wheat corner, the market price for July wheat at the close of that month having reached $1.36.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29.--The report that George M. Robeson is intriguing for the vacant place in President Arthur's Cabinet is confirmed by the statement of many of Robeson's friends in Camden that his case will be presented in an unexpected light and under circumstances calculated to give it the greatest strength with the President.

ALBANY, March 29.--There was a skirmish between the Republicans and Democrats in the Assembly to-day over the proposed charter amendments that will have the effect of drawing the attention of the citizens of NewYork more closely to the Democratic scheme to grasp their local Government.

The Kentucky distillers are still in trouble. They have found no satisfactory way in which to escape the natural penalties of overproduction. Congress adjourned without giving them the relief which they had sought, and at once it was said that their whisky would be taken out of the country and stored in foreign warehouses until there should be a demand for it at home.

E.Y. Bell, counsel for the Great Western Insurance Company, of this City, filed yesterday, before the Court of Claims in Washington, the petion of that company for participation in the amount remaining in the hands of that court awarded to citizens of the United States by the Government of Great Britain for damage done by the Confedrate cruisers Alabama and Florida.

TUCSON, Arizona, March 30.--A special from Benson, received last night, says that an unusual number of fires were seen from that place on Wednesday night at the foot of the Dragoon Mountains. They were successive flashes and it is understood that a large number of Sonora Apaches are approaching the line near Nogales. The people there have called for United States troops and one company has been sent to that point.

BOSTON, March 30.--The Tewksbury Almshouse investigation was continued at the Statehouse to-night. Another large audience attended the proceedings. Gov. Butler was prompt in his attendance, and again took a leading hand in the work of the evening. It was, on the whole, a dull session, and free from taking "points." There was only one new witness.

BORDEAUX, March 30.--Numerous copies of the manifesto of Prince Jerome Napoleon have bean posted in conspicuous places and upon various public buildings in this city. As soon as they were discovered the Police removed them.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 30.--The publication of the fact that the charter of the Cleveland and Pittsburg Railroad Company gives the State undisputed right to purchase, at stated terms, the entire road after the expiration of 35 years, and that that time elapsed in 1881, has caused no small stir in railroad circles, especially among the stockholders of the road.

CHICAGO, March 30.--The afternoon game in the tournament to-day was between Daly and Wallace. In the betting the New-Yorker was freely backed at odds of $100 to $60. Winning the bank Daly counted from the lay-off, and by means of elegant nursing and position play, made a run of 96, stopping on a foul in an attemped masse.

There was more weather on hand yesterday than the average citizen had any use for. Those whose business took them out of doors felt the sudden change keenly, as walking was very unpleasant and the temperature reminded one of a Winter instead of a Spring day. The monthly exhibition of the New-York Horticultural Society took place yesterday afternoon in the hall of the organization, in West Twenty-eighth street, near Broadway. William Sexton Josoph Dion, and Maurice Daly, the billiard experts, arrived last night from Chicago and unanimously expressed to a TIMES reporter their satisfaction with the success of the balk-line tournament.

Referee John Croak listened wearily yesterday afternoon to another installment of evidence in the case of Barwich, the Prussian valet, who is suing Miss Rebecca McLean for $10,000 damages for breach of promise.

BALTIMORE, April 9.--Miss Sarah Duncan, a lady in the twenty-third year of her age, died suddenly at the Shirley House, No. 119 Madison-street, at 9:35 o'clock last night, from the effects of an overdose of chloral.

WASHINGTON, April 9.--The new Postmaster-General is expected here to-morrow night, having left Indianapolis this afternoon. He will come to take hold at once of his duties in the department, but he will not bring his family here until next Winter.

Pugilistic society last evening enjoyed one of the most exciting entertainments ever witnessed in a public hall in this City, and thieves must have rejoiced if the statements made by melaneholy men are to be believed.

News reached this City on Sunday evening of a stupid attempt in Pittsburg to black-mail Miss Mary Anderson, the actress. The story was printed in THE TIMES yesterday. Letters were written to Miss Anderson's stepfather, Col. Hamilton Griffin, M.D., who is also her business agent, ...
The monthly meeting of the New-York Association for the Protection of Game was held last evening at Pinard's. The chair was occupied by the Hon. Robert B. Roosevelt, President of the organization.

Horatio G. Knight, of Easthampton, Mass., and Frank P. Tenney, composing the firm of Williston, Knight Co., of Nos. 74 and 76 Worthstreet, yesterday made an assignment, without preferences, to John M. Wardwell, of this City, formerly a member of the firm.

LONDON, April 9.--The bill to amend the law in regard to explosives was introduced in the House of Commons this afternoon by Sir William Harcourt, who said the nature of the danger which it sought to guard against was well known.

At a recent meeting of the Parnell Reception Committee of Fifteen, it was decided to increase the committee to 30, choosing the new members from representative Irishmen who are not members of any Irish organizations.

At its meeting last month the Thirteenth Assembly District Republican Association passed a resolution calling on Col. Charles S. Spencer, delegate from that body to the Republican Central Committee, to resign that position, because he had voted for John J. O'Brien for Chairman, when the association had instructed its delegates to vote for Isaac Dayton.

It is a long time since this opera of Meyerbeer's, written 30 years ago, was performed in New-York, and the public recollection of it has grown somewhat faint, though several of the airs are familiar and are frequently heard.

BOSTON, April 9.--The curious case of the child Lizzie Gannon against the Archbishop and a priest for damages for loss of health occasioned by the taking away of some paper figures which she called angels was continued to-day.

When M. LEON CHOTTEAU visited this country a few years ago as the representative of a French committee to prepare the way for the adoption of a treaty of commerce between France and the United States he found American public opinion fairly disposed to the project.

WASHINGTON, April 9.--John R. Miner, a defendant, was Called to the stand in the star route trial to-day and examined by Mr. Henkle. He testified that he had lived in Ann Arbor, Mich., for the last year.

The West Side Elevated Patented Railroad Company was organized in 1866, with a capital of $500,000. It built a one-legged elevated railroad from the Battery to Cortland-street, on Greenwich-street, and then it mortgaged its property and franchise for $750,000.
The Iron and Metal Exchange passed resolutions yesterday in memory of Peter Cooper.

There appears to be some doubt in the neighborhood of the Academy of Music as to whether Col. Mapleson has engaged Mme. Patti and Mme. Gerster for the next season in this country.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9.--Catharine Metzgar, a servant, whose recent attempt to murder her mistress. Mrs. Elizabeth May, startled the community, was placed on trial today before Judge Allison, on the charge of assault and battery with intent to kill.
The progress which has been made by the cause of civil service reform in the last two years is something which its most ardent advocates could hardly have anticipated.

Something of a sensation was created in Wall-street yesterday by the statement that there had been a large misuse of trust funds by an operator in stocks.

Ex-Mayor Henry S. De Bevoise was on trial yesterday, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer of Long Island City, before Judge Joseph Barnard. The main point at issue yesterday was whether Mayor De Bevoise had or had not made an overissue of Long Island City bonds.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 10.--Preparations for the season of 1883 are beginning to be made on all sides, and signs of life are becoming visible in the fashionable Summer residences of this city by the sea. Cottages are renting quite readily at prices which are satisfactory to all concerned.
Mr. Lester Wallack will begin an engage ment next week at the Boston Museum. A new-opera, "Le Grand Casimir," will be presented at the Casino to-night, with Mme. Thee in the principal role.

LONDON, April 10.--A royal message giving assent to the bill relating to explosives was read in Parliament this afternoon. The Times says there was a practical reason for the haste in which the bill, was passed, and explains by stating that some members of the dynamite party are believed to be on steamers now coming from America.

Mrs. Rebecca Bruggy, who was shot in the right breast at No. 343 West Forty-third-street, on Monday night, by her husband, Franklim M. Bruggy, died yesterday in the Roosevelt Hospital. Her maiden name was Reid, and she was born in Ireland, in 1848.

It was 4 o'clock yesterday morning before the complete returns of Monday's election in Paterson, N.J., were received. The result surprised the most sanguine friends of Nathan Barnert, the Democratic candidate, whose majority footed up 879. Mr. Barnert was supported almost solidly by the Germans and the liquor interest.

Much miscellaneous business was transacted by the New-York Methodist Conference at its morning session yesterday. The Committee on Necessitous Cases reported that $15,000 would be required for its work during the coming year.

WASHINGTON, April 10.--Valentine W. Sel lers, a middle-aged white man, was before the Police Court this afternoon charged with "raising" the denomination of a United States Treasury note from $5 to $50. A second-hand dealer testified that Sellers tried to pass the bill in his store as a genuine fifty-dollar bill. The case was sent to the Grand Jury, and the defendant was committed in default of $2,000 bail.

The Hon. RICHARD CROWLEY, who represented the Thirty-first District of this State in the Forty-seventh Congress, was appointed, some weeks ago, a, special attorney of the United States to prosecute election cases in South Carolina.

Yesterday afternoon a party of 25 or 30 gentlemen gathered in the hay-loft of an unoccupied barn, in West Farms, at the intersection of the Southern Boulevard and the Boston road, to organize a little chicken-fight.

The Board of Aldermen passed over the Mayor's veto yesterday the scheme by which the New-York Electric Lines Company is given the right to construct vaults, lay tubes, , for placing electric wires under the streets of the City.

The New-York Exchange for Woman's Work is an institution conducted for the benefit of persons who, instead of seeking charity when fortune fails them, make efforts to sustain themselves. The managers of the Exchange have worked zealously with the means at their command, and they enjoy the satisfaction of knowing that much good has been accomplished.

The New-York and Brooklyn Congregational Association met yesterday morning in the StateStreet Congregational Church, Brooklyn. The Rev. J.T. Robertson acted as Moderator. Twenty-six delegates answered the roll-call.

ATLANTA, April 10.--Five ballots have been taken in the State Convention, and Boynton has been discomfitted. The convention was called to order by Capt. Jackson, who introduced Col. C.C. Jones, of Augusta, as temporary Chairman.

A young man, whose frame was wasted by disease, lay dead in a house in Devoe-street, in the Eastern District of Brooklyn, yesterday. The day before he reposed quietly in the parlor of a neat little house at No. 360 South Fifth-street. He was alive, but his life was ebbing away.

A lease of the Wabash, St. Louis and Pacific Railway to the St. Louis, Iron Mountain and Southern Railroad has been executed by the officers of the two companies. It is to go into effect April 15, and is to continue for 99 years. It is in all respects the same as the lease of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas to the Missouri Pacific.
HAMBURG, April 10.--Dr. Havremann, a young physician residing in Rostock, has been appointed special physician to the Queen of Madagascar.

NEW-HAVEN, April 10.--At an early hour this morning the west end of the Ansonia Hotel, Ansonia, Conn., was found to be on fire. The building was of wood and five stories high.
Dr. Norvin Green, the President of the Western Union Telegraph Company, sailed for Europe in the Alaska yesterday.

Mayor Low has caused to be prepared the draft of a bill providing for the opening of Flatbush-avenue to the bridge by the city under certain conditions, which, he believes, will, if carried out, solve the rapid transit problem for Brooklyn.

Miss Anderson's present brief engagement in this City, which follows close upon her recent engagement at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre, has a somewhat unusual interest. COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 10.--Gen. Keifer spent the day in Columbus looking over the political field, and spent considerable time in consultation with leading politicians on the subject of the Republican Gubernatorial nomination.

About 150 of the Alumni of Princeton College sat down to the annual dinner of the Alumni Association of New-York and its vicinity in Delmonico's large banquet hall last evening. The festivities were presided over by J.W. Alexander, President of the association, ...

BALTIMORE, April 10.--The town of Westminster, Carroll County, Md., 38 miles from Baltimore, was the scene of a terrible conflagration last night, which for a time threatened the destruction of all the property in the place. Twenty buildings were burned to the ground, including a Lutheran Church, the first edifice in the town.

ALBANY, April 10.--The Senate occupied the morning session in the third reading of bills, most of them local and unimportant. The only measure that gave rise to discussion was the bill that has already passed the Assembly to regulate the sale of liquors in cities having a population of not less than 300,000, which confines its operation to New-York and Brooklyn.

On the 30th of January the Assembly at Albany adopted a resolution asking the Mayor of this City what legislation he considered necessary to "economize, simplify, and improve the local Government of the City of New-York."

WASHINGTON, April 10.--There is much gossip about the resiguation of the Hon. Richard Crowley as counsel in the South Carolina election cases. It is stated that his fees as agreed upon would have amounted to $36,000, and this leads to the suspicion that he must have had some peculiar and strong reason for resigning.
ALBANY, April 11.--The Democrats continue to grumble at the delay of Gov. Cleveland in making appointments to vacant offices.

Allan Arthur, son of the President, entertained the Princeton College Glee Club at the White House this evening. He gave a supper and had a social evening with his college mates that dispelled the quietness which has pervaded the mansion since the departure of the President.

BALTIMORE, April 11.--At a meeting of the Board of Directors of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company to-day a semi-annual dividend of 5 per cent. was declared upon the stock of the main stem and Washington Branch of the railroad.

The brig Letitia, Capt. Potter, which arrived yesterday from Miragoane, brought news of a recent revolt against the Haytian Government. There have been numerous charges of corruption against the present Government.

Charles E. Hume and James A. Sharp, comprising the firm of Charles E. Hume Co., builders, of No. 17 West Forty-fourth-street, made an assignment yesterday to Arthur T. Gillender. The business has been established since 1850, Mr. Hume becoming a partner in 1874 and Mr. Sharp in February, 1881.

WATERBURY, Conn., April 17.--This city was treated to a sensation to-day. Greene Kendrick is the Mayor of Waterbury, and one of its most prominent citizens. He is a leading Democratic politician, as was his father before him.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17.--In the Coroner's investigation to-day in the death of Michael F. NEW-ORLEANS, April 17.--The facts about the robbery of the Metropolitan Bank in this city on Sunday night have been greatly exaggerated, although there is no occasion for it, the bank officers freely imparting all the information in their possession.

ALBANY, April 17.--The ease and rapidity with which the Broadway Arcade Railroad bill slipped through the Assembly this morning attracted general attention and created more comment than almost any other measure which has passed the Legislature this Winter.

ALBANY, April 17.--The Court of Appeals this morning affirmed the judgment of the lower courts declaring the jury law of Albany County constitutional. Miss Lucia Louise Stephens, a daughter of Mr. I.P. Stephens, was married in Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon to Mr. Eugene T. Kirkland, the ceremony being performed by the Rev. Dr. Henry Y. Satterlee, Rector of the church. There were no brides-maids.

Mme. Albani, accompanied by her husband, Mr. Ernest Gye, sailed for England yesterday afternoon on board the Cunard steam-ship Gallia. She arrived at the ship about 1 o'clock, having ridden down from the Fifth-Avenue Hotel in a carriage, with her maid and Mr. Gye.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 28.--The cigarmakers employed in two of the largest factories in this city notified their employers this evening that they would not return to work on Monday morning unless their wages were increased $1 per thousand. Yesterday was a busy day at the Central Park Menagerie, The warm weather--which made the animals drowsy and heavy and caused the polar bear to fairly gasp for breath as be swayed from side to side in his narrow cage, wearing deep furrows in the floor with his sharp claws--brought out the largest attendance of the season, and the buildings were packed with an ever-changing crowd from early morning until evening.

NASHVILLE, April 28.--The annual sale of thorough-bred horses at Belle Meade, the beautiful farm of Gen. W.G. Harding, attracted several hundred persons to-day, among them being many of the most prominent of American turfmen.
CLEVELAND, April 28.--The Ohio Democrats who have set out to beat Senator Pendleton do not intend to let anything stand between them and the accomplishment of their desire.

NEW-HAVEN, April 28.--In the Police Court to-day Judge Deming rendered his decision in the "washed diamonds" case. Jacob Nepel was charged with obtaining by false pretenses $625 from Edward Engel, a pawnbroker, by means of several diamonds which the buyer took to be old mine stones, but which, when washed with soap and water, proved to be of the Cape variety.

The launch of the new sloop yacht Snoozer and the rebuilt sloop Favorite which was to have taken place yesterday at John Driscoll's ship-yard, Greenpoint, was postponed on account of the weather. The launch will take place on next Saturday.

Mr. Boehm's bronze statute of Sir Francis Drake, which the Duke of Bedford has presented to the town of Tavistock, will be unveiled near the end of July by the Prince of Wales. The Prince will be the guest of the Duke on this occasion, and the country people of the West are earnestly hopeful that he will be accompanied by the Princess.

There were a good many empty seats in Plymouth Church yesterday morning, although the congregation was a large one. Henry Ward Beecher was listened to with more than usual interest, as he talked about liberty of thought and speech. We lived in a time, Mr. Beecher said, when vast changes were going on. In the mother land a great change was going on in theology and ecclesiology.

The theory that colds are the result of exposure to cold or damp air is generally accepted. Indeed, most persons afflicted with this disorder are able to trace its origin, satisfactorily to themselves at least, to some undue or unusual contact with outside air. They seek no other explanation. In the columns of the Popular Science News Dr. Page, of Biddeford, Me., undertakes to show the fallacy of such a course of reasoning.

LONDON, April 19.--The fine weather continues, and agricultural experts favor the anticipations of a good harvest. But prophecy in this respect is utterly untrustworthy. It is not enough to say that everything looks well at any given time.

On Tuesday Henry D. McDaniel was elected Governor. The size of the vote fails to indicate the interest of the people in the result, for the work of the late convention had made the casting of ballots a mere matter of form.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Academy of Music was held last evening in the Academy for the election of Directors and the decision of the important question whether the stockholders would levy an assessment to compensate Messrs. Gye and Mapleson for the extra expense entailed in securing Mme. Patti.

The last of the series of Spring games between the New-York League Club and the Metropolitan team was played on the Polo Grounds yesterday, and resulted in another defeat for the American Association representatives. Of the eight games played the New-Yorks won seven and the Metropolitans one.

Among the really great men of Colorado, the Hon. H.M. TELLER and the Hon. N.P. HILL easily stand first. Mr. HILL is great because he is a United States Senator from Colorado, and Mr. TELLER is great because he has been a United States Senator from Colorado.
WASHINGTON, April 30.--At a late hour this afternoon Mr. De B. Randolph Keim had not received his commission, and there still seemed to be some doubt as to whether he would get it or not.

Some of the members of the Board of Police Justices undertook last evening, in the Jefferson Market Court-room, to elect a successor to the late Charles Blackie, as Clerk of the Court of Special Sessions.

During the month of April 29 new national banks were organized. WASHINGTON, April 30.--There are about 60 vacancies in the grade of Secoud Lieutenant in the army.
The Turf Club enters on its third year today with over 600 members, and about June 20 will assume its new name--the Madison Club.

ATLANTA, April 30.--The trial and convic tion of James Stringer in the Lumpkin Superior Court for murder had some dramatic features. He was indicted for the murder of his brother-in-law, named Gaddis, which occurred four weeks ago.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 30.--The Czar and the Grand Duke Constantine, uncle of his Majesty, have become completely reconciled through the mediation of the Princess Dolgorouki.

Several members of the New-York Stock Exchange met in the Governing Committee's room yesterday to give expression to a feeling of dissatisfaction with the ticket announced by the Nominating Committee on Saturday, to be voted for at the annual election May 25.

ALBANY, April 30.--There is trouble in the Democratic camp over the nomination of ex-Senator Murtha for Emigration Commissioner. As usual when there are bones to be distributed, Tammany is in rebellion unless she gets her full share of more than her share.

MILWAUKEE, April 30.--In the Circuit Court to-day Judge Hamilton reversed the order of Court Commissioner Ryan in ordering the discharge of Kate Kane, the lady lawyer who refused to pay the fine imposed for dashing a glass of water in Judge Mallory's face, and remanded her back to jail.
PITTSBURG, April 30.--If the expectations of those interested are realized, the number of idle men in this city and vicinity will be 8,000 greater to-morrow than to-day.

The Rev. D.C. Potter, Pastor of the SixthStreet Baptist Church, succeeded in surprising most of the clergymen present at the Baptist Ministers' Conference yesterday.
The wholesale fish-dealers in New-York, with many retailers, are of the opinion that the restrictions as to the size of lobsters caught or exposed for sale in New-York should be removed.

The Chief Examinership under the Civil Service Commission is a very important place, because the incumbent is really the executive officer of the commission. He acts under its control, indeed, but he has great opportunities and can largely mold the whole work.

CINCINNATI, May 1.--The Dramatic Festival performance to-night was "The Hunchback." The audience was not so large as last night, but the hall was more than comfortably filled. Last night 2,000 people stood up. To-night there were perhaps 800 standing.

RICHMOND, Va., May 1.--Otis H. Russell, Collector of Internal Revenue for this district, has issued since midnight stamps under the new law for nearly 2,000,000 pounds of manufactured tobacco, 4,000,000 of cigarettes, and 1,000,000 of cigars, the tax aggregating in round numbers $165,000.

BOSTON, May 1.--The Tewksbury Almshouse examination was resumed to-day with a small attendance. Charles B. Marsh, book-keeper at the Alms-house, testified as to his system of keeping the books and other details of the Almshouse routine.

A meeting of prominent residents of the Eastern District of Brooklyn was held last evening at the residence of Capt. Ambrose Snow, No. 11 Bedford-avenue, to discuss the question of building another bridge across the East River from Grandstreet, New-York, to Broadway, Williamsburg.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1.--The Board of Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, at a special meeting this afternoon, decided to declare a semi-annual dividend of 2 per cent. in cash, 2 per cent. in scrip or cash, at the option of stockholders, and 4 per cent. in stock.
LONDON May 1.--Mr. James McHenry has been adjudged a bankrupt. The Queen has abandoned her intention to open the Fisheries Exhibition. The Prince and Princess of Wales will officiate in her place.

The twenty-fifth annual report of the Chamber of Commerce has just been issued. It consists of two parts, the first presenting an analysis of the proceedings of the Chamber at its several meetings during the year, and the second containing special reports of the several trades, with statistical tables of the transactions in each, and tables of exports and imports.
The one hundred and twentieth call for bonds matured to-day. The redemptions under the call, including prepaid bonds, amount to about $11,500,000.

Niles to constitute a commission to select and locate lands for public parks in the Twentythird and Twenty-fourth Wards and their vicinity and to report to the Legislature.

EASTON, Penn., May 1.--Two tramps named John Phillips and William Harris were committed to jail to-day for trial on a charge of assault and battery and attempt to kill L.S. Keller, proprietor of the Ebro House, in Williamstown.

CINCINNATI, May 1.--There will be no disturbance here among cigar-makers on account of the reduction of the tax on tobacco. They struck some time ago for an addition to their wages and succeeded, as also did the cigar-packers. There remains but a single question unsettled between employes and employers, and that will not present itself till Fall, when gas is burned.

The work of moving, the truck and van keepers say began later this year than last, but when it did begin the rush was great. From the best information that could be obtained, two families moved out of the City where one moved into it. Where people moved from one point to another in the City they almost invariably went further up town.

CHICAGO, May 1.--The leading produce markets were less active to-day and averaged stronger, though in an irregular way. The strength was mostly over by about 11 o'clock, as after that time sellers were in the majority. The news favored higher prices for wheat, and that held up the rest, in the face of heavy deliveries on May contracts.

A recent census of German animals contains certain curious and suggestive figures. As compared with a similar census taken in 1873 it shows that most varieties of German animals have decreased in numbers within the last ten years. Germany has fewer mules, asses, and sheep and more pigs and goats than she had ten years ago, while the number of horses and oxen has very slightly increased.

BOSTON, May 2.--Charles B. Marsh was recalled at the Tewksbury examination to-day, and the Governor asked him for a certain book which he claimed to be his private property, but would turn it over if necessary. The Governor said he wanted it, and in the broadest possible way he wanted again to demand every book of the institution.

DENTON, Md., May 2.--The trial of Mrs. Belle Beachamp for the murder of her husband, which began on Tuesday of last week, ended at 12:55 o'clock to-day in a verdict of not guilty. The jury, which retired at 10:30 o'clock, came into court at 12:45 to ask for further instructions.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 2.--The almost unanimous denunciation by the Democratic press of Louisiana of the land ring, of which John McEnery is the head and chief offender, has drawn to-day from Gov. Sam McEnery, his brother, an explanation which is considered far from satisfactory.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 2.--The Harvard oarsmen, as is usual at this season of the year, are actively engaged in preparation for their annual contests, the first of which--the class races--will take place, water permitting, on Thursday of next week, May 10, at 4 o'clock in the afternoon. On the

WASHINGTON, May 2.--The President today appointed First Lieut. Daniel H. Floyd, of the Eighteenth Infantry, an Assistant Quartermaster, with the rank of Captain. Leave of absence until Aug. 15 has been granted Capt. Edmund Luff, Eighth Cavalry.

LONDON, May 2.--Winawer and Rosenthal played a drawn game, and Bird beat Englisch in the chess tournament to-day. In the evening Mason and Noa played a drawn game, and Sellman was defeated by Blackburne.

The Post Office nine yesterday defeated the base-ball club of the Park Bank, after a close game, by a score of 10 to 9.

WASHINGTON, May 2.--A special meeting of the Cabinet was held to-day to consider the civil service regulations now awaiting the President's action. All the members were present except the Attorney-General, who is temporarily confined to his home by a bad cold.

Payne and Amasa Stone to the purchase of the Nickel Plate came to the surface in formal action. Chauncey M. Depew was chosen....

The Controller of the Currency has declared a dividend of 5 per cent. in favor of the creditors of the Mechanics' National Bank of Newark, N.J., making in all 60 per cent. paid to the creditors.

CINCINNATI, May 3.--It is probable that the olimax of the Dramatic Festival was reached to-night. The play was "Othello," and 5,000 people witnessed the strongest performance of that work ever seen on the Cincinnati stage.

Ex-Tax Commissioner John Wheeler has been recommended to Mayer Edson by his friends for appointment as successor to Tax Commissioner Vanderpoel, whose term has expired.

CHICAGO, May 3.--The leading produce markets were stronger to-day, with an irregular volume of trading, but less doing in the aggregate. The strength of the situation lay chiefly with wheat, which is believed to promise so poorly, both here and in Europe, as to justify high prices.

Mr. John Burns, Chairman of the Cunard Company, and one of the largest shareholders, arrived in the Servia on Monday with his family, and is now at the Victoria Hotel.

NEW-HAVEN, May 3.--A match manufacturer of this city said to-day that it was understood that the Ives Judd match factory, of Cheshire, had been purchased by the Diamond Match Company, which has already swallowed up many other concerns, and has virtually a monopoly of the business in this country.
Mr. Herman C. Merivale's drama, called "The Cynie," was performed at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre yesterday afternoon for the benefit of Miss Kate Pattison, the leading actress in Mrs. Langtry's company.

Mrs. Mary C. Johnson, wife of Eli Johnson, puts forward as a plea on behalf of her husband that his mind is affected. She is particular to state, however, that his mental condition is not such as to exonerate him from responsibility for his action in trying to blast her character.

PORT PENN, New-Castle County, Del., May 2.--From the capes of Virginia to Wilmington the peach trees are in bloom. On the lower end of the peninsula they are about shedding the blossom, while here they are just bursting the blossom.

On an order of arrest granted by Judge Sedgwick, of the Superior Court, Thomas B. Pheby was arrested Wednesday night at the Hoffman House by Deputy Sheriff Crawford in a suit brought by the Inyo Consolidated Mining and Milling Company to recover $50,468.40, which, it is alleged, Pheby converted to his own use.

CINCINNATI, May 4.--The veteran actor, Murdoch, appeared in Music Hall to-night as Hamlet. He is 73 years old, and has been off the stage, except as a lyceum reader, ever since the war. His home is in Cincinnati, and he is much respected, and when the Dramatic Festival began to be talked of there was a demand that it should be made the occasion for one more appearance of Murdoch.

WASHINGTON, May 4.--The civil service rules, as telegraphed exclusively to THE TIMES, were for the fourth time discussed to-day in the Cabinet, and it is a flattering testimonial to the Commissioners that their work is said to have borne the criticism of the President and his advisers so well as to remain substantially as they were this morning presented to the readers of THE TIMES. They will probably be promulgated in a few days.

ALBANY, May 4.--The Democratic "reform" Legislature has burst up in a row, and the "regulars" have gone home cursing the day when they admitted John Kelly and his Tammany gang of spoils-hunters back into the fold. Up to the time the Senate convened this afternoon for its closing session no one had any anticipation or inkling of the bombshell that was so soon to burst in the Democratic camp.

The exhibition of taxidermy at Lyric Hall will close to-day. It has attracted much attention. Mr. Jahn B. Cough will lecture Tuesday evening next on "Eloquence and Orators" before the literary society of Dr. Newman's church, Madison-avenue and Forty-fifth-street.

WARSAW, N.Y., May 4.--In the Wyoming County Circuit Court to-day the case of Carrie L. Butterfield against Edgar D. Van Slyke, for breach of promise, was placed on trial, Justice Haight, of Buffalo, presiding, with Messrs. Bartlett and Bartlett attorneys for the plaintiff and the Hon. Augustus Harrington for the defendant.

The annual meeting of the Boston Society of Natural History was held last evening at the society's building. A highly interesting statement was made by Prop. F.W. Putnam, Curator of the Peabody Museum of Harvard University, concerning his recent explorations of certain mounds in the Ohio Valley. The subject was illustrated by drawings hung upon the wall and by photographs.

PITTSBURG, May 4.--The failure of the conference committee of iron manufacturers and the Amalgamated Association to agree yesterday, and the consequent prospect of a strike in the iron mills of the West on the 1st of June, was not unexpected by persons who have watched the course of events. Nevertheless, the formal announcement of the disagreement has caused great excitement in this city, whose prosperity depends almost entirely on the iron trade.

ST. PAUL, May 4.--A reporter who has just returned from a trip through the Red River valley and the Northern Pacific territory between the Red and Missouri Rivers writes that the season is more than usually backward and fully 20 days later than the Spring of 1882. The frost was too slow in leaving the ground.

There was a good deal of excitement in Irish circles in this City yesterday, caused by the report from Europe that P.J. Sheridan and John Walsh had been arrested in this country on extradition proceedings, but no foundation could be found for such statements. Neither Mr. Sheridan nor Mr. Walsh felt alarmed. They were around all day in the neighborhood of City Hall, and freely discussed the situation, with their friends.
"The Muddy Day" will be performed again this evening at the Theatre Comique. The last two performances of "Green-Room Fun" by the Salsbury Troubadours may be seen today at the Standard Theatre.

The originator of the now popular system of teaching by object-lessons was undoubtedly the late Mr. Squeers, who made his boys curry his horses and weed the garden in order to teach them the nature of horses and vegetables. The latest application of this system is to be found in a certain NewEngland girls' school, where object lessons in cooking, eating, dress-making, and millinery form part of the course of instruction.

PARIS, May 4.--Reports prevail here that Duc d'Aumale is seriously ill in Sicily. BOSTON, May 4.--At the Tewksbury hearing to-day Lorenzo Fairbanks resumed his testimony upon the subject of the alterations and erasures in the cash book of the inmates. A large number of instances were developed and explained by witness, showing erasures of figures relating to money belonging to inmates.

The President has appointed Gen. McDOWELL, Admiral HOWELL, and Mr. EDWARD Y. KINSLEY Commissioners to visit the Naval Academy and to ascertain-- among other things--if the standard of scholarship at that institution is higher than it should be.

EAGLE ROCK, Idaho, May 4.--Whitley, a discharged employe of the Utah Northern Railroad, entered the station here yesterday, called the station agent, W.B. Green, to the counter, and, after exchanging a few words with him, drew a revolver and fired three shots at him, inflicting fatal injuries.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4.--There is trouble in the ranks of the First City Troop, the "very swell" military organization of this city, whose history goes back to the Revolution, and whose roll bears many of the brightest names in the annals of Pennsylvania. The trouble first broke out five years age, when E. Bird Grubb was elected Captain.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4.--A bill in equity was filed in the United States Circuit Court to-day by the counsel for U.M. Osborn, of New-Jersey, a stockholder of the Western Union Telegraph Company, to restrain that corporation from paying and the city of Philadelphia from collecting, an annual tax of $2.50 per mile upon the wires of the company in this city.

William H. Vanderbilt yesterday retired from the active management of the New-York Central, the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern, and the Michigan Central Railroads. He remains, however, a Director in the three corporations with which his name has been identified since the death of his father, the Commodore, in 1877. The session of the Legislature which came to a close last night was in some respects the most discreditable with which the State has been afflicted for many years. The tidal wave of last Fall gave the Democrats such a majority in the Assembly that they were able to work their will with the questions that came before that body.

ITHACA, May 4.--President white this morning addressed the students of Cornell University regarding the attack recently made upon the institution at a meeting of local Alumni in NewYork City. He said that if the charges were true the Trustees, Professors, President, and students ought to be dismissed. He then took up the charges in detail, and showed their baselessness.

Gen. CROOK, with his little army of invasion, was on the Mexican boundary before the order of Gen. SHERMAN, dated at Washington, April 28, could reach him. He was at some distance from the end of telegraphic communication when his final preparations were made--April 23.
