A few days ago an American schooner met with a remarkable, not to say unprecedented, turtle. The reptile was sleeping peacefully on the surface of the water in the neighborhood of the Banks, and when it was first seen it was supposed to be the hull of a capsized vessel.

LONDON, May 4.--In the House of Commons this afternoon the Speaker stated that he had received a letter from Mr. Bradlaugh, in which that gentleman announced that he would, at the beginning of business to-day, ask to be permitted to take the oath. The Speaker asked for the guidance of the House.

CHICAGO, May 4.--The leading produce markets were very irregular to-day, with more doing. There was a general dash of weakness early, which continued till near noon, being most marked in breadstuffs. The markets softened with the weather, and a little before noon there was a turn in the state of affairs, and the markets subsequently recovered a large part of the decline, closing strong. Provisions were very irregular, with more activity.

If you could see me now! What contrasts there are in life; indeed, half the world do not know how the other half live. Here we are in a little mud hut, the floor of earth and the walls of mud bricks. The roof is of shingles, but spaces between permit the wind to enter and play round the cabin in gusts.

At times the springs at Steamboat develop geysers of a grand character. In the Spring of 1860 there was at Steamboat a spring that spouted once in about eight hours. This spring had an opening about 3 feet in diameter and some 9 feet deep.

PETERSBUG, Va., May 4.--More than 50 members of the Legislature of Pennsylvania arrived in this city to-day on the midday train from the North. The authorities had been duly apprised of their intended visit, and there was a large assemblage of citizens at the station to meet them. A committee had been appointed from the citizens and the municipal authorities, from the Northern residents ...

Assistant Secretary New, who is Chairman of the special committee to investigate the affairs of the Supervising Architect's office, was informed to-day by Mr. T.H. Murch that he will be ready to appear before the committee in a short time. He says he has no objection to Mr. Alexander serving on the committee, and hopes to be able to say definitely to-morrow when he will be ready to proceed.

The New-York League Club met its first defeat in the championship race yesterday, when it encountered the heavy batting of the Providence team. Fully 4,000 persons assembled to witness the contest, which was rather one-sided, and resulted in a victory for the Rhode Island players by a score of 11 to 3. Among those present were a large number of ladies.

A fatal elevator accident occurred yesterday morning in the new Bryant Building, at the north-west corner of Nassau and Liberty streets, which resulted in the instant death of Gustav Schiff, a plate and window glass dealer, whose place of business is at No. 35 Murray-street. John Lyons, a well-known citizen of this county, on Friday last, while at work in the shaft of his mine near Tres Alamos, had just put in a blast and lighted the fuse, when, on reaching the top of the shaft, he beheld four mounted Apaches rapidly approaching. As they saw him emerge they increased their pace, and their fiendish yells relieved Mr. Lyons of all doubt as to their intentions toward himself.

ALBANY, May 4.--The tidal wave Legislature of 1883 adjourned sine die at 7 o'clock this evening. It disappears from public view leaving behind it a record fully justifying the old saying that the Democracy is unable to bear prosperity. Its closing hours were signalized by a clashing of the Tammany and Tilden factions in the Senate. All the old bitterness has been revived.

WASHINGTON, May 4.--Mr. George Bliss had spoken for five trial days when he stopped this afternoon, but he had not then closed his summing up of the star route case, and will go on again on Monday. The counsel for the defense have agreed to submit their case without argument, and it is probable that they will do so as soon as Mr. Bliss has finished his speech.

Advices from the Pan Handle Railroad state that over a thousand of the strikers returned to work this morning at the reduction, and 1,500 more are reported to have left ...

WILKESBARRE, May 6.--An affair of honor which took place on Thursday morning last, between two well-known young men of this city has just come to light, although great efforts have been made by the interested parties to hush the matter up.

DUBLIN, May 7.--The third trial of Timothy Kelly for participation in the murder of Lord Frederick Cavendish and Mr. Burke was begun to-day. James Carey, the informer, on being called to the witness stand, swore that every one of the invincibles, with the exception of Joe Brady, had offered to turn informer.

The Executive Committee having in charge the arrangements for the celebration of the one hundredth anniversary of the evacuation of NewYork by the British, met in the Chamber of Commerce rooms yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 7, 1883. The new tariff law provides that trade marks which may be adopted by any American manufacturer may be deposited with the Secretary of the Treasury and distributed to Customs officers, and that when so distributed no goods bearing such trade-mark shall be imported unless the person owning the trade-mark is the importer.

BATAVIA, May 7.--George Brisbane, who was arrested in Brooklyn on Saturday, charged with sending malicious and annoying letters to the wife of his brother Albert, and who was afterward served with a summons in a suit for $50,000 damages, on the ground of libeling his sister-in-law, has resided in Batavia all his life.

The Governor will have until the 4th day of June in which to consider the merits of the great mass of legislation left in his hands at the close of the recent session, and it is likely to give him plenty to do. But there are some bills which ought to give him very little trouble.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7.--There was a lively time at the session of the Philadelphia Presbytery Central to-day when the request of the Northwestern Presbyterian Church, of which the Rev. Waldo Mesaras is Pastor, for permission to withdraw from the Presbytery came up for consideration.

The rattle of the cutlery, the chink of the glasses, and the merry hum of conversation, at the one hundred and fifteenth anniversary banquet of the Chamber of Commerce, at Delmonico's last night, gave way to a vigorous round of applause when the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher entered the banquet hall and took his seat beside President Lane.

Slosso and Heiser, the billiard experts, left this City for Rochester yesterday and will play exhibition games there this to-morrow, and Friday evenings. They play in Utica on Saturday.

BOSTON, May 8.--The opening session of the annual convention of the Hotel Men's Mutual Benefit Association was held to-day at Wesleyan Hall, and was attended by delegations from various sections of the United States.

The increase of 1881 ana 1882 of the Mountainside herd of Jersey cattle, the property of Mr. Theodore A. Havemeyer, were sold yesterday at auction at Mr. Havemeyer's private stables, in West Seventy-second-street, by Peter C. Kellogg Co., the auctioneers.

At the meeting of the Bar Association last night President Francis N. Bangs read an order made by the Supreme Court, General Term, appointing the association as Referee to take testimony and report as to the propriety of rehabilitating William H. Gale as a member of the Bar.

WASHINGTON, May 8.--As a result of inquiries made at the State Department to-day, it has been learned that the subject of Gov. Butler's recent letter to Secretary Folger, namely, pauper immigration from Ireland, has been under consideration in that department.

Mr. Washington Winsor, President of the New-York Mereantile Exchange, has sent a message to the Executive Committee of that Exchange calling their attention to certain abuses in the produce trade which he believes should be corrected.
The authorities and the rest of the people of Halifax are much disturbed by the information which has reached there concerning two mysterious schooners.

NEW-HAVEN, May 8.--The stroke which the Yale crew will pull this year is that which they Dulled last year when they were defeated by the Harvard men by three seconds. It is known as the rapid stroke, in distinction from the slow English or Cook stroke.

PITTSBURG, May 8.--This afternoon Secretary Flannery, of the Coal Miners' Association, filed a petition in the Prothonetary's office for the appointment of a trades tribunal under the Wallace act to settle the differences between the railroad operators and miners.
A tender solicitude in regard to the present abiding place of Joseph Haerr, a plausible man of 30 years, prevails in the neighborhood of Third and Grand streets, Brooklyn, Eastern District.

DUBLIN, May 8.--Earl Spencer, the Lord Lieutenant, has commuted the death sentence of Patrick Delaney, who pleaded guilty to the charge of complicity in the murder of Lord Frederick Cavendish and Mr. Burke.

By far the best exhibition of dogs yet given by the Westminster Kennel Club, and probably as fine a canine display as ever was made anywhere, was opened in the Madison-Square Garden yesterday morning.

A rain and wind storm followed by thunder and lightning raged in thin City and neighborhood for a few minutes, beginning at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The storm was extremely severe in the neighborhood of the Battery. The ferry-boats listed heavily to one side.

The Massachusetts Legislature has adopted a resolution certifying to the ability, public services, and integrity of the late OAKES AMES, and asking the Congress of the United States to take similar action. Mr. AMES was a member of Congress during a stormy period of our national history.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 8.--The palatial villa of Miss Catherine L. Wolfe, of New-York, is rapidly approaching completion. It is at Ochre Point, on a piece of land which cost Miss Wolfe $192,000.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 8.--Mrs. Barnes, a lady much respected, aged over 80 years, and her two granddaughters, Adela Carrier, aged 18, and Fannie Carrier, aged 16, live in a small frame house on the west side of the Farmington road, about a quarter of a mile west of West Hartford Centre.

BOSTON, May 8.--Gov. Butler sent to the House this afternoon a message on insurance matters. He says the required examinations of insurance companies by an Actuary have not been made for several years, and their condition is not known.

A concert was given last night for the banefit of the Children's Aid Society at No. 16 East. Thirty-sixth-street, the residence of Mr. A.B. Stone, one of the Trustees. There was a large and distinguished andience present, and it was stated that a large nymber of persons who were not present had bought tickets.
The present Governing Committee of the New-York Stock Exchange held its last stated meeting yesterday afternoon, and nearly all of the members were present.

It may fairly be inferred that we are much less likely since the Irish-American conventions in Philadelphia than we were before to have serious trouble in regard to unlawful acts in Great Britain aided from this country.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 9.--The Illinois Department of Agriculture has just completed a report covering 1,600 townships in the State, from which an estimate is made of the crops. The Winter wheat crop will not exceed 40 per cent of the crop of 1882.

BOSTON, May 9.--The Tewksbury Almshouse hearing was resumed to-night. Dr. Henry Wood testified that the trouble with the Swede Johnson's stumps might have come from the use of the artificial legs or exposure to cold.

NEW-HAVEN, May 9.--The Yale University nine played the Alaskas, of Brooklyn, at Hamilton Park this afternoon, and easily defeated them by a score of 19 to 0. The visitors, were unable to hit Booth, while the Yale men found no difficulty with the pitching of Church.

A collision occurred at 8:30 o'clock yesterday morning on the east track of the elevated railroad, opposite No. 1,195 Third-avenue between the engine of a train going to Harlem and the second car of a commission train that was switching into a pocket to lay up.
A draft of a lease of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey to the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad was presented to the Directors of the latter road at a meeting in Philadelphia on Tuesday.

At the meeting of the Dock Commissioners yesterday it was resolved to request the Governor to send the Commissioners copies of all bills affecting their department, and to refrain from signing them until examined by the Commissioners.

Eleven hundred dogs sat patiently in their kennels in the Madison-Square Garden yesterday receiving the pattings and caresses of such visitors as ventured to test their good-nature, and waiting for their rations of dog biscuit.

The annual meeting of the American Tract Society was held yesterday at the Collegiate Church, at Fifth-avenue and Twenty-ninth-street. The Secretary's and Treasurer's reports showed that during the year there have been 97 new publications issued.

BERLIN, May 9.--A motion recently offered in the Reichstag by a member from Strassburg, for the abolition of the dictatorship in Alsace-Lorraine, has provoked comments in the French press which are calculated to cause irritation in Germany.

CHICAGO, May 9.--The leading produce markets were dull to-day, in most departments, and irregular in tone. The bad crop reports failed to advance grain, except for a moment, and provisions weakened in spite of a higher quotation for hogs. The storm-laden skies tended to repress enterprise in trading.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 9.--The particulars of a terrible cyclone, which passed over the lower end of this county last evening, have just been collected.

CHICAGO MARKETS STRONGER. CHICAGO, May 12.--The leading produce markets were generally stronger, with a fair volume of business. Grain was firm throughout, while provisions weakened early in the day, but reacted in sympathy with breadstuffs. DES MOINES, Iowa, May 12.--The Winter wheat area in Iowa has always been very restricted. The amount of Spring wheat sown is smaller than in any previous year, and the bushel yield this year will hardly exceed the short crop. of 1881. Oats are more largely sown than horetoforo, which is the case with rye.

The annual Commencement of the Law Department of the University of the City of NewYork took place last evening in the Academy of Music.

CHICAGO, May 14.--The evidence for the de fense in the Dunn murder case was continued to day before Judge Smith. It was expected that the defendant would take the stand in his own behalf and the consequence was that an unusal effort was made by the public to gain admission to the court-room.

The announcement that Mrs. Maria Stoddard, wife of the Rev. E.L. Stoddard, Rector of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church, on Summit-avenue, Jersey City Heights, had accidentally killed herself was heard with much regret yesterday. St. John's Church is the most fashionable church in Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, May 14.--The order for the court-martial of Paymaster J.R. Wasson, to be convened on the 16th inst., has been suspended by Gen. Auger, the department commander, by direction of the Secretary of War, pending a further examination as to the extent of the defalcation.

CINCINNATI, May 14.--The Boot and Shoe Manufacturers' Association this afternoon decided to lock out all union men in their employ. An agreement existed between the union men and the manufacturers that no strike or lock-out should occur until efforts at an arbitration of differences had failed.
PHILADELPHIA, May 14.--Miss Carrie Buechle, 32 years old, a public school teacher, committed suicide yesterday at her home, No. 1,221 Brown-street. She resided with her mother.
DUBLIN, May 14.--Joe Brady, who was convicted of participation in the murder of Lord Frederick Cavendish and Mr. Burke, was hanged at 8 o'clock this morning.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14.--There was a very large attendance at the foot and dog handicaps, under the management of Arthur Chambers, at Pastime Park this afternoon. There were 60 entries for the foot handicap, and 21 for the 200 yards' dog handicap.

CLEVELAND, May 14.--The funeral services of Amasa Stone were held at 2 o'clock this afternoon at the residence of the family in Eualid-avenue. The attendance of friends from Cleveland and from other cities was large, and the services were solemn and appropriate.
Controller CAMPBELL has made a report to the Mayor of the result of his investigation into the defalcation of the deceased coupon clerk, CARROLL.

WASHINGTON, May 14.--The President has accepted 25 miles of the Northern Pacific Railroad, in Montana, westward from the six hundredth to the six hundred and twenty-fifth mile west of the Missouri River.
The American Museum of Natural History gives its annual reception to-day, and visitors will find there the basis of a really excellent collection, systematically arranged and classified.

PITTSBURG, May 14.--This has been a fateful day for the railroad coal industry of this section. The operators and miners held a meeting, the outcome of which will result either in a settlement of the strike, which has already cost $250,000, or in a more bitter fight between the contending parties.

LOUISVILLE, May 14.--The testimony in rebuttal in the Thompson case was closed at noon to-day. The evidence was either confirmatory of that given before or related to the character and credibility of the witnesses.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 14.--Great crowds thronged the streets this morning in the southern part of the city, viewing the destruction by last night's storm. Workmen are already busy clearing away the debris from the streets, and patching up such houses as are capable of repairs.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14.--Judge Butler, in the United States Court, to-day filed an important opinion, in which he dismissed a bill in equity of Charles M. and Frederick Siemens against the Directors of the Midvale Steel Company, claiming a royalty upon the use of the Siemens regenerative gas furnace from 1878 to 1881.

CHICAGO May 15.--The produce markets were slow to-day, and grain averaged easier, while provisions were uncertain, but did not fluctuate badly. Reuben Wells, of Staten Island, had a fair share of this world's goods, and also a yearning for domestic life, which led him to assume the bonds of matrimony three times. His third wife survives him.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 15.--The little town of Empire, in the southorn part of Kentucky was entirely destroyed at 6 o'olock last night by a tornado. Heavy ominous clouds gathered and came up quickly from a westerly direction, bringing with them a fearful storm of thunder, lightning, and wind.

The first is the General Street Railroad bill, and affects Brooklyn only indirectly. Against the signing of it the Mayor enters a most emphatic protest.

ST. LOUIS, May 22.--Judge Chester H. Krum, ex-United States District Attorney and exDistrict Judge, has disappeared. It is charged that he is a defaulter as Administrator of two large estates.

CINCINNATI, May 22.--There is considerable talk among Republicans as to the wisdom of holding their State Convention at as early a date as has been agreed upon. It is now almost certain that the constitutionality of the Scott law will not have been decided at the time the convention meets.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22.--Col. Thomas F. Barr. Judge-Advocate of the United States Army, came to this city from Washington to-day and secured certified copies of Major A.H. Nickerson's libel in the divorce proceedings against his wife, the testimony in support of it, the decree, and of Mrs. Nickerson's affidavit in support of the rule to have the decree vacated. Col. Barr said that the copies would be used in court-martial proceedings ...

A sense of the necessity of Republican unity in this City has somehow penetrated even the thickest heads among that class of public-spirited gentlemen who have so long and magnanimously subordinated their private interests to the nobler duty of managing the party. Not long ago these persons were in a sullen and vindictive mood.

Two men and 14 horses lost their lives by a fire in President-street, Brooklyn, about 2 o'clook yesterday morning. The fire was caused by the slaking of a quantity of lime consequent on the rain-storm in the brick sheds of Morton Sons, on the Gawanus Canal. The sheds were in flames before the first alarm had been given, the fire having burst suddenly out in several places at the same time.

SARATOGA, May 22.--The General Assembly was opened this morning with prayer by the Rev. Dr. Brauns, of Buffalo. The Herman (Penn.) Church case was indefinitely postponed. The appeal of Dr. W. McLane from the Steubenville (Ohio) Presbytery, suspending him from the ministry for heresy, was temporarily laid aside.

WASHINGTON, May 22.--Capt. John P. Walker, Third Cavalry, who was tried by courtmartial on a charge of borrowing money from enlisted men and failing to make payment, has been found guilty and sentenced to be publicly reprimanded. The finding of the court has been approved by Gen. Sherman, and the official order will be promulgated at once.
CHICAGO, May 22.--The leading produce markets were generally rather quiet today and irregularly higher. There was not much doing in any department.

In the interviews of the Boston Traveller with prominent men in Massachusetts, touching the issues of the next campaign, there is a singular agreement of opinion that civil service reform and the tariff will have more than anything else to do with the result.

HARTFORD, May 22.--The April report of the State Board of Health says that diseases of the respiratory organs still maintain the first place upon the mortality lists and are the most prevalent types of sickness pretty uniformly throughout the State. Consumption is perhaps a cause of rather more deaths than the acute forms.

CONCORD, N.H., May 22.--It is stated that the Boston and Maine, the Eastern, and the Boston and Lowell Railroads have formed an alliance to secure legislation beneficial to them at the next session of the Legislature. The Boston and Maine and the Eastern wish a rectification of the recent lease, and the Boston and Lowall desires a general railroad law.

CHICAGO, May 22.--The National Railway Exposition will open Thursday of this week. The sheds blown down by the date Saturday are rapidly being repaired. Engines from the principal locomotive Works in the country are in place, and two of the old engines--one from Nova Scotia and one from Baltimore--have arrived. The Rocket, which was expected, will not come, but the Locomotion ...

LONDON, May 22.--In the chess tournament to-day Mackenzie and Englisch played a drawn game.
NEW-HAVEN, May 22.--The following letter was received to night by a person in the confidence of President Arthur.
PORT HURON, Mich., May 22.--The storm is still raging, accompanied by snow and sleet. The barge Clematis became waterlogged about seven miles out in the lake, off Lakeport.

William Jones was sentenced to imprisonment for three years by Judge Cowing, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, for robbing George Armine of a gold watch and chain, at Waverley-place and Sixth-avenue, on the l2th inst.

Railroad Commissioners Kernan, Rogers, and O'Donnell spent the day in the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday in investigating the complaints of milk-dealers against the NewYork Central Railroad Company. The complaint, which was signed by 24 dealers, was to the effect that this company discriminated against the milk trade in charging 45 cents a can over its tracks.

ST. LOUIS, May 22.--The strike among the coal miners at McAllister and other places on the Missouri Pacific Railway, in the Choctaw Nation, seems to be in fair way of settlement. These miners can only remain in the Territory by obtaining permits from the Indian authorities. This having been explained to the miners a large number of them have signed an agreement to resume ...
ATLANTA, Ga., May 22.--The thermometer touched 44 this morning. The records show that in no previous year has such temperature been experienced within three weeks of the present date.

BALTIMORE, May 22.--A lively controversy is now in progress between the Trustees of the Johns Hopkins University and the hospital regarding the management of the large trust. The trust now amounts to over $7,000,000. The controversy principaliy relates to the university trust, and centres in the action of the majortty of the Trustees in deciding to continue the site of the university within ...

More than $2,000,000 of United States notes and gold and silver certificates were reduced to pulp in the Treasury Department to-day by the macerating process. This is greatly in excess of the average amount destroyed.

The fifty-fourth anniversary of the Brooklyn Sunday-school Union was celebrated in that City, yesterday, by the usual street parade. Notwithstanding the fact that only the schools of the Western District participated in the celebration, there were over 50,000 children in line.

DUBLIN, May 23.--Two more arrests have been made at Castlebar in connection with the recently discovered murder conspiracy in County Mayo. Great excitement exists, and 200 extra members of the Royal Irish Constabulary have been drafted to the town.
Mr. WALTER EVANS, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, presided yesterday over the Kentucky Republican State Convention.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23.--There was a remarkabla scene in the Quarter Sessions Court today during the trial of Thomas W. Lyons for the killing of Chung Wah You, a young Chinese laundryman, which occurred on Feb. 22 last.

LEXINGTON, May 23.--The Kentucky Republican State Convention was called to order to-day by George Denny, Jr., of Lancaster. Capt. W.W. Calbertson, of Ashland, was made temporary Chairman, and Henry Scraggins, (colored,) temporary Secretary.

Louise Guedan, a widow, 60 years old, who manufactured artificial leaves and fruit, was burned to death yesterday at No. 190 Greene-street. She occupied the first and second floors and the rear basement and slept in the work-shop.
SARATOGA, May 23.--At the Presbyterian General Assembly to-day the forty-sixth annnul report of the Board of Foreign Missions was read by the Rev. Dr. Marvin R. Vincent, of New-York.

CHICAGO, May 23.--The conviction is spreading that the schooner Wells Burt, which went down near Chicago with 11 men in Monday's storm, met her fate through a collision with another craft. The Burt was loaded with coal. It is thought from the wreckage washed ashore that she came into collision with a schooner carrying a cargo of merchandise.

The new steam-ship Normandie, of the French line, started on her first trip from this port at 4:20 o'clock yesterday afternoon, having on board 160 cabin passengers, and others making in the aggregate 300.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 23.--The GovernorGeneral, the Marquis of Lorne, and the Princess Louise met the Royal Society of Canade for the Encouragement of Science and Literature in the Senate Chambers to-day.
MOSCOW, May 23.--The ceremony of blessing the imperial flag was performed in the Kremlin to-day in the presence of the Emperor, the Empress, the imperial family, and the Emperor's military household.

ST. LOUIS, May 23.--Heavy frost occurred on Monday and Tuesday nights throughout Southern and part of Central Missouri, and particularly in that section of Illinois swept by tornadoes last Friday night.

CHICAGO, May 23.--The leading produce markets were less active to-day, and averaged lower. Provisions were very weak, with no support from the longs and no demand from outside. Grain was easier on the facts of fine weather and larger receipts, with an equal absence of outside demand.
WASHINGTON, May, 23.--Col. Frank E. Howe, formerly well known as the Pension Agent at New-York and a once prominent member of the Union League Club, died here suddenly today.
TRENTON, May 23.--Philip Hart, a notion dealer in this city has been missing since last Thursday. He left for New-York on that morning and has not returned.

The sub-committee of the Jersey Central income bondholders met at the office of William Alexander Smith, in Wall-street, yesterday, for the purpose of considering the best manner in which to assert their claim for back interest on their bonds.

EPSOM, May 23.--The Derby was won today by St. Blaise, with Highland Chief second and Galliard third. Such a brilliant Derby Day has not been known for years.

MILWAUKEE, May 24.--At a secret meeting of the employes of the immense rolling mills at Bayview, held last night, it was announced that a general strike of the iron-workers of the country would take place June 1, owing to a determination on the part of manufacturers to enforce a reduction all around of 20 per cent in wages.

CHICAGO, May 24.--The leading produce markets were moderately active to-day and generally stronger. The advance was led by wheat, on poor crop advices, and the improvement was made the occasion for selling freely in some other markets, oats breaking under the extra load, especially as receipts were larger. There was an active shipping movement.

LONDON, May 10.--The Prince of Wales just now is very much in the eve of the public. His recent vacation abroad is being well paid for in his extra work at home, for what is generally regarded as pleasure may oftentimes become very hard work.

The Brooklyn bridge was successfully opened yesterday. A fairer day for the ceremony could not have been chosen. The sky was cloudless, and the heat from the brightly shining sun was tempered by a cool breeze.

WASHINGTON, May 24.--Judge-Advocate Barr, who was sent to Philadelphia to make an examination of the judicial proceedings and all the papers in the Nickerson divorce case, has returned to this city and will prepare a report to be submitted to the Adjutant-General within the next few days. The investigation, army officers say, cannot fail to result in a court-martial of Major Nickerson for conduct unbecoming an officer and a gentleman.

NEW-HAVEN, May 24.--The very great advance made by Yale College in mathematical studies is not fully understood by those unfamiliar with this department of college work. Steps recently taken by the instructors in mathematics, to accomplish more and within less time than hitherto are already proving exceedingly acceptable.

GOTHENBURG, May 24.--The arctic exploring vessel Sophia, with Prof. Nordenskjold and other scientists on board, has sailed for Greenland.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 24.--The Spring meeting of the Louisville Jockey Club was continued to-day. The weather being fair and the programme attractive, there was a large attendance, and the betting was active. The track was fairly fast.

LONDON, May 24.--In the House of Commons to-day Lord Edmund Fitzmaurice, Under Foreign Secretary, replying to a question, said he had already stated, on March 19, that the Government had never entertained a scheme to establish a British Resident at the Vatican, and Mr. Errington had not since been a channel of communication between the Foreign Office and the Vatican.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24.--The Times to-morrow will publish an account of a very exciting time enjoyed to-night by the congregation of the Union Baptist Church, on Minister-street, below Sixth. The worshipers at the Union Baptist Church are all colored people.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 7.--A curious change has come over Russia in the last few years. WASHINGTON, May 25.--Lieut.-Col. George H. Elliott, Corps of Engineers, has been ordered to proceed from Newport, R.I., to Clark's Point, New-Bedford, and return, via Wareham, Mass., on public business. The leave of absence on Surgeon's certificate of disability granted Lieut.-Col. John E. Yard, Twenty-fourth Infantry, has been extended three months on Surgeon's certificate of disability.

COLUMBUS, May 25.--The Republican State Convention will meet at Columbus on June 5, and will continue in session for two days. There is so much dependent upon the result of the election in Ohio this year that the Republicans will take ample time for their deliberations.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25.--The political situation in Pennsylvania begins to unfold, The call of the State Convention for July 11 has set in motion much of the machinery of the Republican Party, and it begins to be practicable to form some idea of what may be the outcome of the year's work.

The order excluding guides from the White House grounds, in Washington, was enforced Thursday for the first time.

The male department of the Cooper Union Art Schools held a reception last night in the rooms of the institute. A brass band discoursed music, while large crowds of people viewed the drawings and plaster models on the upper floors. The exhibition was very large, and was declared to be quite as good as anything yet seen at the institute.

George Dana Boardman, D.D., Pennsylvania; VicePresidents--J. Warren Merrill, Massachusetts, and Charles L. Colby, Wisconsin; Recording Secretary --the Rev. H.S. Burrage, Maine.

Officers of the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railway stated yesterday that there would be no postponement of the contemplated opening of that road for traffic between this City and Newburg on June 4. NASHVILLE, Tenn. May 25.--The weather to-day was quite warm, but notwithstanding this the attendance was the largest of the week, fully 5,000 persons being present during the morning and 20,000 in the afternoon. At 10 o'clock the Washington Artillery, of New-Orleans, marched upon the grounds and at once began their drill.

WASHINGTON, May 25.--An accident occurred on the Virginia Midland Railroad last night by which three men were seriously injured. As the fast northward freight train was nearing Shorties Bridge, between Charlottesville and Orange Courthouse, an axle broke, throwing four cars off the track and down an embankment.

The political canvass is opening rather quietly in Pennsylvania, but it will excite considerable interest in consequence of the breach in the Republican ranks which occurred a year ago, and which now seems likely to be healed.

The game last evening at Tammany Hall between Schaefer and Daly was the concluding one of the cushion carom tournament, although the ties yet remain to be played off. Daly, being sure of the championship, and having nothing either to gain or lose, played as if he were practicing, and, although at one time Schaefer seemed to lose his grip, his play, on the whole, was a magnificent exhibition.

PARIS, May 25.--An extensive fire has occurred at Vars, in the Department of the Upper Alps. Fifty houses were destroyed, and several persons perished in the flames.

TRENTON, N.J., May 25.--Judge Nixon filed an opinion in the United States Circuit Court this afternoon, relative to the Hoboken water-front cases. SAN FRANCISCO, May 25.--The steamer Pilot blew up this morning near Lakeville. It is estimated that 18 persons were killed. The first news of the disaster was conveyed in a dispatch saying: "A heavy report was heard this morning from the steamer Pilot and a large escape of steam was seen. I think she is blown up. It looks as though she sank."

LONDON, May 12.--International exhibitions on a grand scale may be said to date from the latter half of the present century. The Prince Consort's name is associated with the first one. WASHINGTON, May 31.--In the star route trial this morning Mr. Merrick began the third day of his address to the jury. He argued that Brady had not the authority claimed by him to consolidate the orders for expedition and increase, and he pointed out how that system had involved great loss to the Government, notably on the Tongue River route.

An important decision was filed by Judge Barrett, in Supreme Court, yesterday, vacating a judgment of deficiency against Dion Boucicault for over $33,000. In the Spring of 1873 James Purssell, being the owner of premises corner of Twentysecond-street and Broadway, in this City, and desiring to build a theatre thereon, applied to Mr. Boucicault for the loan of $20,000.
PARIS, May 31.--The bombardment of the capital of Annam in revenge for the death of Capt. Riviere is probable. It is stated here that several German vessels will leave Kiel for China next week.

The woman who uttered the cries was supposed to have thought the officer was arresting the one who lost her footing.

CHICAGO, May 31.--The leading produce markets were moderately active to-day and generally unsettled. Corn and oats were stronger, while wheat and provisions opened weak, then improved some, but closed easy. There was not a large volume of trading for the last day of the month, most of the June deliveries seeming to have been provided for beforehand. The weather was fine, in one sense, but not warm enough seriously to weaken grain quotations.

OMAHA, Neb., May 31.--Before the Sioux City and Pacific passenger train arrived at Fremont this afternoon Sheriff Gregg received a telephone message to arrest two suspicious characters on the train. The message was from L.D. Shepard, of Arlington, who said he would come on the train and point out the men.

PETERSBURG, Va., June 1.--At a late hour last night Glenroy Henson, colored, keeper of the city hay scales, who lived in the suburbs of this city, was murdered by his step-son, Joseph Henson, a lunatic, who struck him on the head with a fence paling in which there were several nails. The nails penetrated the skull, causing almost instantaneous death. The murderer has been arrested and lodged in jail.

CHICAGO, June 6.--At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railway Company here to-day there were represented 351,424 shares, out of a total stock vote of 419,800.

In the case of William Black and the child John McLaren, who died on May 24 from poisoning at Paterson, the jury yesterday found a verdict of death by the use of poison mixed with their dinner by some person unknown. Most of the witnesses at the inquest were of the opinion that Black poisoned the food.

LONDON, June 6.--This was the second day of the meeting at Ascot Heath. The race for the Ascot Biennial Stakes, for 3-year olds, was won by Mr. J.R. Keese's eh. c. Blue Grass, with Mr. J.H. Houldsworth's ch. f. Lilac second and Mr. E. Weever's br. c. John Jones third.
BOSTON, June 6.--At the annnal meeting of the stockholders of the Vermont and Massachusetts Railroad Company to-day, the old Board of Directors was re-elected.

DUBLIN, June 6.--Quakers residing in Ireland have lately distributed in County Donegal 270 tons of seed potatoes, thus relieving the distress of 3,000 families in that county.

The leaders among Massachusetts Republicans are already exercised over the question how to beat BUTLER next Fall, it being assumed that he will try to secure a re-election.
CHICAGO, June 6.--The leading produce markets were fairly active to-day, with a good deal of individ uality. Provisions fell back to about the lowest point of the previous day, and staid there.

The Brooklyn public schools will close for the Summer season on June 29. The open area in front of the Brooklyn City Hall is to be covered with turf instead of flagging and trees will be planted. Cost, $5,000.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 6.--The most severe storm known here in many years broke upon the city this afternoon. The air was very hot and humid during the morning.
The President to-day appointed William S. Roulhac, of North Carolina, to be Secretary of the Civil Service Commission.
LOUISVILLE, June 6.--This was the thirteenth day of the Jockey Club's Spring meeting. The weather was cloudy and windy, the track fast, and the attendance only moderate.

The special committee of the Board of Aldermen which was appointed to assist Mayor Edson in investigating the accounts and methods of the Finance Department during the years 1879, 1880, 1881, and 1882, met yesterday and began the examination of witnesses. The committee consists of Aldermen Cochrane, Grant, and Wells, with Gen. Cochrane as Chairman.

WASHINGTON, June 7, 1883. The Treasury Department is informed of the arrival at San Francisco of a large cargo of tea consigned to merchants in Chicago, and has directed than samples be forwarded to New-York for inspection before the tea is delivered.

WASHINGTON, June 7.--Senator Van Wyck is determined not to allow the fact that the Fort Niobrara and Rapid City star route was let in disregard of the Senate discussion about it to be lost sight of, and having to-day written a letter to Postmaster-General Gresham on the subject he proposes to bide his time and ventilate the subject in Congress next Winter.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 7.--Thomas L. Shields, who killed Joseph G. Sitton, Superintendent of the Maryland and Charlotte Copper Mines, because, as he alleges, Sitton refused to marry his sister after seducing, her, expresses no regret for what he has done. His only source of solicitude appears to be for his aged father and mother.
The United States steamer Swatara, Commander Coeper, arrived here yesterday after a voyage of five days from Key West. She carries eight guns and 210 officers and men.

A dinner was given at Delmonico's last evening to the Southern gentlemen who have come North to awaken interest in the exposition which will open in Louisville, Ky., on the 1st of August. The representatives include Bishop T.W. Dudley, Senator James B. Beek. John W. Stevenson, Henry Watterson, Charles D. Jacob, Mayor of Louisville; Frank D. Carley, John English Green, and James Sheridan Faulds.

LONDON, May 22.--The English Roman Catholics and many of the better classes of Irish applaud the action of the Pope. At the same time there is among the disaffected classes of Ireland a revolt against the authority of Rome. Dispassionate lookers on are inclined to see in the present aspect of the Irish, question a permanent and serious split betwaen the Papal See and its spiritual subjects.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7.--The Times tomorrow will publish a special report of the launching at Wilmington to-day, from the yards of the Harlan Hollingsworth Company, of the monitor Amphitrite. The event was made specially interesting by a speech by Secretary Chandler, in which he in effect defended the administration of the Navy Departmend by Secretary Robeson.

The annual meeting of the stock and bond holders of the Des Moines and Fort Dodge Railroad Company was held at No. 61 Wall-street yesterday. Arthur B. Graves and Joseph E. Brown were elected to fill vacancies in the Board of Directors, and no changes were made in the excutive offices. The President and Treasurer, Mr. Charles E. Whitehead, made a report as to the financial condition of the company.

The club-house bluff was deserted. There were five races decided, and only two of the favorites won.

WASHINGTON, June 7.--Capt. Michael V. Sheridan, Seventh Cavalry, was this afternoon appointed by the President Major and Assistant Adjutant-General, to fill, the vacancy caused by the death of Gen. Mitchell.

WEST POINT, June 7.--The Board of visitors are continuing their labors and, examining everything connected with the Military Academy. CONCORD, N.H., June 7.--The ceremonies attendant on the inauguration of Gov. Samuel W. Hall to-day attracted an unusually large number of visitors. The display of the State militia and visiting companies was one of the finest ever witnessed here. The Governor was inaugurated at noon.

The Masonic Grand Lodge concluded its labors last evening, after being in harmonious session for three days. Fraternal greetings were received yesterday from the Grand Lodges in Iowa and Washington, and representatives of Grand Lodges in Vermont, Dakota, Texas, and Canada were received. Ex-Judge Dittenhoefer, of a special committee, reported a plan to save the time now lost in Grand Lodge elections.

The marriage of Mr. L.U. Reavis and Miss Rebecca Morrow is definitely announced to take place in the parlors of the Southern Hotel at 4 o'clock Sunday afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Eliot has been invited to perform the ceremony. Mr. Reavia has gone a long time unscathed, but the arrow has struck him hard at last. No lover was ever more devoted in his wooing than Mr. Reavis has been.

The Rev. Father Abelshine, for some years a missienary in China, arrived here yesterday by the steamer Finance, from Rio Janeiro, now lying at Roberts's Stores, Brooklyn. He brought with him his Drivate secretary, a Chinaman named Shin Chin Sun, who is said to be a literary man of no mean ability.

A bill has passed both branches of the Legislature of Pennsylvania which makes ticket specu lating in front of theatres a misdemeanor.

BRIDGEPORT, June 7.--The suit of Alexander Mead against David S. Husted for $20,000 damages for the alleged burning of three of the plaintiff's barns, which has been on trial here since May 22, is drawing to a close. This morping Clarence M. Sterling, of this city, was called to the stand by the defense to testify as an expert upon the subject of light.

ROME, Ga., June 7.--Two years ago the Bank of Rome failed. It was a State depository and held a large sum in State funds. Gov. Colquitt proceeded summarily against the bank and the sureties. Among the latter was Sam Morgan, who asked the Floyd County Court for an injunction, to restrain the Governor from proceeding, alleging that the bond was fradulent.

The champions of both the leading base-ball associations of the country, the Cincinnati and Chicago clubs, were defeated by the Metropolitan and New-York Clubs yesterday. In spite of the rain which fell during the last seven innings both nines played the full number of innings.

The Attorney-General has caused the publication of the papers relating to the Ottman compromise. Long as these papers are, they not only fail to answer some of the questions which curious persons have asked, but they also suggest other questions for which replies must be sought elsewhere.
Black clouds rolled over the Deerfoot Park, where the last day's races of the New-York and Brooklyn Driving Club took place yesterday, but the occasional showers did not interfere with the sport.

PANAMA, MAY 19.--The President of the State of-Boyaca was captured and imprisoned by the State troops, and a pretender installed himself in office. The national Government determined to use the Federal troops against him, and the threat was sufficient. He resigned, and the imprisoned President was reinstated. No lives were lost.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., June 7.--At Mountain Valley last evening, Robert Wallace, while temporarily insane, fired several shots at John Tate, his brother-in-law. Wallace's sister interfered, whereupon he shot her twice, inflicting dangerous wounds. She soon afterward have birth prematurely to a child, and will doubtless die.

DUBLIN, June 7.--The commission opened to-day. Counsel for Gibney, Kingston, and other murder conspirators asked for the discharge of their clients, as they understood that the Crown would not proceed with their trials at the present commission. Counsel for the Crown will reply to-morrow to the request.
BRUSSELS, Jnne 7.--M. Philippart, the Belgian financier who mas arrested in Paris on a charge of forgery and brought back here, has been liberated on 15,000, bail.

CHICAGO, June 7.--To-day's diapatches from New-York relating to J.H. Haverly's financial embarrassments created a sensation here. No one in Chicago knows the "true inwardness" of Haverly's troubles as well as C.H. McConnell, of the National Printing Company. More than a year ago Haverly owed Mr. McConnell an enormous sum for show printing.

The American Fish-cultural Association listened yesterday to a paper by Col. McDonald on the improvements made in the fish-hatching jar. The separation of the dead from live eggs, he said, was formerly done by picking out the dead ones with a forceps, but of late years fish-culture had attained such proportions that hand picking be came impracticable. The siphon had been used, but this system did not prove satisfactory.

WASHINGTON, June 8.--It is said that Lieut.Gen. Sheridan has purchased for $45,000 the residence of Judge Aldis, on Rhode Island-avenue, near the Scott Circle, in this city, and will come here to live in November next, when he will relieve Gen. Sherman of the command of the army. Gen. Sherman expects to leave Washington for his trip to the North-west on the 19th inst., and to return early in October.

What might have been a worse tragedy than that of the Brooklyn bridge very nearly occurred at Chicago the other day. Some 15,000 persons were assembled to witness a performance of BARNUM'S circus, when one of the elephants undertook to vary the entertainment by a special performance not set down on the programme.

The fifth of the open-air concerts which philanthropic citizens in the neighborhood of Washington-square are providing for the liabitues of the pretty little park was given by Cappa's Seventh Regiment Band last evening. The concert began at 5 o'clock, but long before that hour an audience began to gather around the stand, and when the musicians appeared over a thousand people gave them a welcome.

Schedules of Jesse Oakley Co., manufacturers of soap and perfumeries, who recently made an assignment for the benefit of creditors to William H. Ames and Herman N. Vanderpool, were filed in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday.

JAMAICA, Long Island, June 8.--When Mr. Perry Belmont shied his castor into the political ring of the First Congressional District in the Fall of 1880 and asked the Democrats of the district to elect him to the office of Congressman he made Capt. Israel J. Merritt, of Whitestone, Long Island, his political almoner.

The decision rendered in St. Louis by United States Judges McCRARY, LOVE, and TREAT, in relation to the barbed wire suits, although preliminary in its nature, is a very important one, and seems to foreshadow the overthrow of the barbed wire patents, and what the Western farmers and stock-raisers call the great barbed wire monopoly.

Especial care ought to be exercised in proposing amendments to the Constitution of the State, inasmuch as they are likely to be ratified by a light vote and with little consideration unless they involve some question that touches the interests of the people very closely.

Yesterday afternoon Detective Joseph Timmins, of the Hudson River Railroad police, saw Robert Harris, of No. 555 West Forty-second-street, a young thief, who robs railroad cars, slip out of a store kept by John Par, at No. 640 Eleventh-avenue, and get on a freight train which was in motion.

The passenger traffic on the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railway since the opening of the road has been satisfactory. Gen. Winslow said yesterday that the road would be opened to Kingston and the Catskill region on June 25, and on July 9 cars would begin running to Albany, Saratoga, Lake George, and other points north.

EASTON, Penn., June 8.--Both this county and the surrounding country were visited yesterday afternoon by the heaviest thunder-storm known here for years. The residence of Henry Douglass was badly damaged by lightning.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 8.--In the Court of Appeals at noon to-day, Mr. William M. Evarts, on behalf of the Bar, moved that out of respeot to the memory of the late Addison Gardiner, formerly a Judge of this court, the court adjourn.

EASTON, Penn., June 8.--George Holdeman, 70 years old, a farmer living in Bethlehem township, died this morning from injuries received by being dragged by a runaway horse. Holdeman was riding the animal and was thrown from his seat by the animal jumping. His foot caught in the harness and he was dragged 500 yards and terribly injured.

When the annual report of Shipping Commissioner C.C. Duncan was presented to the United States Circuit Court for approval, United States District Attorney Root objected that excessive salaries were paid by the Commissioner to his sons as deputies.

The garden party which was held in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon and evening, for the benefit of the Diet Dispensary of that city, was one of the most brilliant of the series of these social events. In former years they have been held on the grounds of the Barnes family.

CHICAGO, June 8.--The victory won in the Legislature at Springfield to-day in favor of high license creates much enthusiasm among the friends of the measure in this city. It is regarded as the most important legislation which has been accomplished in Illinois in 20 years.

The investigation of the affairs of the Finance Department was continued yesterday by the special committee of the Aldermen. Ex-Disbursing Clerk William C. Emmet testified that he never paid any warrants for interest without the presentation of the coupons. Assistant Deputy Controllor McDaniel described how bonds are issued and how interest coupons are canceled when presented for payment.

CHICAGO, June 8.--William E. Lawrence, Manager of the Red Star Steam-ship Company, today secured the arrest of George C. Sherman for stealing $3,600 of the company's funds. Sherman has been the Passenger Clerk of the company at the Chicago office. In default to bail he was committed to jail.
UTICA, June 8.--The Electors of NewYork will engage next November in the expensive luxury of electing 12 Justices of the Supreme Court to add to the 34 new on that bench.

Mr. Willie Beckwith, the champion swimmer of the world, and his sister, Miss Agnes, who holds the female championship of the same planet, both of whom arrived from England a few days ago, gave an exhibition of their art last evening in the Natatorium, at Nos. 2 and 4 East Forty fifth-street, and their performances were really wonderful.

LAWRENCEVILLE, Ga., June 8.--Elbert M. Stevenson was hanged here at 1 o'clock this afternoon, in the presence of 8,000 people, for the murder of his aunt. The immense concourse of people present at the execution had gathered from six different counties.

The New-York and Metropolitan Clubs were each defeated yesterday. Buffalo took the NewYork League club into camp while the Cincinnati Club managed to win a scratch victory from the "Mets" by close figures of 8 to 7.

Nearly a hundred actors and managers of the City theatres assembled on the stage of Wallack's Theatre yesterday afternoon at the second annual meeting of the Actors' Fund of America. Among those gathered on the stage probably the most venerable was Benjamin Baker, who was years ago stage manager of Mitchell's old theatre.
ROME, June 8.--An article published in the Moniteur de Rome is considered as proving clearly that the Vatican is satisfied with the new Church bill of Prussia.

WASHINGTON, June 8.--The attention of the friends of civil service reform here has been directed to some of the differences between the National Civil Service act and that passed by the New-York Legislature, and it is found that in some respects the State act has been constructed much more reasonably than the other. In the first place, the Commissioners for the State get only $2,000 each a year.

Mr. GLADSTONE's explanation in the House of Commons leaves no doubt, if there was doubt before, that the Pope's declaration against the Land League was procured by the solicitation of a representative of the English Roman Catholics.

After occupying a little more than one day, the trial of Theodore Hoffman for the murder of Zife Marks, the Hebrew peddler, rear Port Chester, on Feb. 1 last, was finished yesterday afternoon in the Westchester County Court of Oyer and Terminer. Justice Barnard presiding.

No approach to a settlement of the affairs of J.H. Haverly, the theatrical manager, had been made last night. At the Brooklyn Theatre matters were doing on as usual. It was stated that Under Sheriff Hodekinson had been unable to attach the house on behalf of Mr. Sheridan Shook, because Mr. Haverly's partner, Mr. McConnell, had at ready levied an attachment on it on account of an unpaid loan of $4,500 made by his brother.

Mr. R.W. Donnell, a wealthy banker of this City, has liberally offered to present to the citizens of St. Joseph, Mo., upon certain easy conditions, valuable hotel property to be converted into an educational institution for female students.

The fair given by the ladies of St. John's Church, Clifton, Staten Island, at the German Club rooms, stapleton, came to an end last evening. Unremitting exertions during the Winter had resulted in the preparation of many pretty things to adorn the stalls, and the beauty and fashion of Staten Island had looked forward to this fair as a social event of no small importance.

Faugh-a-Ballagh, Lord Ellesmere's 6-year-old ch. h. Wallenstein came in second, and Mr. Lefevre's 4-year-old b.c. Credo third. Mr. Vyner's 5-year-old ch. h. Hagicscope also ran.

The members of the party are the Hons. N.E. Harris, of Macon; F.P. Rice, of Atlanta; M.V. Calvin, of Augusta; W.A. Little, of Columbus; R.F. Watts, R.B. Russell. W.A. Wilson, Thomas Eason and W.N. The Director of the St. Paul and Northern Pacific Railraod met in the company's office in this City yesterday and elected the following offcers: Henry Villard, President; Edward D. Adams, Vice-President: George S. Jones, Secretary and Treasurer.

There was an extra ripple of excitement in the Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon when the announcement was publicly made that the firm of Vanderhoof, Morrison Co., brokers, at No. 36 New-street, had given notice of their temporary suspension.

Superintendent Witt, of the German Hospital, yesterday informed Coroner Kennedy by telegraph of the death at that institution of Carl F.W. Hosehke, a German, from what was supposed to be typhoid fever, and added that the widow of the deceased had stated that his sickness was due to partaking of diseased and unwholesome meat.

"Hair Singeing, 25 Cents," is the somewhat novel sign displayed in the window of a South Broad-street barber's shop. The interior of the shop is decorated with half a dozen more of the signs, and two knights of the razor and a colored boy fanned themselves and waited for customers.

LONDON, June 11.--In the House of Lords to-day, the bill legalizing marriage with a deceased wife's sister passed its second reading by a vote of 165 to 158. The Prince of Wales, the Duke of Connaught, and the Duke of Albany voted for the bill, and the 2 Archbishops and 19 Bishops voted against it.

The first witness examined yesterday by the committee of the Aldermen which is investigating the affairs of the Finance Department was Edward Morrison. He testified that in the Spring of 1879 "A.C. Bennett" offered to sell him some coupons. The witness sent to the Finance Department and found the coupons were genuine, and then he purchased them, paying cash.

Many persons went on the bridge wearing hats yesterday afternoon who came off without them. A stiff breeze was blowing. Its force was most felt about the towers, where it swept the huge network of wires with a rushing sound. Every one felt the heavy sweep of the wind as soon as a point above the housetops was reached on either approach.

WASHINGTON, June 11.--Second Assistant Postmaster-General Elmer's award of the Niobrara and Deadwood star route contract to John R. Miner, which has been extensively noticed and criticised, is defended in a column and a half article in the Administration organ to-day.

TROY, June 11.--Trouble has been brewing here between the union and non-union molders since the Malleable Iron-works displaced their employes with non-union men, and it culminated this afternoon in a bloody fight between the factions on Ida Hill, which has already resulted in the death of one man, while it is not unlikely that others may die of injuries received in the melee.

If Gov. BUTLER feels any soreness at his failure to receive a degree from Harvard University honoris causa, it is doubtless somewhat soothed by the invitations which he has received to be the guest of other distinguished institutions at their coming festivities.

The New-York Club is keeping up the heavy batting that characterized last week's games, and yesterday defeated the strong-batting team from Buffalo. With the exception of the eighth inning, the nickel-plate nine played a model fielding game, and up to that point had confined the score of the visitors from Niagara Falls to a solitary run.

BERLIN, June 11.--The different factions in the Landtag have agreed upon the special committee to be appointed to consider the new Church bill. The Government journals maintain that the bill is not a concession to the Roman curia, but is framed in the interests of the monarchy itself.

The regular monthly meeting of the Presbytery of New-York was held yesterday afternoon in the lecture-room of the Scotch Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. R.R. Booth, of the University-Place Church, asked for a dissolution of his pastoral relations with his congregation on account of ill-health.

The meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club begins to-day with a varied programme, consisting of six races, in which 61 horses are entered. Nearly all of the 760 Irish immigrants who arrived do Monday by the Anchor Line steamer Belgravia left this City last evening. Those who remained were a few single girls for whom situations had been provided in New-York. These immigrants, who were assisted in reaching this country by a grant of $25 each from the British Government, form one of a number of parties which are being sent to America.

WASHINGTON, June 12.--The Civil Service Commission has completed most of its arrangements for beginning the examination of applicants for places in the Government service. Blank forms of application for admission to the service have also been printed, and can now be had at the rooms of the commission here or from the local examining boards.

The Continental Guards, the crack corps of New-Orleans, arrived in New-York at 4:30 P.M. yesterday, and took the Fall River boat for Boston. A number of officers of the Seventy-first Regiment were on hand at the station in Jersey City to receive them, and escorted them to the foot of Murray-street, whence they took their departure for the East.

Chalmers came to this city and early inaugurated a movement to secure the indorsement of his political course.

Jacob Schaefer, the champion billiardplayer of the world, and Maurice Vignaux, the famous French expert, crossed cues in the Academy of Music last evening in a match game at balk-line billiards, 800 points up, for a stake of $1,000. The contest was exceedingly interesting and resulted in a decisive viotory for the Frenchman. William Sexton was chosen referee and George H. Ellis acted as market.

BIRMINGHAM, Conn., June 20.--About 11 o'clock last night John Dyer, the watchman for the Derby Building and Lumber Company, went to his home near by to get something to eat. Upon his return, 15 minutes later, he found four masked men seated on the office steps.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 20.--The Society of American Civil Engineers this morning discussed the question of the cost of steam power. Numerous papers were read. This afternoon members of the convention were entertained by ex-Gov. Washburn, at Lake Minnetonka.

CHICAGO, June 20.--A motion was made today before Judge Blodgett to file the transcript of the record from the State court in the quo warranto case of the people against R.C. Clowry and the other officers of the Western Union Telegraph Company.
The June meeting of the Gentlemen's Driving Association was opened yesterday most auspiciously. The weather was warm, but not hot enough to prevent the horses doing their best.

CHICAGO, June 20.--Emily Thole and Catherine Baumgarten, of Pittsburg, Penn., were arrested to-day, charged with child-stealing. They had partially succeeded in abducting two orphans named Engie, when they were taken into custody. The children have a fortune awaiting them in Germany. They were to be taken to Pittsburg, where an aunt resides. The case will be investigated by the Humane Society.

AURORA, N.Y., June 20.--The concluding exercises of Wells College Commencement were held here to-day. The attendance upon the exercises has steadily increased with the arrival of every train. The graduates are Miss Rosa W. Pickett, Geneva, N.Y.; August A. Ogden, Kings Ferry, ...

DES MOINES, June 20.--The trouble between the law class and the State University was settled late yesterday afternoon by the letting off of all the students but one, R.H. Hawkins, of Marysville, Kan., who was asked, "Were you at the indignation meeting?" and replied that he was not.

Among the passengers of the Cunard steamship Scythia, which sailed yesterday afternoon for Liverpool, were the Baroness Gevers, Gen. and Mrs. I.S. Catlin, the Rev. Dr. John R. Paxton, of this City, and Col. Alexander Moore.

Miss Artelia De Leyer, daughter of Mrs. Margaretta De Leyer, and a descendant of the old French family of that name in this City, was married to Mr. Thomas F. Keating last evening at St. Leo's Church, on East Twenty-eighth-street.

CHICAGO, June 20.--A decree of court was entered to-day permitting Mrs. Frances Maria Scoville, sister of Charles J. Guiteau and the divorced wife of George Scoville, to change her name to Frances Maria Howe.

The track at Brighton Beach yesterday was very heavy, but the racing was nevertheless of exceptional brilliancy, especially so in the third and fourth races. Only one favorite came off victorious during the day, and consequently the pool dividends were large to the holders of winning tickets.
The thirty-eighth Commencement of St. John's College took place yesterday afternoon at Fordham.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 20.--The thirty-third annual Commencement exercises of the University of Rochester were held in the First Baptist Church this morning.

TORONTO, Ontario, June 20.--A young and wealthy farmer named Kesler this morning led to the alter, the belle of the village of Norham, Minnie Campbell. The couple started from Campbellford to drive to the bride's home. The bridal fell off the spirited team, which ran away, and the bride, in attempting to jump, fell on her head, breaking her neck. Death was instantaneous.

NEW-LONDON, June 20.--During the night a heavy fog prevailed, and until 9:30 o'clock this morning it looked as if the boat-race between Harvard and Columbia Colleges would have to be postponed.

In his address at the unveiling of a monument to the Confederate dead at Camden, S.C., Senator HAMPTON made an eloquent appeal yesterday for a full reconciliation between the sections once divided by civil strife.

ALBANY, June 20.--John L. Sullivan, slugger champion, had a fight to-day in Riverside Park with "Steve" Taylor. "Steve" fell out like a nut from a tree. The time was six minutes. A crowd of 1,000 persons was present, but the gate money was trifling, some persons say ...

MADISON, Wis., June 20.--At 8 o'clock this morning Dr. W.W. Daniells, Professor of Chemistry in the State University, took a heavy dose of what he supposed was quinine. Half an hour afterward he felt symptoms of strychnine. A hurried consultation of physicians was had. He was pumped out, and survived one spasm. He is now under the influence of opiates.

SHAWNEETOWN, Ill., June 20.--The boiler of the saw mill of Behymer, Holbrook Sitles, on the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad, seven miles above this city, backed out from its moorings to-day, tore a pile of lumber into fragments, was deflected by a pile of sawdust, tearing up the switch and throwing the main track several feet out of line. Eight men were standing at the front and sides, but not one was injured.

The gossips of the village of Jamaica, Long Island, are wagging their tongues over the sudden disappearance of Victor Murro, a lively village youth, and more particularly over the cause of his mysterious fight.

The firm of R.H. Parks Co., stock, cotton, and grain brokers, at No. 13 New-street, which suspended on Tuesday, gave notice to the Stock Exchange yesterday that they had settled all of their differences in the Exchange.
TOLEDO, Ohio, June 20.--This was the second day of the Summer meeting of the Tri-State Trotting Association. The attendance was fair, the weather fine, and the track in good condition.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 20.--The seventysixth annual Commencement of the University of Tennessee occurred to-day. The exercises were held in the Opera-house, which was filled with the largest audience that ever assembled at a Commencement in Knoxville.

MONTREAL, June 20.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Merchants' Bank was held to-day. The report of the Directors and the statement of accounts showed a most prosperous condition of affairs. General Manager Hague re viewed the situation, referring specially to the bank's immunity from losses during the year. He spoke hopefully of the North-west, where the bank is very largely represented.

It is claimed that the section added by the Republican Central Committee to the plan of reorganization reported by the Committee of Eighteen will give all Republican voters an opportunity to vote for delegates to the State Convention and thereby exert their power upon the selection of members of the next State Committee.
BRIDGEPORT, June 20.--The sixth annual Spring shoot and opening of the new Readmoor Rifle Range by the Bridgeport Rifle Club took place to-day.
Macomb's Dam Bridge, over the Harlem River, is a rickety old structure, and its vibrations when crowded with vehicles and people are alarming.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 20.--The Williamson Stewart Paper Company have made an assignment to J.P. White. Their assets are $152,000, subject to a deed of trust for nearly $100,000.

The game started at 12:30 o'clock with the home team at the bat.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., June 20.--M.J. Kinder, a prominent lime-dealer of this city, went home intoxicated last night, and after having hot words with his young wife attempted to shoot her with a revolver. He fired four shots. The third, fired just as she grappled with him, went downward into his thigh. Mrs. Kinder was uninjured. The affair caused great excitement here to-day.
There is considerable excitement among silkdealers over a sudden rise in the price of raw silk. This is due principally to a failure of the crop in China.

OMAHA, Neb., June 20.--In the United States court to-day a verdict for about $50,000 was rendered in favor of A.S. Patrick, of Omaha, against Erwin Davis, of New-York, upon a contract on the Flagstaff Mine, Utah.

There were not many visitors yesterday at the rose and strawberry exhibition of the NewYork Horticultural Society, in Horticultural Hall, but those who were present enjoyed a fresh display of the varieties of flowers that were awarded prizes on Tuesday.

The races of homing pigeons from Steubenville, Ohio, to this vicinity, yesterday, were the success of the season, the speed being the best on record for American birds.

ST. LOUIS, June 20.--The St. Louis Jockey Club continued its meeting to-day. ST. LOUIS, June 20.--At all the chief point the Missouri River is reported as still rapidly rising. It is now up to the high-water mark of 1881. In the last 12 hours it has risen six inches. All the bottom lands are flooded, and the people are moving out.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., June 20.--A negro boy named Jim Ball, age 18, attempted to outrage the 11-year-old daughter of Mr. Edgar Lee, in Fairfax County, yesterday.

A dividend of 3 per cent. on the preferred stock of the St. Paul and Duluth Railroad has been declared, payable at the Fourth National Bank of New-York July 2. The books of the company were closed in St. Paul and opened in this City yesterday.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, June 20.--Caterpillars in great numbers have appeared in Colchester and other neighboring counties, and have been in such masses on the railway tracks as to impede trains.

PROVIDENCE, June 20.--In the League championship game to-day between the New-York and the Providence Clubs, the umpire, Decker, did wretched work.

FAYETTE, Mo., June 20.--E.L. Stewart, the aeronaut, made an ascension here on Monday in an old hot-air balloon, which burst when it had attained the height of about 2,000 feet. The balloon and aeronaut came down with a rush, and both plunged into the Bonne Femme Creek and at once disappeared. Stewart's body was recovered.

CHICAGO, Ill., June 20.--Alexander Sullivan, President of the Irish National League, declares that the published accounts of his speech at the Parnell meeting here on Saturday night were incorrect in one essential, viz.: He made no allusion to the Pope or propaganda circular.

JOLIET, Ill., June 20.--The mortality among the cows in this vicinity is becoming heavier every day, and many people are afraid to use milk for any purpose. It is supposed that their death is caused by eating a small bug which appears on the grass and is very poisonous. Those who own valuable animals are keeping them in their stables.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 20.--J. Alexander Shriver, of Baltimore, delegate to the International Exhibition of Holland, at Amsterdam, will sail to-morrow on the steamer Braunschweig from this port. He will be accompanied by his son, John S. Shriver, as Secretary, and Mrs. Shriver and Miss Pigman. Mr. Shriver is the only delegate appointed by the President of the United States to that exhibition.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 20.--The closing part of the Princeton College Commencement exercises began at 9 o'clock in the First Presbyterian Church, Dr. McCosh presiding and the Trustees and members of the Faculty occupying seats on the platform.

CINCINNATI, June 20.--A large number of persons attended the races at Chester Park to-day. Owing to the narrowness of the track the first race was split in two, making two distinct races of a mile each.

BRANCHVILLE, N.J., June 20.--George C. Heald, 19 years old, was drowned in Long Swamp last evening. Heald was a son of Charles G. Heald, of Cooperstown, N.Y. Accompanied by several young men, Heald was bathing in the swamp and was taken with cramps, sinking before his companions could reach him. The body has not yet been recovered.
The opinion prevails even among the least censorious people that homicide is a worldly diversion, and as such should be shunned by ministers of the Gospel.

GREENVILLE, June 20.--The boiler of an engine attached to a thrashing-machine on Robert Williams's place exploded to-day. Seven men who were standing close to the machine were seriously wounded. Ned McBrayer, the engineer, and a colored man were fatally hurt. Two others are expected to die.

NORWICH, June 21.--A solitary thunderbolt that fell in the west part of this city during a recent shower produced an extraordinary effect. About 5:30 o'clock in the afternoon an unusually heavy black cloud that had rolled up in the northwest was sent by a contrary wind into wild streamers of whirling vapor.
ATLANTA, Ga., June 21.--A few weeks ago Galveston passed Savannah and took rank next to New-Orleans and usurped Savannah's place as the second cotton port in the country.

The new American Yacht Club, an organization founded by Mr. JAY GOULD for the promotion of steam yachting, is about to have a regatta, and as a matter of course finds itself confronted with the problem of time allowance.

COLUMBUS, June 21.--The expected has again happened, and Judge George Hoadly has been made the Democratic nominee for Governor of Ohio; but if the charges made by leading Ward men in the convention are true, there will always be a cloud upon his title.

TRENTON, N.J., June 21.--A few weeks ago the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, filed a bill in the United States Circuit Court, in this city, setting forth that an agreement had been entered into between it and the Central Railroad of NewJersey by which the Pennsylvania was permitted to run trains over the New-York and Long Branch Road to the sea-shore.
The fifth day of the meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club was a great success, both in point of attendance and the character of the racing.

Frederick Gillis, a colored waiter, employed in a billiard saloon on West Twenty-third-street, angered at the relations existing between his wife Maria and a boarder named David Lee, made an attack upon them early yesterday morning with a revolver and shot them both.

CHICAGO, June 21.--A special to the Tribune from Redfield, Dakota, says: "Several parties at work on a farm four and a half miles south of Redfield have discovered an old fort, which occupied nearly two acres, and from which nearly 200 human skulls have been exhumed.
WASHINGTON, June 21.--Secretary Chandler to-day issued the following circular relating to proposals for the purchase of condemned Government vessels:

ST. LOUIS, June 21.--Gradually rising, at the rate of about six to eight inches a day, the Mississippi, swollen with the added waters of the booming Missouri, has at last attained a height which threatens grave disaster to the city and to the surrounding country.

Members of the New-York Yacht Club and their wives, sweethearts, friends, admirers, cousins, office boys, and followers, to the number of more than 5,000, went down the Bay yesterday to sail and to see the annual regatta.

Sherman, the day before leaving Washington on his tour through the North-west, wrote a letter explaining the necessity which called him from the city almost at the moment of Gen. Charles Ewing's death and paying the following tribute to the character and public services of his dying comrade:

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 21.--This city is somewhat excited over a bold robbery committed last Monday night, when a box containing securities to the amount of several thousand dollars mysteriously disappeared from the residence of the widow of the late Judge Sickles, an elderly lady of wealth, Knickerbocker connections, and high social position, who is related to ex-Senator Roscoe Conkling. The family retired at an early hour.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., June 21.--Charles H. Brown and Henry D. Maynard are two young men of about 27 years of age, claiming to reside in Rochester, whose adventures on the road have been to-day the subject of examination in the Niagara Sessions, before Judge Davis and a jury.

RICHMOND, June 21.--Warrents were issued this morning for the arrest of Richard F. Beirne, editor of State, an afternoon paper, and W.C. Elam, editor of the Whig, on a charge that they were about to break the peace by engaging in a duel.

The second day of the Spring trotting meeting under the auspices of the Gentlemen's Driving Association was a repetition, in so far as a pleasant day, a good track, spirited contests, and a good attendance go, of the first day.
The fiftieth Commencement of the University of the City of New-York took place in the Academy of Music yesterday. The audience was a large one.

CHICAGO, June 21.--Provisions were less active and again irregular to-day, but averaged stronger. Pork advanced 20 cents, receded 17 cents, again improved 20 cents, and fell off at the close of 'Change to about the latest prices of Wednesaay, being $16.87 bid for July and $17 bid for August.
WASHINGTON, June 21.--Mr. Murch again took the stand to-day in the Hill investigation, and was cross-examined.

The White Star steam-ship Celtic, which sailed yesterday for Liverpool, took out among other passengers the Baron de Meysenbug, Austrian Consul at New-Orleans, and Dr. William Owen Pughe. The complete cabin list of the Celtic is appended:
