The thirty-seventh annual Commencement of the Mount St. Vincent Academy, which occurred yesterday afternoon, was very largely attended by the Catholic clergy and laity of this City.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 21.--A few weeks ago the ordinance forbidding sparring-matches within the city limits was repealed.

The Queen of Roumania has written an opera, the music for which she has invited the Swedish composer Hallstrom to compose. She writes under the name of Carmen Silvia. The action of the piece is laid in Roumania.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 21.--The Newport season is opon. Signs of local prosperity are seen upon every hand. Elegant equipages block the principal business thoroughfare, and they frequently come in collision with the tradesmen's turnouts. The moist weather of late has done much for the place from a natural point of view.
LONDON, June 21.--The Government have announced their intention to abandon the Criminal Procedure bill for the present session.
An English ship-owner is endeavoring to raise money to erect a monument to the late Capt. Raphael Semmes, to be placed on American soil.

STATE CAMP OF INSTRUCTION, PEEKSKILL, June 21.--After the blazing sun and fatiguing duties of yesterday, the sounding of the "taps" at 10:30 last night was a welcome signal, and in a few minutes the lights were extinguished and silence reigned throughout the camp.

CHICAGO, June 21.--The feeling at the close of business on Change to-day was still very uneasy. Many operators have held off, afraid to touch anything. The trading done was in small, insignificant lots.

The new Board of Trustees of the Brooklyn bride, which is composed of the same gentlemen as the old board, held its first meeting yesterday afternoon.

Mr. John S. Washburn, the Quaker farmer, whose residence near Chappaqua, Westchester County, was entered and robbed by masked burglars on Tuesday night, was able to give some additional details of the affair yesterday when called on by a reporter to those published in yesterday's TIMES.

MOBILE, Ala., June 14.--Father Ryan says his feet know more of the humble steps that lead to the altar then of the stops that lead up to Parnassus and the home of the muses. And souls are always more to him than song.

An agreement has been prepared, and will probably be formally executed in a few days, by which existing differences between the bondholders and junior securities of the New-York City and Northern Railroad will be amicably settled and the road taken out of Receiver Leary's hands.

Dr. JOHN HALL'S address at the Commencement of the so-called "University of the City of New-York" sounded like the swelling prologue to a more imperial theme than the graduation of six Bachelors of Arts and eleven Bachelors of Science.

ITHACA, June 21.--The closing exercises of the fifteenth annual Commencement of Corell University occurred to-day. Beside President White there were seated upon the platform the Hon. Erastus Brooks, ex-Gov. Cornell, the Hon. Stewart L. Woodford, Senator Merrill, the Trustees, and Faculty.
The first step in the abolition of dueling at the South appears to have been taken by two young men at present residing in Kings Mountain, N.C., and until recently paying court to a local young lady.
The Governor of Massachusetts is by profession a lawyer, and many interesting stories are told about his labors in defense of persons accused of crime.

CLINTON, June 21.--The usual harmony and happiness attending the approach of Commencement at Hamilton College are disturbed this year by an unpleasantness attending the competition for the Clark prize.

BELLE VERNON, Penn., June 21.--Warehouses Nos. 2 and 3, attached to John Gibson Sons' distillery, at Gibsonton, Penn., together with 10,000 barrels of whisky, were totally destroyed by fire this afternoon.
ST. LOUIS, June 21.--The Metropolitans changed their luck to-day by putting away their old blue stockings and white caps, and coming out with a blue head-gear and hosiery of pure white.
The Canada Southern Railway Bridge over Niagara River is to be built at a point about 300 feet above the present suspension bridge.

TRENTON, N.J., June 21.--Fuller particulars of the tornado at Penn's Manor, in Bucks County, Penn., on Tuesday afternoon, show it to have been as violent as many of the recent Western cyclones. The gale came up about 4'o clock, approaching the manor from the south-west.
CONCORD, N.H., June 21.--Another vote for Senator to-day showed that Rollins's forces are steadily losing.

The failure of McGEOCH and his accomplices to carry through their conspiracy to corner the lard market at Chicago not only brought disaster to themselves but drove to the wall others who were only indirectly concerned with their operations.
HAMILTON, N.Y., June 21.--The Commencement exercises at Hamilton University were held to-day. Alumni Hall was filled with spectators.

The sale at auction of between twenty and thirty vessels of the navy on the ground that they are unseaworthy and not worth repairing naturally attracts attention to the miserable condition of our naval establishment. It is, however, the first step toward building a respectable navy.

WASHINGTON, June 22.--senator Dan Voorhees, who is in this city, had an interview last night with a reporter of the Critic, and he talked along on several political topics with great freedom and entire disregard, apparently, of the effect his opinions might have upon his own chances for becoming the candidate of the Democrats for President.

BOSTON, June 22.-- Two well-contested trotting events to-day closed the June meeting at Beacon Park. The attendance was very large and the track was in first-elass condition.

Dr. Herrick Johnson, formerly Professor of Sacred Rhetoric and Pastoral Theology in the Presbyterian Theo logical Seminary, at Auburn, N.Y., and for the past three years Pastor of the Fourth Presbyterian Church of this city, has accepted the Professorship in the Theological Seminary in Chicago, and will tender his resignation of the pastorate Sunday morning.

BROCKVILLE, Ontario, June 22.--A west-bound express on th Grand Trunk Railway left the rails just east on this station this evening. The express, baggage, and postal cars were badly smashed, and two first-class coaches and a Pullman car were tipped partly over, but were not much damaged. The dining car alone kept on the track. Only one passenger, an old lady named Friar, was injured. The accident was caused by the spreading of the rails.

CHICAGO, June 27.--The leading produce markets were active to-day and very irregular, but averaged heavy. Provisions were weak, and wheat followed suit, while corn held up for a while, and then succumbed to sympathy with hog product.

HANOVER, N.H., June 27.--Gov. Butler's friends have failed to secure for him the degree of LL.D. It has not been for want of hard work and urgent importunities by his friends, who, by letter and personal solicitation, have urged the Trustees to give him the degree. MILWAUKEE, June 27.--An old and interesting case, which has occupied the attention of Judges and juries for years, and is still unsettled, was revived in the United States Circuit Court in this city this morning.

LINCOLN, N.H., June 22.--I started Thursday, 21st, on a business trip to Lincoln. Arriving at Plymouth, I learned that the Pemigewasset Vallev Railroad was washed out and no trains could run for several days.

Alderman Hadley, of London, after several weeks of negotiation in this country, has at length completed what he regards as most satisfactory arrangements for the laying and operation of a new cable line between England and America.

The Governing Committee of the New-York Stock Exchange listed an unusually large number of securities yesterday. The meeting was the last one of the Summer, the time for the next regular meeting being the second Wednesday of September.

WASHINGTON, June 27.--Ever since Gen. Arthur became President there has been more or less pressure brought to bear from time to time upon the Executive to secure the removal from office of Postmaster Pearson, of NewYork.

There has been a good deal of chaff about the pomposity with which the two editors in Richmond have, or rather have not, gone to war with each other, and many playful imputations on their good faith have been made by a satirical press.

NEW-HAVEN, June 27.--At the Yale College Commencement exercises to-day honorary degrees were conferred as follows: D.D., the Right Rev. John Williams, D.D., LL.D., of Middletown, Conn., Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Connecticut; the Rev. A.S. Twombly, of Boston, Yale, '54.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 27.--The removal of Revenue Collector Stivers by the consolidation of this district with the Fourteenth excites very general regret. His long administration of the office has been entirely satisfactory both to the department and to the public.

Mayor EDSON has sat down with greatpromptness and decision upon the Aldermanic resolution that all mechanics and skilled and unskilled laborers in the employment of the City shall have a weekly half holiday with pay. Last week this resolution, offered by President REILLY, went ...

The assembly-room in the Primary Department of Grammar School No. 59, in East Fiftyseventh-street, was crowded yesterday by the relatives and friends of the pupils invited to witness the closing exercises or the department, of which Mrs. Mary E. Perley is the Principal.

The Republican Convention of Iowa, which assembled yesterday, was an extremely harmonious body. There were no contested delegations; there was no dispute over the organization; the nominations for Governor and State administrative officers were made by acclamation, and that for Judge with only two ballotings.
It appears likely that we are to come pretty promptly now to an end of the trade dollar nuisance which has so long been tolerated for lack of concerted action to get rid of it.

BOSTON, June 27.--The Commencement exercises at Harvard today and the Alumni dinner were attended by larger numbers of graduates and others than usual, all on account of Gov. Butler. He was the conspicuous feature, outshining all others.
NEW-LONDON, June 27.--Up to 6 o'clock this evening there was a good deal of doubt here as to which was the bitter Freshmen crew, Harvard's or Columbia's, but there is no such doubt now.

The closest match yacht-race that has been sailed for many years in the waters hereabout took place over the Knickerbocker Yacht Club course yesterday between tha Gracie, owned by Mr. William R. Morse, and Mr. John W. Thorp's yacht the Nettie Thorp.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 27.--An Austrian staff officer has been arrested near Warsaw. He had in his possession strategic plans of the River Bug.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 27.--The people residing in the north-eastern section of the city, known as the Five Points, were startled this morning by the report that a portion of the district which caved in last Fall was giving away through the action of the rain-fall of yesterday and last night.
The closing exercises of Colored School No. 3, in West Forty-first-street, between Seventh and Eighth avenues, will take place at 10:30 o'clock.

NORWICH, June 28.--The project undertaken by the Baptist societies of this State to purchase a tract of land at Niantic Beach, 10 miles west of New-London, on Long Island Sound, to be used as a Summer watering-place where the Baptist Sunday-school workers of Connecticut might prosecute their labors in unison and with better organization, has resulted in perfect success.

LONDON, June 28.--Mr. Trevelyan, Chief Secretary for Ireland, replying in the House of Commons this afternoon to a question by Mr. Cowen as to whether it was true that pauper emigrants had been sent to America with the knowledge and consent of the Government, said the reports about the landing of paupers in America were greatly exaggerated.

The address of CHARLES FRANCIS ADAMS, Jr., before the Phi Beta Kappa Society at Cambridge yesterday was one of those wholesome invasions upon the traditions of the place which that association from time to time gives an opening for.

The dancing hall of the notorious Billy McGlory, known as Armory Hall, at No. 166 Hesterstreet, was the scene last night of a mysterious shooting affair for which their appears to have been no provocation.
CHICAGO, June 28.--The Tribune has crop specials from many grain and fruit sections of the North-west. From Dakota reports are that all kinds of grain are looking finely and the weather is favorable.

CHICAGO, June 28.--The loading produce markets were active to-day, and very badly unsettled, with great weakness. They fell to a lower point than that touched a fortnight ago, but turned steadier, and looked at the close as if the bears had called a halt, at least for the present.
Mr. Charles Francis Adams, Jr., delivered an address before the Harvard Chapter of the fraternity of the Phi Beta Kappa in Sanders's Theatre, Cambridge, Mass., yesterday.

Robert L. Cutting, Jr., was on the stand yesterday in the Marie-Garrison suit, before Referee Theodore W. Dwight. He testified that he became acquainted with the other plaintiffs in 1876, when they together hold 36,000 shares of the steek of the Pacific Railway of Missouri.
HARTFORD, June 28.--Twenty-five or thirty years ago Cornelius J. Vanderbilt used to come to Hartford frequently to loon after property belonging to his father, the old Commodore.
WASHINGTON, June 28.--Secretary Lincoln has received a dispatch from Gen. Crook stating that he will arrive in Washington about July 4.

At the meeting of the Emigration Commissioners yesterday, Mr. Stephenson said the committee of which he was Chairman had waited upon the Attorney-General of the State and asked whether the commission was acting under the old law or the one passed at the last session of the Legislature. The Attorney-General had promised to give his opinion in the matter.

When the National Convention of Master Plumbers was called to order in Masonic Hall, yesterday morning, by Chairman W.E. Foster, of Norfolk, Va., the room was only one-quarter filled, but as the day progressed the attendance gradually increased.
DES MOINES, June 28.--Some of the rabid Prohibitionists say they would have liked the resolutions of the Republican convention better if they had been a little stronger.

Forty-three young men were graduated from the College of the City of New-York last evening. The Commencement exercises, the thirty-first in the history of the college, attracted to the Academy of Music a throng of relatives and friends of the graduates and of the institution that completely filled it.

LEXINGTON, Va., June 28.--Valentine's recumbent figure of Gen. Robert E. Lee was unveiled here to-day in the presence of 6,000 persons. Gen. Wade Hampton acted as Chief Marshal and Gen. George Stewart as Assistant Marshal.
WILKESBARRE, June 28.--Vast crowds of people to-day visited the scene of yesterday's disaster at Five Points.
LONDON, June 28.--The Standard's correspondent at Rome says the Pope is indisposed. He is much disturbed by the state of affairs in Ireland and France.

When the steamer Granite State was burned at Goodspeed's there was deposited in the safe of the boat about $75 in greenbacks and national bank notes, also one solitary silver dollar. This money was the savings of the deck-hands on the steamer, and had been placed in the hands of the purser for safe keeping.
Edwin R. Kirk, a sail-maker doing business at No. 195 West-street, and residing in Hoboken N.J., told Inspector Byrnes, Tuesday, of the manner in which he had been swindied.
Referee John C. Gray has reported to the Supreme Court that in his opinion Mary Alice Tearie is entitled to an absolute divorce from George Osmond Tearle, loaning man at Wallack's Theatre.
The Hon. Perry Belmont has been made a member of the Art Committee of the Southern Exposition.

COLUMBUS, June 28.--The Supreme Court to-day gave out its opinion on the Scott liquor tax law, holding it to be valid and constitutional, except the second section, wherein it is held not to apply to leases executed prior to the passage of the act, as no contract made can be violated.
CHICAGO, June 28--Archbishop Feehan and Chancellor Gill arrived home yesterday from Nashvilie. Ten n., where they have been participating in the ceremonies of installine the new Bishop.

The plumbers who have been in convention in this City for two days have grievances against three classes of persons--the dealers in plumbers' materials, the writers for the public press, and the sanitary engineers.
The final resting-place of the late President Garfield, and the site for one of the grandest monuments ever erected in the United States, has at last been determined upon.

On Saturday evening last, when crossing on the Union Pacific transfer from Omaha to Council Bluffs, I noticed the conductor having a controversy with a poorly clad but honest-appearing young man--evidently a day laborer--about his ticket, or, I should say, the change he had received with his ticket.

NEW-LONDON, June 28.--The Harvard-Yale race is over, and Harvard has given Yale a layingout that will last for a twelvemonth at least, and will very likely prove the death of the miserable jerky stroke pulled by the Yale crew.
James Hearne, the steward of the Century Club, an organization mainly composed of artists and literary men, which has its house in East Fifteenth-street, was dismissed from its service June 18.

STATE CAMP OF INSPECTION, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 28.--Last night was the most dismal, dreary, and wretched the encampment has experienced this year.

Yesterday was an exciting day at the Sheepshead Bay course. The crowd was large and the betting very heavy. The first, fifth, and last races were great surprises for the knowing ones, while "Plunger" Walton received a severe set-back and lost over $25,000 during the day.
ST. PAUL, June 28.--Last night's session of the Republican State Convention was protracted. At midnight not half the ticket had been completed.

Referring to the dispute between BISHOP, the "mind reader," and Mr. LABOUCHERE, the Pall Mall Gazette remarks that the only committee whose investigations of the performances of spirit mediums and "mind readers" would be worth anything would be a committee of conjurers.
The Post Office Department is once more called upon to decide how far a lottery can be considered a lawful institution and entitled to the privileges of the United States Postal Service.

SCHNECTADY, N.Y., June 28.--When President Potter handed a neatly tied package to one of the Seniors of Union College on the Commencement stage yesterday, everybody supposed the graduates had received their diplomas.
WASHINGTON, June 28.--Postmaster Pearson is not in such danger of removal assome of his enemies would wish.
Johann Strauss's comic opera, "Prince Methusalem," was produced on Wednesday night at the Cosmopolitan Theatre, in the presence of a large and generously demonstrative audience.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28.--Capt. Lewis Barker, of the lost schooner Mary D. Leach, was arraigned before United States Commissioner Edmonds, to-day, on the charge of "willfully and corruptly casting away and destroying an American vessel, of which he was not the owner."

CHICAGO, June 28.--In the case of the State Savings Institution of Illinois, a petition was filed yesterday before Judge Tuley asking for letters rogatory to take the deposition of David D. Spencer, and a motion was made to prevent the Clerk of the Court from issuing a dedimus for the same purpose.
CLINTON, N.Y., June 28.--An usual, if not an unprecedented, Commencement incident marked the graduating exercises at Hamilton College to-day.

HANOVER, N.H., June 28.--The exercises of Dartmouth's One Hundred and Thirteenth annual Commencement opened this forenoon with the meeting of the Alumni in the college chapel.

Secret Service Agent Drummond, with his assistant, Daniel McSweeny, were busily engaged last evening in overhauling a trunk and desk belonging to A.F. Baldwin, who had been arrested late in the afternoon with counterferfeit quarters and half-dollars on his person.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28.--The jury in the case of John Syren, on trial for the killing of his brother's wife in March last, this afternoon returned a verdict of not guilty on the ground of insanity.
CONCORD, June 28.--The Senatorial situation is unchanged. Two votes were taken to-day with no result.

Two hundred and forty young ladies were awarded diplomas and licenses to teach yesterday, at the fourteenth annual Commencement of the Normal College of the City of New-York, at Sixtyeight-street and Fourth-avenue.

CINCINNATI, June 30.--Considering the extraordinary decline in provisions, with a heavy market for breadstuffs, the business situation is quite satisfactory. Money is abundant, and the current borrowing demand from business interests only moderate.

LONDON, June 16.--Comedy and tragedy move along in complicated proximity just now in the daily history of these exciting times. One is apt to feel the incongruous association of mirth and sorrow more perhaps in London than in any other great city of the world.
LEBANON, June 30.--For some time the library of the Lebanon Valley college, at Annville, has been systematically robbed by unknown persons. To-day four large cases were found at the station.

ELLIS P. PHIPPS, of Philadelphia, has been tried and found guilty of forgery. The sentence is that he shall suffer solitary confinement, at hard labor, for five years in the county prison. PHIPPS was for nearly ten years Superintendent of the Philadelphia Alms-house.

Last week's heavy rain-storm very seriously damaged the Hudson River strawberry crop, while it made the Connecticut strawberries almost unmerchantable.

Friends of Mr. Charles W. Cass, a young lawyer, of No. 2 Nassau-street, called at Police Head-quarters yesterday and reported his mysterious absence. Mr. Cass is a member of the firm of Stanton Cass, and is also the representative in this City of a number of extensive manufacturing concerns in the West and South-west.

Sam Benton, the Connecticut negro who is in the jail at White Plains charged with brutally outraging Miss Stoeum at Salem on Tuesday last, is in no way concerned regarding his position. He is a light-colored mulatto, with bright, intelligent features, weighs about 140 pounds, and is 38 years of age. He was well dressed yesterday in a suit of dark clothes.

ROCHESTER, July 1.--Early this morning the officers of the Rochester and Pittsburg Railway were startled by the receipt of news that a terrible accident had happened on their road, near the little station of Resselas, Penn., 150 miles from this city.

LONDON, July 1.--Mr. Biggar, member of Parliament for County Cavan, in a speech at Manchester, declared that the leading trait of the present Government was falsehood.

The Long Island News Company ran its first Sunday "newspaper express" train of the season to carry the Sunday morning New-York papers to the Summer resorts on Long Island yesterday, and Messrs. Allen and Morris, of the company, invited a number of leading citizens along the route to accompany the train and witness the delivery of the papers.

James H. Wynne returned to his home, No. 92 Myrtle-avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon in an intoxicated condition, and finding his wife on the bed ordered her to get up. She replied that she wasn't talking to him.
Seven firemen belonging to Engine No. 19 of the Brooklyn Fire Department had an almost miraculous escape from death late Saturday night.

CHICAGO, July 1.--Although the official notification has not yet reached Chicago or San Francisco, there is no doubt that Father P.W. Riordan, Pastor of St. James's Church, in this city, has been selected by the Papal authorities for coadjutor to Archbishop Alemany, of San Francisco, with right of succession.

At the weekly meeting of the Central Labor Union yesterday afternoon the Committee on Arrangements for the union's labor demonstration and picnic, to take place on Sept. 3, reported in favor of inviting Gov. B.F., Butler to act as Grand Marshal on the occasion.

Drum Major Nat Jenks, whose mighty snore awoke the State camp at Peekskill, was examined yesterday before the committee of the Drum Majors' Association appointed to investigate his case, at Schilling's Hotel, No. 364 Sixth-avenue. Major Jenks was arraigned upon the charge of seducing the drummers and fifers of other corps from their allegiance and persuading them by alluring promises to join the drum corps of the Seventy-first Regiment.

The encounter between Mr. J.C. Tower and Mr. August Belmont, Jr., at the depot of the Long Island Railroad in Hempstead on Saturday morning is the sole topic of discussion in that locality. Mr. Tower is a commercial traveler doing business in this City.

The period of speculation and guesswork as to the personnel of the Metropolitan Opera-house has at length come to an end, and a cable dispatch printed in yesterday's TIMES enlightened the reader as to the engagements effected by Mr. Abbey and his corps of advisers for the new abode of Italian opera in this City.

COLUMBUS, July 1.--The Bohemian of Saturday publishes an interview with D. Thornton West, of Springfield, one of the "young eagles" who had charge of one of Mr. Bookwalter's literary bureaus two years ago, and who is still in the ring.

LONDON, June 20.--There was a trial in the Court of Queen's Bench between Mr. Hunter, late editor of Bell's Weekly Messenger, and the proprietors of that once popular and flourishing journal, which is of some general interest.

PEEKSKILL, July 1.--When darkness came on last night there was scarcely a cloud in the sky, the stars shone, and the breeze was cool. The darkies at the mess hall got together and picked the banjo, rattled the bones, and sang. There was a man of Company C in the camp who could imitate a calliope.

The Treasury Department has issued a circular regarding the admeasurement certificates of Norwegian vessels entering ports of the United States, which provides that the certificates of sailing vessels shall be accepted as correct, and that remeasurement will be required in the case of steam vessels only when the masters cannot produce a certificate of admeasurement by what is called the Danube Rule.

WILLIAMSTOWN, July 1.--The year has witnessed the accession of one new Professor and instructor at Williams College.

The building season of 1883 is now sufficiently advanced to enable a close observer to speak of it with a certain degree of clearness. From most points of view it is all that could reasonably be desired.

BATAVIA, N.Y., July 1.--The most terrible drowning casualty that ever occurred in this locality happened on the Tonawanda Creek this afternoon, a few minutes after 5 o'clock, by the overturning of a small excursion steamer, the Stranger, which has been plying on the creek since June 1.

NEW-LONDON, July 1.--The meeting of the joint Board of Army and Navy Officers, to whom was referred the question of the proposed bridging of the Thames River, which was held in this city on Friday noon, was distinguished chiefly by a lively passage between Gov. Thomas M. Waller and Gen. J.H. Wilson, President of the New-York and New-England Railroad.

ST. PAUL, July 1.--C.H. Beaulieu, an Indian trader at White Earth, arrived in St. Paul last evening. According to the reports which he brings from that country affairs are far from being in a satisfactory condition, and the famous Father Tomasein, at Red Lake, will again receive considerable prominence.

Horton, who was appointed a Special Agent of the bureau in place of Mr. C.W. Eldridge, he had in his possession another letter making other complaints against Horton and asking an investigation of them also.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 1.--Pawtucket was visited this morning by the most destructive fire for many years.

CHICAGO, July 2.--The racing meeting of the Chicago Driving Park Association was continued to-day, with last Thursday's regular programme, which was postponed on account of rain. The track was in excellent condition and fast.

CINCINNATI, July. 3.--The Metropolitans were badly whipped in the game to-day, the last in the series of four with the Cincinnatis. They changed their battery, putting in Lynch and Reinschiager. PHILADELPHIA, Jnly 4.--The Pennsylvania branch of the Jefferson National Monument Assooiation was organized to-day in Independence Hall by Judge Thomas W. Bartley and E.B. Hay Esq., of Washington, President and Secretary of the Board of Inspectors. An address was delivered by Judge Bartley. Gov. Pattison was chosen President for the ensuing Year.
SANTA FE, New-Mexico, July 4.--The features of the second day of the tertiomillennial celebration were interesting. The Zuni Indians had a 10-mile foot-race. They painted their bodies

NEW-HAVEN, July 4.--Judge Denning, in the Criminal Court, to-day discharged Ezra Daggett, of New-York, who was tried on Tuesday on a charge made by the State Agent of the Humane Society that Daggett had driven his horse 90 miles in 15 hours. The discharge was on the ground that, while the horse had been driven that distance, it had been kindly treated and properly cared for. Daggett went to New-York to-day with the horse.

CHICAGO, July 4.--The weather to-day was bright and warm. The track was hard and somewhat slow, but the racing was good and the betting heavy. Ten thousand persons were in attendance. It was a field day, only two favorites winning, and in one or two instances--notably in the Garden City Cup--unexpected outsiders turned up in the first place.

LOWELL, Mass, July 4.--The regatta to-day, the most successful ever held here, was witnessed by 15,000 persons. The principal race, and the great attraction, was the professional single scull, free for all, prizes, $400, $200, and $100, distance three miles.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 4.--What at first was supposed to be an accidental drowning case at the Highlands of Navesink is likely to turn out a ernel murder.

Two games of base-ball of the League championship series were played on the Polo Grounds yesterday, and each resulted in victory for the New-York Club. In the morning the NewYork team defeated the Bostons by a grand rally at the bat in the latter part of the game, and in the ...
PORTSMOUTH, N.H., July 4.--About 1,500 people from all sections of the Union arrived here to-day to attend the decennial reunion of the Sons and Daughters of Portsmouth.

LONDON, July 4.--Mr. Lowell, the United States Minister, gave a reception to Americans to-day at his residence, where there was a large attendance. There was also a reception at the United States Consulate.

SEA SIDE, N.J., July 4.--Willie Wilcox, 17 years old, was drowned in the presence of 300 people while bathing in front of the Oceanic Hotel this afternoon. Young Wilcox, although a cripple, was an expert swimmer.

SALEM, Oregon, July 4.--The convicts in the State Prison to-day made a desperate attack on the officers and attempted to escape. Three of them were killed and two wounded. Eight escaped and are at large. None of the officers was wounded.

WESTBORO, Ohio, July 4.--Archbishop Purcell was thought to be dying yesterday afternoon, but he rallied during the night and regained consciousness this morning. He is somewhat better this evening.
DES MOINES, Iowa, July 4.--The Mutual Marriage Endowment Association of Oskaloosa has accepted the inevitable, and its officers announce that its affairs will be wound up.

PETERSBURG, Va., July 4.--The cornerstone of the State Normal and Collegate Institnte to be erected at Fleet's Farm was laid this afternoon by the Most Worshipful Grand Master, Thomas Clayton, of Hampton, Ohio, in the presence of an immense throng of spectators. LONDON, July 4.--The Parnell fund has reached 17,065. The deaths caused by the accident to the steam tram car at Huddersfield yesterday now number five.

CHICAGO, July 4.--In Chicago the "glorious Fourth" has had a very effective toy pistol observance. Boys have blown their little hands to atoms, a score or more have kindled fires, and the aggregate loss by Fourth of July confiagrations is heavy.
The fifth annual Summer meeting of the Williamsburg Athletic Club took place yesterday upon the club grounds, at Wythe-avenue and Pennstreet, Brooklyn, Eastern District.

JACKSON, Miss., July 4.--The Independent Party, sparsely represented from scattering counties throughout the State, met in convention in the House of Representatives at 12 o'clock to-day.

PORTLAND, Me., July 4.--The monument to George Cleves and Richard Tucker, the first settlers of Portland, was unveiled to-day with Masonic honors. At the City Hall, later on services were conducted in the presence on Mayor Deering and Gov. Robie and staff, with distinguished guests occupying the platform. A historical oration was delivered by the Hon. William W. Thomas, the newly appointed Minister to Sweden.
The Nerous Rowing Club, of Flushing, Long Island, had its annual regatta yesterday in Flushing Bay.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., July 4.--Cornell got on her sea legs again to-day. In a game race against four-oared crews, representing the University of Pennsylvania, Princeton, and Wesleyan Colleges, her boat came home a winner under circumstances astonishing to most oarsmen.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 4.--United States Detective M.G. Bauer to-day arrested three men here for passing counterfeit money, and found $319 in counterfeit trade dollars on their persons. The leader of the gang, a man named Caldwell, has several partners near Collinsviile, Ala., and has flooded that section with counterfeits.

BOSTON, July 4.--The regatta was advertised to begin at 10 o'clock A.M., but the first race was not called until 11. The first race, for professional scullers, three miles, for prizes of $150 and $75, had four starters.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 4.--William S. Cleary, aged 18, a son of Judge Cleary, the Commonwealth Attorney, Covington Circuit, and brother of Edwin Cleary, the actor, was drowned to-day in the Little Miami while bathing. Miller Stewart who attempted to rescue him, had a narrow escape from drowning.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 4.--Probably the largest crowd that ever assembled in Monumental Park witnessed the balloon ascension to-day. They had begun to come in at 4 A.M., and the crowd continued to increase until the time of the ascension.

Col. F.W. Parker, late Superintendent of the Primary Schools of Boston, has entered upon his duties as Principal of the Cook County Normal School, at Englewood.

An application was made at a railroad ticket office in this city not long since for a ticket to NewHampshire. "To what part of the State?" was the question asked by the agent. "Well," was the reply. "I don't exactly know, but it's next to that place called Vermont."
PARIS, July 5.--A telegram received here from Frohsdorff at 1 o'clock this morning says that the Count de Chambord's death is momentarily expected.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES, in discussing student self-government at Amherst College, states that it has worked well, but intimates that Amherst was the first institution in this country to inaugurate such a system.

The third annual regatta of the New Rochelle Rowing Club took place in the New Rochelle harbor yesterday afternoon, and was witnessed by several hundred spectators.
PHILADELPHIA, July 4.--Pastime Park was given up to English sports to-day. The chief attraction was a foot handicap race of 135 yards, in which there were 40 entries and 33 starters.
The excursion steamer D.R. Martin, of the Manhattan Beach line, was run into by a tug-boat as she was leaving her pier at 2 P.M., Tuesday, for Bay Ridge. The Martin was backing out into the

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., July 4.--A severe hail and thunder storm struck this vicinity, at about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, doing great damage to buildings, crops, Rumors of disasters are constantly coming in. James Riley, a well-known farmer was struck by lightning during the storm, and instantly killed.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., July 4.--The brass foundry and old rolling mill at Bethlehem were shut down last evening. Union men were employed in them. The works are to be started up with non-union men on Monday and trouble is feared.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 4.--A conference of railroad officers will be held at Columbia tomorrow to determine what course the railroads shall pursue as to the schedule of rates established by the State Railroad Commission.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 4.--The Times-Democrat will print to-morrow an interview with the Hon. T.T. Alain, of Iberville, Chairman of the Republican Executive ...

AMERICUS, Ga., July 4.--Several months, ago Mrs. Hill, wife of P.D. Hill and sister of the Rev. C.A. Evans, formerly a General in the Confederate service, died. Now her husband has died, of a broken heart.
TORONTO, Ontario, July 4.--Mathew H. Richey was sworn in as Lieutenant-Governor of Nova Scotia this afternoon.

There were more than 12,000 people at the Brighton Beach track yesterday to witness the six races that the association had provided. The winners were Charley Gorham, Arsenic, Little Minch, Orange Blossom, and Tennyson who ran a dead heat, John Ledford, formerly Westoner, and Buster. No very large dividends were paid in the mutual pools.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4.--The cricket-match between 11 English residents and 11 Americans which was begun yesterday was resumed this morning, with the former at the bat, and they were not disposed of until they had scored 259 runs.

The most popular pulpit orator in Virginia, says: "If I were to die today, I would not leave behind enough of this world's possessions to pay for my coffin and the digging of my grave." He wants to go empty-handed to heaven, but there are not many people who prefer going in that way.

CHESTER, Vt., July 4.--A farmer named Samuel Abbott, while shooting at a target to-day, accidentally shot his hired man, Henry Spaulding inflicting fatal injuries.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4.--The wires between this city and the Monmouth Park race track were tapped to-day and bogus messages were sent to the pool-rooms in this city. It is said the proprietors of the rooms paid but about $6,000 on them.
BOSTON, July 4.--Rufus P. Marsh, City Superintendent of Fiacks and Trucks, was sun-struck to-day and died in the evening. Five policemen were also overcome by the heat.
WASHINGTON, July 4.--The Hon. Richard T. Merrick yesterday afternoon took a party of gentlemen, including Judges Wylie, Hagner, and James, of the District Court; ...

Two gentlemen, at a large reception in NewYork last Winter, were discussing one of the foremost politicians of the country, a man who, whether in office or out, always keeps himself prominently before the public.
HAVANA, July, 4.--The steamer Newport, Capt. Sundberg, is detained here for repairs to her machinery.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 4.--Gen. Crook passed through this city this afternoon on his way to Washington. He said the rumor that he proposes to ask to be relieved from duty in Arizona is not true, and that he is going back to that Territory as soon as his mission to Washington is accomplished.

BOSTON, July 4.--The bicycle races on the Common were witnessed by 15,000 persons. They were won as follows: One mile, for amateurs, C. F. Haven, in 3:14 ; two miles, for amateurs, A.D. Claflin, 7:04 ; five miles, for professionals, C.F. Young, Boston, 17:18 ; three miles, for amateurs, H.D. Corey, 10:19 ; five miles, for amateurs, E. P. Burnham, 18:35.

COLUMBUS, July 4.--The Ohio State Board of Agriculture will not issue its July crop report until the wheat crop is harvested throughout the State, which will be about July 20.
PHILADELPHIA, July 4.--Early this morning there was a crowd of hopeful looking men gathered at the door of Inventor Keely's famous motor shop.

The report of William F. Beutler, a Referee appointed to pass upon the accounts of Henry N. Wickes, as Trustee of the estate of Catherine W. Van Rensselaer, under the will of Elizabeth Bleecker, has just been completed. It reveals an extraordinary series of deceits practiced by the Trustee, and shows misappropriation of a fortune by him.

NORWICH, July 4.--After the severe thunderstorm of last evening had passed and the west was unclouded, Mr. Charles W.R. Dow, manager of the telephone line of this city, went to the sink in his kitchen to draw water.
The suggestion of Mr. Charles Francis Adams, Jr., as a candidate for Governor is not to be taken seriously. Those who have talked with Mr. Adams

NORRISTON, Penn., July 4.--At an early hour this morning neighbors heard a disturbance in the house of James Jack. They entered and found his wife, Mary, 35 years of age, on the bed strangled to death. Jack was arrested. It is paid that he was drunk and had a neighbor, Alfred Harvey, in the house at the time. Harvey was also arrested and both were lodged in jail.

The fourteenth annual picnic and games of the St. Patrick's Alliance of America, District No. 1, of New-York, took place yesterday at Sulzer's Harlem River Park.
The annual regatta of the Argonauta Rowing Association took place at Bergen Point yesterday afternoon. The attendance was much more select than large.
Gen. Steedman claims to have saved the life of his friend Gen. Ward at Chickamauga with a dose of commissary whisky. But that sort of medicine didn't succeed on the battle-field at Columbus.

LYNCHBURG, Va., July 4.--The regatta of the Virginia, State Rowing Association took place here to-day. In the first trial heat for four-oared gigs, the Appomattox crew, of Petersburg, won, defeating the Rives University crew by half a length, and the Olympics, of Richmond, by a length and a half. The second trial heat was won easily by the Cockade City crew of Petersburg.

HARRISSBURG, Penn., July 4.--Both the burned women at the alms-house fire died this evenning from their injuries. Their names are Mrs. Geitz and Mrs. Koons. The latter is from Middletown; the other woman's home is not known. Both were about 70 years of age.

JACKSONVILLE, July 2.--In my last letter I gave you a description of the lake region of Florida. I have had nothing to say of the St. John's or the eastern coast, these sections being on the main line of travel and the subjects of letters
SOUTHAMPTON, June 20.--Even in "hard, gray English weather," Southampton is wellworth seeing. William the Conqueror, farsighted ...

UNION, Ind., July 5.--Dr. W.D. Hornbrook, a respected physician, was shot and killed in his office yesterday by Sam Hemminger, a farm laborer, with whom he had had some dispute about work. Hemminger was arrested.

MONTREAL, July 5.--The double cases of Thomas Davidson against Dame A. Winteler, his wife, and Dame A. Winteler against Them as Davidson, were decided this morning by Justice Papineau. The domestic troubles of the pair, who are well known in society here, have excited considerable interest.
Reports from all the principal grain-growing counties in the State have been received by the Chronicle.

It is pleasant to know that Mr. Freeman, whose praise is generally stinted, writes kindly of Green, the late lamented historian of England. "Mr. Green was good enough," writes our author, "in the dedication of one of his volumes, to speak of me as one of his masters in the study of English history."

WASHINGTON, July 5.--Leave of absence for four months, with permission to go beyond the sea, to take effect from the date of the expiration of the extension of leave of absence granted him June 13, 1883, hes been granted First Lieut. William Stanton, Sixth Cavalry.

NEW-TACOMA, Washington, June 23.--Senator Edmunds, accompanied by T.F. Oakes, First Vice-President of the Northern Pacific Railroad; Lieut. Arthur, United States Navy, and J.M. Berkeley, General Manager of the Western Division of the line, left Tacoma on Wednesday, the 20th, for the glaciers reported as existent on Mount Tacoma by Mr. B. Willis, of the Geological Survey.
WASHINGTON, July 5.--The Hill investigation was resumed this morning. Mr. Enoch Totten, of this city, appeared as additional counsel for Mr. Hill.

A number of persons visited the Cunard dock at the foot of Clarkson-street, North River, yesterday, to see the new steam-ship Aurania, whose voyage was interrupted by the breaking of her machinery when almost within sight of this port, and which arrived on Wednesday evening last.

Upon the return of Gen. Crook from his successful campaign in Mexico the citizens of Tucson, Arizona, gave him a banquet, at which Gen. E.A. Carr, Colonel of the Sixth Cavalry, commanding Fort Lowell, who had been looking after the Indians in the Territory during the absence of the commander of the department, was called out in response to the toast.
ALEXANDRIA, July 5.--The number of deaths from cholera at Damietta during the 24 hours ending at 9 o'clock Wednesday night was 111.

It is long since the reports on crop prospects, always abundant at this time of year from all parts of the country, have been as hopeful as they are just now. We have before us reports from nearly all the English counties, written during the last fortnight, and among them all there are only two, those from Durham and Lancashire, which are at all of a despondent character.
The acquittal of BRADY and the Dorsey party seems to have given Mr. WILLIAM A. COOK, a lawyer of Washington, an opportunity to secure a little free advertising.

Nothing could more effectually point the moral and adorn the tale of DENIS KEARNEY'S brief career as a leader of men than his summary expulsion from the AntiMonopoly Convention held in Chicago on Wednesday.
Between midnight on July 3 and 8 o'clock yesterday morning 58 alarms of fire were sent out. Damage was reported as resulting from 46 of the fires.
One hundred and fifty members of the NewYork Jewelers' Club and a number of guests representing various firms throughout the country left the Astor House at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

Archbishop Purcell died in the Ursuline Convent at St. Martin's, Ohio, at 11:45 o'clock Wednesday night. He was born in Mallow, a town at a railway junction about 17 miles from Cork, on Feb. 26, 1800. Purcell is a Southern Irish name, well known in Dublin.

CHICAGO, July 5.--This was the seventh regular day of the Summer meeting at the Chicago Driving Park. The weather was warm and fair, the track slow from the rains of last night, the attendance light, and the races of only moderate interest.

Prof. E.S. Holden, Director of the Washburn Observatory, returned last Wednesday night from his expedition to Caroline Island, in the South Pacific Ocean, where he went in march last, in charge of the American expedition, to view the total solar eclipse of May 6, under the direction of the Eclipse Committee of the National Academy of Sciences.

At various points in Texas bands of horsethieves are reported to be organized and plying an occupation which is ten-fold more injurious to the farming interests than the raids of Mexican stockthieves and forays of wild Indians ever were.

MONTREAL, July 4.--The increasing competition between railways and canals for the carrying trade between the Atlantic and the West, and the rivalry between the St. Lawrence and Erie canal systems, have lately been engaging a large share of attention in commercial circles on both sides of the line.

In the elder days the only guide about the somewhat intricate city of Boston was the Boston Almanac, a neat little publication containing not much else than a map, a calendar, and a few facts relative to the population, points of interest, and early history of the metropolis of New-England.
The Right Hon. John Winston Spencer Churchill, Duke of Marlborough, died in London. England, yesterday, of angina pectoris, in the sixty-second year of his age.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 2.--In grim December last a fashionable wedding took place in this city. The bride was Miss Sallie Whiting, of New-York, a granddaughter of the late Judge Swan, of Ohio.
SIMLA, July 5.--The Indian Government has decided to grant the Ameer of Afghanistan a large annual subsidy.
The most obvious reflection upon the farewell banquet to Mr. HENRY IRVING in London is how much further English society has moved than American society from the Puritanical view of the drama.

The extreme heat of Wednesday was modified somewhat yesterday, according to the thermometer. Unless a man carried a thermometer with him he would not have noticed it, however, as the difference in the maximum of heat between the two days was but 2 in favor of yesterday.
WATERBURY, Conn., July 5.--Young Mayor Greene Kendrick, of Waterbury, sat in his office in Irving Block to-day placidly smoking his meerschaum pipe and apparently at peace with all the world.
CHICAGO, July 5.--Little progress was made this morning at the National Conference of Anti-Monopolists.

The announced purpose of the Anti-Monopoly conference at Chicago was to form a new political party, but no sooner did the delegates get to talking than a wide divergence of opinion was revealed as to the expediency of attempting anything of the kind.

Considering the eminent piety and the self-denying laboriousness of the late Archbishop PURCELL, of Cincinnati, even the most callous worldling cannot repress a feeling of sadness when the last days of this prelate are contemplated.

CONCORD, N.H., July 5.--Two hundred and seventy-four members voted in joint convention to-day for United States Senator. Rollins received 14 votes more-than on Tuesday, but really suffered a slight loss, two of his men voting for President Bartlett and two others for District Attorney Burns, of Wilton.

LONDON, June 22.--An old gentleman who had lost his teeth was once speaking to another in a certain club. The listener could not understand the veteran, who had a considerable reputation as a linguist.
CHICAGO, July 5.--Congressman W.H. Calkins, of Laporte, Ind., is in this city, en route for San Francisco, where he proposes to stop five or six weeks, and then he will go to Arizona.

PITTSBURG, July 5.--The movement to depose the Knights of Labor from the leadership of trade organizations and substitute for it a federation of trades, which was reported in THE TIMES'S dispatches a week ago, is gaining strength.

DENVER, Col., July 5.--A terrible tragedy occurred in Grand County on the afternoon of yesterday, on account of the removal of the county seat from Hot Sulphur Springs to Grand Lake.

DUBLIN, July 5.--A dispatch from Ennis states that a farmer named Griffey has been shot and seriously wounded for taking a farm near that place which had been "boycotted" owing to the eviction of the former tenant. Griffey's house was entered by a party of disguised men, two of whom held him in bed while another fired three shots at him, shattering his knee.

The steam-ship Bolivia, of the Anchor Line, which arrived yesterday from Glasgow and Moville, brought 143 assisted immigrants who came on board at the latter port.

DOVER, N.H., July 5.--The damage done by the severe storms of rain, hail, and wind yesterday afternoon and evening in this neighborhood was quite extensive. The most serious loss was sustained by the Cocheco Print-works.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5.--A special dispatch to the Times says that some time ago it was noticed that the library of the Lebanon Valley College, at Annville, Penn., was being robbed, but the thefts had been committed in a very systematical manner.

About 1,000 persons assembled in Washington Base-ball Park, Brooklyn, yesterday, to witness a game between the Brooklyn and Harrisburg Clubs. Among those present was Veteran "Joe" Start, of the Providence Club, who said that he felt line a fish out of water while sitting in the grand stand.

A meeting of the Niagara Falls Reservation Commission was held at the office of Andrew H. Green, one of the Commissioners, at No. 214 Broadway, yesterday, Sherman S. Rogers, of Buffalo, was the only Commissioner absent. The first subject taken up was a proposed preliminary map.

CINCINNATI, July 7.--The city is unusually healthy this Summer. The number of deaths during June was fully 30 per cent. less than in June 1881 or 1882. Owing to the Spring floods the contrary was expected. FALL RIVER, Mass., July 7.--The printing cloth market is quiet in demand, and quotations closing steady at 3 5/8 cents and 3 1/8 cents for, respectively, 64 squares and 60X56 cloths; production for the week, 130,000 pieces; sales, 44,000 pieces and deliveries, 99,000 pieces, leaving the stock of hand 110,000 pieces.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 7.--The lightning played sad havoc hereabouts last night. Great damage was done to the electric light station.

CHICAGO, July 7.--A dispatch was received here to-day from Watertown, N.Y., stating that M.S. Nichols Co., the Chicago brokers who recently failed, had sued 23 Watertown speculators for $40,000 margins which the firm recently advanced to carry their accounts.

OTTAWA, July 7.--Cummings, who defeated Paine here on July 1, has been challenged by Steele, of Pennsylvania, for a level 10-mile race for from $500 to $1,000 a side. Cummings beat Steele in New-York a few weeks ago, but the latter was in poor health.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 7.--About a month ago the Auditor of the State revoked the certificates of four Iowa co-operative life insurance associations. The Home, of Burligton, has brought suit by mandamus to require the restoration of its certificate, and an agreed statement has been prepared, which will be heard by Judge Miracle, of Webster City, at this place on Thursday, July 12.

SARATOGA, July 7.--In the National Council of Education this morning the report of the Committee on Moral Education was discussed. D. B. Hagar, of Salem, Mass., submitted his report, as Chairman of the Committee on Normal Schools, on Academic and Professional instruction in Normal Schools.

WASHINGTON, July 7.--Commissioner Dudley has returned to Washington from the West. PHILADELPHIA, July 7.--The annual settlement of accounts of the Mint for the last fisca year closed yesterday. Representatives of the Treasury Department have for more than a week been weighing up enormous amounts of gold and silver on hand, and arrived at the actual loss in the operations of the institution for the period named.

LANCASTER, Penn., July 7.--A heavy thunder-storm passed over the southern and eastern sections of Lancaster County last evening, doing considerably damage. NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 7.--The Hon. John R. Beasley argued at length this morning in the Chancery Court on the motion to enjoin the State Funding Board from funding the bonded debt of the State under the 50.3 act. No opposing counsel appeared, and on the conclusion of Mr. Beasley's argument Chancellor Merritt stated that he would take the matter under consideration.

WASHINGTON, July 7. A party, including Chester A. Arthur, Jr., son of the President; Private Secretary Phillips, and a few New-York merchants, will leave NewYork City on Monday for a visit to the Restigouche Club, near St. john, New-Brunswick, a famous fishing resort. They expect to be absent about three weeks.

NEW-HAVEN, July 7.--A writ of habeas corpus was prayed out to-day in the case of Samuel E. Holmes, formerly the Assistant Superintendent of the Alms-house, who was committed to the Insane Hospital. Dr. C.A. Lindsley, Medical Professor at Yale College, who examined Holmes, reported that he found him sane on most subjects. The case was continued until Tuesday next.

BOSTON, July, 7.--A fire broke out at 8:35 o'clock this morning in the State Work-house at Bridgewater, and destroyed all the buildings with the exception of two barns. Calls for assistance upon Taunton and Brockton were responded to and their, steamers did good service.

The White-Star steam-ship Britannic arrived at Quarantine last evening after a passage of a little more than eight days from Queenstown. The recent round trip of the Britannic from Liverpool to this port and back again was accomplished in 19 days 2 hours and 30 minutes. This is said to be the quickest round trip on record, either from Liverpool or New-York.

READING, Penn., July 7.--Farmers in this section advance the theory that since the onslaught upon the English sparrows, which is permitted by recent legislative enactment, there has been a remarkable increase in the damage to crops by the Hessian fly and the wheat worm. The farmers attribute the ravages of these insects in the main to the destruction of the sparrow.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 7.--The opening polo games were largely attended by cottagers and others. The sides were: Reds--W.K. Thom, Jr., and Stanley Mortimer. Blues--F.O. Beach and G.H. Warren, Jr. Ton interesting games were played, the Blues winning six.

MONTREAL, July 7.--A local paper says that McDermott, the suspect, is in communication here with an Irish society which numbers nearly 200 members, whose objects are unknown. The Witness this evening publishes an interview with McDermott, in which he advocates Rossa's dynamite principles in the most extreme form. His real object here is unknown, and all accounts published are merely conjecture as to his movements.
